story:
It’s raw, it’s beautiful, and it’s happening!

A big idea that started as a grassroots effort, Philadelphia’s Rail Park is finally right on track. We at the National Trust for Historic Preservation, in collaboration with Heineken USA and the Friends of the Rail Park, are on a mission to ensure this unique public space shines when it opens its doors next year. With your support, we’ll be able to tackle additional enhancements that will make it the ultimate destination to meet, walk, bike, and play.

It all started with a dream. Could three miles of abandoned railroad tracks spanning 10 neighborhoods and 50 city blocks be reclaimed as usable green space? With the proper support, anything is possible.

The Rail Park stands on two unused rail lines that were built by the Reading Railroad to carry passengers and freight in and out of Center City. But the trains stopped running in the 1980s, and since then, the tracks have sat idle—until now.

As conceived, the Rail Park is made up of three distinct sections: the Viaduct, the Cut, and the Tunnel. Much like the High Line in New York City, the Viaduct soars overhead with amazing views of the city. It leads to the Cut, which ramps down below street level and runs through the city between high stone walls. Then, just behind the Rodin Museum, the line goes underground and becomes the Tunnel. Running beneath Pennsylvania Avenue, it features stunning stone arches illuminated by shafts of light from above ground.

For now, the space sits quiet. But soon, it will be filled with life. The Friends of the Rail Park see the park not simply as new green space, but as a dynamic gathering place that connects people across Philadelphia. They have plans for walking paths, bike trails, and public spaces for everything from art to education. And while they’ve already broken ground on the Viaduct, they still need help to fund some important finishing touches so that the first portion can open in early 2018.

Success! We're happy to report that our campaign raised $42,208! That's $27,208 above our original goal of $15,000!

So far, the construction team has begun critical repairs to the bridge structures. They’ve also removed the old soil that was tainted by years of engines running over the tracks and replaced it with clean, healthy earth. Now, thanks to the generous support of our backers, the Friends of the Rail Park can finish the work that makes a great park flourish—beautiful trees, inviting benches, and winding pathways. They even have plans to restore an abandoned Reading Railroad dining car into a welcome center for the entire park.

Please stay tuned to the updates section of this page for additional project news.

I claimed tickets to the Bruno Mars: 24K Magic World Tour as my perk and have questions.

Thank you for supporting our project! You will find answers to your questions in our FAQ. If you have specific questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com. Enjoy the show!

What is the National Trust for Historic Preservation?

The National Trust for Historic Preservation, a privately funded nonprofit organization, works to save America’s historic places. We are the cause that inspires Americans to save the places where history happened. The cause that connects us to our diverse pasts, weaving a multi-cultural nation together. The cause that transforms communities from places where we live into places that we love. As the leading voice for preservation, we are the cause for people saving places.

Our mission is to protect significant places representing our diverse cultural experience by taking direct action and inspiring broad public support.

Where is my donation going?

More than 90% of all funds raised will support the cities' projects and the National Trust’s ongoing work to save historic places in Philadelphia and around the country. Up to 10% will cover Indiegogo costs and processing fees, as described in Indiegogo’s Terms and Conditions.

When will I get my perk (non-ticket)?

Perks will be delivered later this summer (July/August).

Can I visit the project site?

Sadly, no, but soon it will be a wonderful green park filled with activities for everyone to enjoy.

When will the project be complete?

Saving places takes time! But with your generous support, we hope to get the Rail Park project completed as soon as possible.

How do I get support for my project? Or can I submit a project for consideration?

We at the National Trust are always interested in hearing about what is important to you. Although we may not be able to save it immediately, you can always contact your state’s historic preservation office and see how you can get started on the road to preservation!

Is the National Trust involved in other restoration projects?

Yes! We’re the country’s leading advocate for saving historic places. As such, we’re on the ground in communities across the nation. Visit our website to explore other historic places that we are trying to save like the Philadelphia Rail Park.

Media Inquiries:

For further media inquiries about these projects, check out our Press Center.

My question wasn’t answered above. Who can I contact?

First, please see the full FAQ for the Cities Project.

If you have questions about the projects or how to claim perks other than tickets, please email cities@savingplaces.org.

If you have questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email  fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com.

If you have questions about the Cities Project, please email  corporaterelations@heinekenusa.com.

story:
Завен Аршакуни (1932-2012)  - советский и российский художник армянского происхождения, представитель "шестидесятников". 
Характерная особеность творческих работ художника - это невероятные цвета: насыщенные, яркие, радостные, погружающие зрителя в светлый и жизнелюбивый мир автора. Такие потрясения, как война и блокада, несомненно, оставляют глубокий след, но Завен Аршакуни был тем художником, который раскрасил полный тяжёлых воспоминаний Ленинград яркими красками,  будто ребёнок, раскрасивший серый асфальт цветными мелками.


Выставка набросков Завена Аршакуни  в Цехе анимации - это некоммерческий проект, мы его делаем своими силами, поэтому без вашей помощи нам не обойтись.

Для того, чтобы выставка состоялась, нам нужно оборудование для оформления работ:

-рамы А4 и А3, а также подвесы для них;

-картон для паспарту; 

 

Также мы мечтаем выпустить печатную продукцию: открытки, стикеры и другие приятные вещи, которые станут подарками для всех, кто нам помог.


творчество Завена Аршакуни - это то, чем хочется делиться, что хочется показывать и о чём хочется рассказывать. Мы планируем продолжать делать мероприятия, связанные с творчеством этого замечательного художника и его современников.
Надеемся, что у нас получится заразить своей любовью и других.


Мы будем рады любой помощи, будь то репост или небольшое денежное пожертвование.

Спасибо вам всем за внимание, мы верим, что всё обязательно получится!

My friends and I are organizing an exhibition of one wonderful artist with Armenian roots.
Zaven Arshakuni (1932-2012) was born in Leningrad (now it's St. Petersburg), he survived in Leningrad blockade, lost both of his parents. But in spite of all these heavy parts of his life his paintings are full of joy and bright colors. Besides lots of paintings and decorative creations. Zaven made illustrations for a single soviet edition of "A Ballad about a Small Tugboat" poem written by Joseph Brodsky. And in addition to that he has created costumes and decorations for "Gayane" ballet by Aram Khachaturian.
This exhibition is about drafts and sketches, it's our first time of making suchlike projects, so we want this event to be small and intimate. But it could be great to continue working with materials left by Zaven Arshakuni to save his heritage and to tell a lot of people about his talent, his creativity, let them dive into his lightsome world with angels, birds, multicolored trams, motley houses.
This task is not easy, there is a lot of work ahead, but we hope that good deeds always get attention.
We need to frame Zaven's works (frames A3 and A4), also we want to print some postcards and stickers with Zaven's sketches for everyone who helped.
Zaven Arshakuni's creation inspires all of us and we're happy to share it with you.
Thank you for your attention!

story:
The Festival is organised by local residents – all volunteers.  On the day itself, dozens of people get involved to make it happen.  The Festival brings people together, celebrates local talent and provides a fantastic day for all – with a climbing wall, children’s activities, music, stalls, food, street entertainment - and thousands of people.   The fact that it is a free event is crucial – we want everyone to be able to come along.   It costs around £7000 to organise – to pay for the stage, PA equipment, public liability insurance, music licensing, climbing wall, First Aid, posters, leaflets, street entertainers and performers.  We are able to raise about £1000 through stalls, and get a small ‘Lets Get The Party Started’ grant from Newham Council.  Two local housing associations make a donation and we raise a bit of money from local businesses.  This crowdfunding campaign is crucial – without these donations, the Festival cannot happen in 2017.

We also need to spread the word - please share this campaign with people you know!  Even if you cant contribute, please do tell others - we need all the help we can get to reach our target of £3000.

story:
Who We Are

We are a group of students from Emerson College in Boston. We thrive on creating passion projects.

  • Our cast and crew range in age, major, specialty, and identity.
  • This music video is the biggest project the majority of us have taken on, and we can't do it without your support. 
  • This matters to more than just us.

The landscape of the entertainment industry is changing. This project is empowering young visual arts students to grow and to take media in America to the next level.

What We Need

Let's break it down. We want to do this music video right! That means we need capital to allow us to have access to things like:

  • Safe transportation for the cast, crew, and equipment
  • Locations and sets previously unavailable to student productions
  • Props, costuming, and makeup to bring the story within the music to life

What You Get

We want to thank our supporters by giving back. Here's what you can get from donating:

  • Exclusive Early Access to the music video for all levels of supporters
  • R.U.N. original vinyl stickers and signed posters mid-level supporters
  • A Producer credit for any supporter to fund the project in full

Risks & Challenges

As a student group, we understand that there are many challenges that we may run into that we are unfamiliar with. We can handle it.

  • Being students, we have a vast network of other students that will gladly help us get through tough times.
  • We will attack our challenges head-on, and we won't be afraid to ask for help when we need it. We're in this to learn, after all!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can support with a monetary donation. We hope that you consider helping us out in different ways!

  • Share our campaign to your friends to spread the word.
  • Keep your eye out for the video release and make sure to watch!

Props, costuming, and makeup to bring the story within the music to life


What You Get
We want to thank our supporters by giving back. Here's what you can get from donating:

Exclusive Early Access to the music video for all levels of supporters
R.U.N. original vinyl stickers and signed posters mid-level supporters
A Producer credit for any supporter to fund the project in full


Risks & Challenges
As a student group, we understand that there are many challenges that we may run into that we are unfamiliar with. We can handle it.

Being students, we have a vast network of other students that will gladly help us get through tough times.
We will attack our challenges head-on, and we won't be afraid to ask for help when we need it. We're in this to learn, after all!


Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that not everyone can support with a monetary donation. We hope that you consider helping us out in different ways!

Share our campaign to your friends to spread the word.
Keep your eye out for the video release and make sure to watch!

Hi! Do you know what Poetry Slam is?
If you're here, you probably already know, or you know someone who knows it, so we won't bother you with details about this art form (if you're new to it, go and enjoy it on youtube, you won't regret it!).

We are LIPS, the italian poetry slam league, and we're hosting this year's european championship finals in Milan. The event will take place on march 19-20-21, it will be hosted in a marvelous venue (BASE Milano is a huge and lovely area where concerts, theater, exibitions, book-fairs and other kinds of events fit perfectly) and we're planning to have an entire week of gigs and performances.

For the first time ever, the championship will see 30 poets from all around Europe compete for the title, and a lot of italian volunteers are already working in order to make this experience extraordinary for everyone involved.

We managed to cover expenses for hosting and food, for everyone, each day, but we wanted to cover travelling expenses for every participant and to create something special for you to enjoy.

We're creating a book

In order to raise the money we need to cover travelling and extra expenses, we wanted to give something unforgettable and enjoyable in return. So we thought about a book (but if you prefer a t-shirt or you need a tote bag, we have you covered).

The book will contain the best poem (in english and italian) from every slammer participating in the competition, it will have a literary compendium about languages and translations, but the real killing feature is that Martina Dirce Carcano (MDC Illustration) will illustrate the introduction page for every poet, giving an artistic touch to the anthology.

We want to make everyone feel our warm italian welcome, so we'll donate to each participant a bag with her or his copy of the book. You can have it too by contributing to the campaign. Feel free to chose among perks and spread the word if you think you know somebody who could be interested (or just do it in order to be sure that your favourite slammer won't have to WALK to Italy).

Come to see the event!

The best way to enjoy a poetry slam is to participate live, so feel free to go on our site and find all the details about the events, we'll be happy to hug you!

We're planning to have a lot of side events, workshops, live shows, open mics, and so on, so, if you're a poet and you want to be part of this community, make sure not to miss this opportunity. But if you can't make it to Italy, have yourself a wonderful book that gathers all the best poems, from the best poets.

Risks & Challenges

We're trying to plan everything, in order not to face unexpected expenses, but the organization of events of this size and proportions could be problematic, we just want to be sure to give everyone the best experience possible.

We're a team of 50 volunteers (and counting) that will take care of every aspect of the event, the production of the book and every little thing that concerns this special occasion.

Support words with words

If you can't support us here, first of all try to come and enjoy the championship with us, but be sure to spread the word of this campaign, in order to help us reach our goal.

Thank you so much for your attention and slam on!

 

|--->ITALIANO<---|

 

Unitevi a noi!

Ciao! Sai cos'è un Poetry Slam?
Se sei qui, probabilmente lo sai, oppure conosci qualcuno che lo sa, quindi non ti annoieremo con i dettagli su questa forma d'arte (se non la conosci, vai e goditela su youtube, non te ne pentirai!)

Siamo la LIPS - Lega Italiana Poetry Slam, e quest'anno ospiteremo le finali del campionato europeo a Milano. L'evento si terrà il 19-20-21 marzo, in un posto meraviglioso (BASE Milano è un posto enorme dove si tengono concerti, spettacoli teatrali, mostre, fiere del libro e altri eventi su larga scala) e stiamo preparando un'intera settimana di spettacoli e performance.

Per la prima volta, il campionato vedrà sfidarsi 30 poeti provenienti da tutta Europa, e un manipolo di volontari è già al lavoro per rendere questa esperienza straordinaria per chiunque avrà voglia di partecipare.

Siamo riusciti a coprire le spese di vitto e alloggio, ma vorremmo coprire le spese di viaggio per tutti i poeti e creare qualcosa di speciale che tutti possano godersi.

Stiamo realizzando un libro

Per raccogliere la somma necessaria per coprire le spese di viaggio e gli imprevisti, volevamo ripagarvi con qualcosa di indimenticabile. Così abbiamo pensato a un libro (ma se preferite una maglietta o una shopper, tranquilli, abbiamo anche quelle).

Il libro conterrà la migliore poesia (in inglese e italiano) di ogni slammer che parteciperà alla gara, ci sarà un compendio letterario su lingua e traduzione, ma la vera chicca è che Martina Dirce Carcano (MDC Illustration) illustrerà la pagina introduttiva di ogni poeta, dando un tocco artistico all'antologia.

Vogliamo far sentire a tutti il tipico benvenuto italiano, quindi doneremo a ogni partecipante una borsa con una copia del libro. Se sosterrai questa campagna, potrai portarteli a casa anche tu. Scegli l'offerta che ti interessa, ma soprattutto dillo a tutti se credi che possano essere interessati (o anche solo se vuoi che la tua o il tuo slammer preferita/o non debba camminare fino a Milano).

Vieni a vivere le finali!

Il miglior modo per vivere le finali e godersele dal vivo, quindi se ti interessa l'evento, troverai tutte le indicazioni sul nostro sito (orari e partecipanti), così, oltre a non pagare le spese di spedizione, potremo anche abbracciarti!

Stiamo pianificando un sacco di eventi collaterali, laboratori, spettacoli, microfoni aperti e così via, quindi, se ti piace la poesia e vuoi essere parte di questa comunità, non perdere questa occasione. Ma se non riesci a venire a Milano, assicurati di goderti almeno la migliore poesia dei migliori poeti in un'antologia illustrata.

Rischi e difficoltà

Stiamo provando a prevedere ogni particolare, per affrontare spese impreviste, ma l'organizzazione di eventi così grandi potrebbe essere problematica, vogliamo solo essere certi di dare a tutti la migliore esperienza possibile.

Siamo circa 50 volontari (sempre in aumento) che cureranno ogni aspetto dell'evento, la produzione del libro e ogni minimo dettaglio di quest'occasione speciale.

La parola s'alimenta di parola

Se non puoi sostenerci, ti invitiamo a venire a trovarci e a goderti il campionato con noi, ma ti saremmo grati se potessi diffondere il link a questa campagna, così che noi si raggiunga l'obiettivo e si possa fare tutto al meglio.

Grazie infinite per l'attenzione e buono slam!

story:
Why PAYA?

In 2016 PAYA was a huge success in both creating space for networking, collaboration, exchange and training for young East African Artists as well as empowering youth to recognize and harness their talents and strengths in order to build innovativeness and self direction. This trans-boundary and multicultural project recognizes culture as a powerful tool for social change and acknowledges expressive arts having the ability to reach people with various mindsets, attitudes and experiences. In 2016 the project involved about 200 youth from 6 orphanages and centres and 50 East-African artists from Kenya and Tanzania.

As there is no confirmed funding for 2017 this campaign is collecting the needed funds to carry through similar youth projects in various locations in November-December 2017. Through these projects the youth are exposed to various art forms and guided through a creative process that will develop their confidence and self-expression as well as social skills and team working. The goal is to include 15 artists and about 100 youth in 4 locations in both Tanzania and Kenya. 

For the youth participants, most coming from socio-economically challenged backgrounds these type of projects are creating meaningful experiences helping them to grow to responsible and active citizens.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To make PAYA 2017 happen in the best way possible we are in need of 8 000 USD. This will be used for carrying out youth several projects in Tanzania and Kenya and organising PAYA FEST 2017 in Arusha, Tanzania to showcase the work of the projects. The funds will be used for:

  1. Materials for creating the performances, e.g. costumes and props (400$)
  2. Food & Accomodation for approximately 100 youth during project and final festival (1300$)
  3. Communication & Documentation, e.g. producing documentaries and video material for each youth project and printing t-shirts for participants (2100$)
  4. Per Diems to cover food and accommodation during project for approximately 15 young artists volunteering their expertice (2000$)
  5. Transportation costs of artists and youth between Kenya and Tanzania and in town (600$)
  6. Permits & Licenses, e.g. work permits for artists crossing the borders and event organizing permits (700$)
  7. Venue & Equipment hire for the festival, including required security and maintenance staff (900$)

Even if we do not reach the total fundraising goal we will be able to carry through the project. The funds will be used in the priority order presented above and the budget will be adjusted according to available funds. The more funds we have the more youth we are able to involve! With this 8000 USD we are able to include about 100 youth in 4 locations. The more funds the more youth and locations are involved!

So even few hundred dollars more we can collect through this campaign will make a huge difference!

By supporting this project you will support the growing creative industry of East Africa and promote empowering work done among youth of East Africa. You will get to follow the project closely from social media and we will send you the project t-shirt as a thank you for your generosity and help!

 

What are we actually doing and how we do it?

The artists will spread out to community centres and children homes and explore arts with the youth. Together they will create a perfomance based on a traditional african story. This performance will be recorded and presented at the PAYA FEST 2017 in Arusha. The youth close to Arusha region will perform live at the festival together with local and guest artists.

Our team consists of talented and motivated people who are donating their expertise to this project and its actualization. We have also valuable partners who are assisting with various ways to make this project a successful one. All the people and partners involved are committed making this project for the benefit of the next generation and for the promotion of arts and culture in the society.

Some of the activities however are still in need of a financial assistance and with your help we will be able to:

  • Purchase materials needed to create the performance art productions (e.g. costumes and props)
  • Feed the youth during the project and giving them a place to stay during the festival
  • Produce communication materials such as t-shirts to give to the youth participants and publish advertisement and documentation of the project in different medias
  • Provide per diems to cover costs occurring for artists volunteering to work for the project
  • Transport artists between the locations and bringing the youth participants to the performance location
  • Obtain the required licenses from the government for the implementation of the project
  • Hire a venue and necessary technical equipment such as light and sound for the final festival

 

Why we need you?

Good will of people involved and generosity of partners goes a long way. But not everything can be obtained through sponsors and thus we are crowdfunding to cover the remaining costs of the project.

Cross cultural youth project can have many challenges, but as this is the second year of PAYA we have already found ways to overcome many of them and know already how these can be avoided.

In 2016 the PAYA project was supported by UNESCO's International Fund for Promotion of Culture and GIZ & EAC inniative Incubator of Integration and Development in East Africa (IIDEA).

For 2017 we are without project funds and WE NEED YOUR HELP in covering the remaining costs. All donators can request a full report on activities and how the finances were used after the project is completed!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We do appreciate your help also in other ways! If you are located in East-Africa and can help us for example with donations or discounts in some way please contact us! We will happily hear about your offer on materials/making costumes, renting equipment, assistance in travel costs, food donations etc. Whatever you think would help this project!

Also your help is valuable by sharing and making noice about this project and help us raise the needed funds!

story:
Help us build the House.

Our Story

The Rogers Experimental House was born on the bricks of Rogers, Arkansas, the second week of June 2016 during a chance meeting and sidewalk conversation between founding board members Dayton Castleman, a Rogers-based artist and museum professional, Jessica Hester, a Rogers-based architect, and Karen Wagaman, downtown development VP at the Rogers-Lowell Chamber of Commerce. The consensus was that downtown Rogers would make an ideal home for a space driven by making, and by facilitating the growth of innovative ideas - a place where art, and technology, and learning, and skill-building could thrive and become a creative resource to the community. 

Conversations about just what form that making space might take continued for the next several months, including public forums to begin building a community of partners and collaborators, shaped by Dayton's and Jessica's involvement in the founding and operation of artist-run and maker-run spaces in Philadelphia, Chicago, and Rome, Georgia. That summer we added board members Morgan Hooker, a local real-estate developer, and David Vaden, an accountant, and by the fall of 2016 we had incorporated and begun the process of applying for non-profit status, receiving our 501(c)(3) in December of 2016. 

2017 came with the potential to test drive the Rogers Experimental House in a temporary home with a wonderful address. The Elks Lodge at 121 W Walnut sits in the heart of downtown Rogers, steps from Arkansas Public Theatre, the Rogers Historical Museum, and Rogers' growing mix of eateries, breweries, and unique shopping. By April we had secured the opportunity to create a pop-up creative space on the ground floor of the building, as an incubator and community-building pilot for the future Rogers Experimental House.

What the House needs.

Like any "new" house, we need a few things to keep us running and facilitate the creative work we want to support.

  • Furnish the House! We are in need of work tables, seating, and storage solutions in order to host workshops, classes, performances, and community gatherings. Hufft, a design-build firm based in Kansas City with an outpost in Bentonville is on board to assist us by donating design and shop time to fabricate customized solutions to help us get the most out of the space, and to expand with us when we grow into a future, permanent home. We need to purchase materials to fabricate our work furnishings, and your contribution can help us furnish the House!
  • Keep the lights on! While use of the space has been generously donated, we have expenses in the form of utility and insurance costs, as well as day to day supplies for maintenance and cleaning, and signage to let the community know who we are. The space is our greatest current asset, and in order to host the creative life of the community into the future, we need to pay our utility bills! Your contribution can keep space running!
  • Be the Experimental House! Projects already in the works include collaborations with Rogers Public Schools, public art projects, and community gatherings for learning and skill-building. We need contributions to help us fund our community creative life. We're releasing a call for proposals in order to support pop-up projects of all kinds and your contribution can help us make those happen!

Every donor to the Rogers Experimental House will be recognized by name with a tile on our 3D printed donor wall - a mosaic of hexagonal plaques that will grow with us and recognize those who have contributed to establishing a making space for the region in downtown Rogers.

Rogers' Experimental House

As our region's cultural footprint and influence expand, so does its population of creative professionals and artists. Anchored by major cultural institutions like Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, and the Walton Arts Center, the opportunity exists for localized cultural specialization, and we'd like to see Rogers become a hub for artists, for supporting independent projects, and for creative innovation.

Join the Experimental House Family

Even if you can't contribute to our campaign you can be a part of the movement to establish a making space in Rogers:

  • Share this fundraiser with friends and family!
  • Volunteer to help!
  • Submit an idea for a project, gathering, workshop, or class!

Hufft, a design-build firm based in Kansas City with an outpost in Bentonville is on board to assist us by donating design and shop time to fabricate customized solutions to help us get the most out of the space, and to expand with us when we grow into a future, permanent home. We need to purchase materials to fabricate our work furnishings, and your contribution can help us furnish the House!
Keep the lights on! While use of the space has been generously donated, we have expenses in the form of utility and insurance costs, as well as day to day supplies for maintenance and cleaning, and signage to let the community know who we are. The space is our greatest current asset, and in order to host the creative life of the community into the future, we need to pay our utility bills! Your contribution can keep space running!
Be the Experimental House! Projects already in the works include collaborations with Rogers Public Schools, public art projects, and community gatherings for learning and skill-building. We need contributions to help us fund our community creative life. We're releasing a call for proposals in order to support pop-up projects of all kinds and your contribution can help us make those happen!

Every donor to the Rogers Experimental House will be recognized by name with a tile on our 3D printed donor wall - a mosaic of hexagonal plaques that will grow with us and recognize those who have contributed to establishing a making space for the region in downtown Rogers.



Rogers' Experimental House
As our region's cultural footprint and influence expand, so does its population of creative professionals and artists. Anchored by major cultural institutions like Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, and the Walton Arts Center, the opportunity exists for localized cultural specialization, and we'd like to see Rogers become a hub for artists, for supporting independent projects, and for creative innovation.

Join the Experimental House Family
Even if you can't contribute to our campaign you can be a part of the movement to establish a making space in Rogers:

Share this fundraiser with friends and family!

Volunteer to help!
Submit an idea for a project, gathering, workshop, or class!

story:
Please consider donating to the founding of the Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive (LLTA) and make a home for an extensive and varied collection of transgender archival materials.

Help get hundreds of publications and thousands of photographs out of storage and into a dedicated space where they will be available to researchers and the public.  

We hope to raise $25,000 for remodeling an existing structure to create a 250 square foot space in Vallejo, CA, with controlled temperature, relative humidity and air quality.  The LLTA will have UV filters on all windows to protect the holdings from the damaging effects of ultraviolet exposure.  We are also exploring renewable energy sources to lower operating costs. Many items are 100 years old or more and warrant meticulous care.

 

The archive is named in honor of Northern California transgender pioneer Louise Lawrence, who began living full-time as a woman in 1942, first in the Berkeley, CA, then San Francisco.  She, along with Virginia Prince and others, published the first incarnation of Transvestia in 1952.  Louise’s address book was the initial subscription list and she was instrumental in developing the trans community’s connection to pioneering sex researchers such as Alfred Kinsey and Harry Benjamin.

Your donations are Tax Deductible thanks to our generous fiscal sponsor the GLBT Historical Society and Museum in San Francisco. 10% of our proceeds benefit their incredible efforts to archive and exhibit our queer history.

Support from other Transgender Archives

I have had the pleasure of having Ms. Bob Davis give me a tour of her extensive collection of trans historical materials. What a treasure trove! The collections are both varied and deep. The materials are meticulously cared for, and most carefully organized. Anyone who uses the Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive will be pleasantly and continuously delighted. Even more so if you have the opportunity to benefit from Ms. Bob’s vast knowledge of the field.

– Aaron Devor, PhD, Chair in Transgender Studies, Founder and Academic Director, The Transgender Archives, University of Victoria, BC

Ms. Bob Davis is a life-long collector of transgender print media and ephemera. The depth and breadth of the material is astonishing, ranging from autographed books to support group newsletters to slick magazines to rare publicity shots from the turn of the XX century onward to mid-XXth century Parisian night club programs. Ms. Bob knows every piece intimately. Even better, she has become an expert at deciphering and finding meaning in early material. She and her library are treasures and must be protected at all costs.

– Dallas Denny, MA, Founder, National Transgender Library & Archive, housed in the Labadie Collection, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor

LEFT: Holiday card from Virginia Prince to the members of Phi Pi Epsilon (Foundation or Personal Expression) and Transvestia subscribers. CENTER: Cover of Transvestia Magazine #22 1963. RIGHT: Cover of Ladylike Magazine 1992 with “Tippi” as Princess Angel (left) and Miss X as Queen Veneer from the cult film “Vegas in Space.”

A Message from Ms. Bob Davis

Founder and director of Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive

For over 35 years I have been fascinated by the history of my trans community, the people who formed it and those who preceded it.  The first transgender magazine I bought was the premiere issue of Female Mimics International in 1979.  By the early 1990s I had accumulated a rich trove of transgender history, information that many in the community wanted to see.  I began to share the archive by writing history columns for trans community publications such as Lady Like, Transgender Community News and Transgender Tapestry.  Many of these articles are available at the Transgender Forum archive www.tgforum.com.  I have presented lectures on trans history at conferences such as the 2nd International Congress on Crossdressing, Sex and Gender, California Dreamin’, and Fantasia Fair (2014). By 2000, scholars of transgender history had begun requesting access to my archive because of its depth and the rarity of its holdings.

The LOUISE LAWRENCE TRANSGENDER ARCHIVE is the next logical step, a community-based institution that will make this important collection available to scholars and the public.  The history of marginalized communities is elusive, imperiled and best preserved by the community itself.  The LLTA will preserve transgender history and encourage its study.

-----------------------------------

Ms. BOB DAVIS, LLTA founder & director, served two terms on the board of GLBT Historical Society, one as secretary.  She presented her lecture, “Do the Clothes Fit? - Searching for Trans Identity in Archival Images of Cross-dressing,” at Moving Trans History Forward, the world’s first academic conference on transgender history (2014), at the University of Victoria, BC.  Ms. Bob delivered the opening keynote at the 40th annual Fantasia Fair (2015), the world’s longest running, annual transgender event.  Her article, “Using Archives to Identify the Trans* Women of Casa Susanna,” appeared in Transgender Studies Quarterly’s “Archives & Archiving” issue (2015), Duke University Press.  She teaches music at City College of San Francisco.

The collection of archival materials that Ms. Bob has amassed is truly extraordinary––it stretches back long before “transgender” even existed and it thoroughly documents the emergence of what we now understand to be transgender community. Ms. Bob’s lifetime of community engagement, activism, and leadership provides an unparalleled knowledge base for this collection. Any researcher who is able to work with this collection would be in for a real treat!

-- K.J. Rawson, Ph.D., Director, Digital Transgender Archive

 

LEFT: Bigwood Twins, early 20th century vaudeville female impersonators. CENTER & RIGHT: Publicity still for EMERGENCE, a 1977 trans man autobiography by Mario Martino pictured on the right. The center image on the left is Mario as a young woman named Angela.

Support from the Transgender Community

 

Ms. Bob Davis is a true connoisseur of particular veins US transgender history, with an exquisite collector’s eye for material associated with theatrical impersonation, heterosexual cross-dressing, and male-to-female gender expression. Her vast personal collection is full or rarities; it is of great historical value and will be a boon to researchers, but just as importantly, it’s also a playground for anybody with a curious and open mind. It’s a treat simply to paw through boxes and shelves full of archival materials that document, in exquisite detail, that gender is a whole lot more complicated than most people ever suspect.

– Susan Stryker, Ph.D., author of Transgender History, Director of the Institute for LGBT Studies, University of Arizona

 

Ms Bob is a fascinating human being who has created a deep and fascinating archive of transgender material that includes the kind of ephemera that makes history come alive. The Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive will be a treasure trove of information that scholars will love. This unique archive offers access to material not found elsewhere and cataloged intelligently. You may also have the privilege of discussing the material with Ms. Bob for further insight.

– Mariette Pathy Allen, M.F.A., photographer, writer, speaker, author of TransCuba and ally of the transgender community since 1978

 

The Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive will be an amazing and much needed resource for the transgender community and scholars alike. Ms. Bob Davis has assembled a formidable collection of publications and other artifacts from past (and largely forgotten) eras of trans history. Preserving this collection, and making it accessible to the public, is a laudable goal!

– Julia Serano, author of Whipping Girl: A Transsexual Woman on Sexism and the Scapegoating of Femininity

 

I first got to know Ms. Bob while working on a trans history display for the GLBT Historical Society in San Francisco. While we worked on the curation of the display, I discovered her passion for history, as well as her keen eye for culturally significant items. This is one person, and one project, I would strongly recommend pursuing. I cannot think of any one person who I would turn to more when it comes to a true archive of important transgender materials like this.

– Gwen Smith, transgender activist and author of syndicated column “Transmissions”

 

The Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive is absolutely critical for our Transgender/Trans/Genderqueer/Non-Binary Histories. As we know, marginalized people’s lives and stories are often erased – and once gone, it is nearly impossible to fight against dominant voices saying we have never existed. 

Ms. Bob Davis’s curating, collecting, preserving, and housing of the Louise Lawrence Transgender Archive needs to be fully supported. I have been amazed by Ms. Bob Davis’s collection and think that we must all support her endeavor to make this archive fully accessible in a place where students and researchers have the ability to to work with them so that we can all continue to uncover the stories of our lives. Please help me in supporting this project.

–Ardel Haefele-Thomas, Ph. D. author of the forthcoming Introduction to Transgender Studies.

 

LEFT: Ambi Sextrous, who promoted herself as, “slightly extraterrestrial androgynous vocalist.” CENTER: 1960s Parisian female impersonator Maxy photographed by Teddy Piaz RIGHT: Hand drawn and colored handbill by Doris Fish.

 

Support from Researchers

While I was collecting data for my dissertation, Ms. Bob was gracious enough to open her home and her vast collection to me. Having spent time at every major transgender archive in North America and some beyond, I can say without a doubt that Ms. B’s collection is not only one of the richest I have seen, but its materials have also been meticulously cared for. Scholars and community members – this collection cannot be missed!

– Demetrios Psihopaidas, Ph.D. Candidate, University of Southern California

Bob Davis’s archive has been invaluable to my research for a biography of the Sydney and San Francisco drag performer Doris Fish (1952–1991) and the circle around him. The collection of materials Ms. Bob has amassed is extensive and superbly organized, and Ms. Bob’s knowledge of it is profound. These are materials I could never have found elsewhere. Their importance to my project has been inestimable; I’m grateful to have had access to them and very much hope other researchers will be able to share my good fortune.

–Craig Seligman, author of Sontag and Kael: Opposites Attract Me and the forthcoming Homage to Doris Fish

The work Ms. Bob has done in collecting historical trans archives over the years is invaluable. I was grateful to have access to this treasure trove of materials while editing MAJOR! a documentary film about trans pioneer Miss Major Griffin-Gracy. I highly recommend the archive to researchers and artists who are seeking materials about transgender history. There is a rich history of trans individuals and communities that has existed long before the age of the internet and Ms. Bob’s archives includes much of this.

–StormMiguel Florez, co-producer and editor of MAJOR!

 

PERKS AVAILABLE WITH DONATION

Speacial Thanks 

Thanks and gratitude to the people who donated their time and talents to this campaign:

Jim McKee  earwax productions: Sound recording and mixing 

Rob Oakley  Architectural design and drawings

and especially

Robyn Adams Secret Fan Base Design - Graphic design, website, video, and campaign cheerleading.

story:
Scroll down for English

’S e iomairt shòisealta a th’ annainn a tha airson a’ Ghàidhlig a bhrosnachadh ann an Steòrnabhagh. ’S e ar n-amas gum fosgail sinn ionad Gàidhlig ann an Steòrnabhagh far am bith cafaidh, bùth, agus àite airson tachartasan. Bidh na trì pàirtean dhen ionad (cafaidh, bùth, agus àite-thachartasan) am measg a chèile los gum bi cothrom aig ‘cèilichean’ air strùpag agus biadh a ghabhail fhad ’s a tha iad a’ coimhead air na rudan ri reic agus air na tachartasan.

Chuir Dr Teàrlach Wilson An Taigh Cèilidh air chois. Tha teaghlach aige ann an Leòdhas agus rinn e PhD ann an Gàidhlig. A-nis, tha e a’ feuchainn ri cothroman cleachdaidh a thogail dha luchd-labhairt agus luchd-ionnsachaidh na Gàidhlig. Tha cafaidh aig a mhàthair Chuimreach, Maighread Wilson. Còmhla ri chèile, tha iad ag obair air gnìomhachas teaghlaich agus a’ cur an eòlasan ri chèile airson ionad Gàidhlig fhosgladh ann an Leòdhas. Bidh cafaidh, bùth, agus àite thachartasan ann.

Anns a’ bhùth, bidh sinn ag rèic rudan a bhios dèanta air an eilean le luchd-labhairt na Gàidhlig, leithid ealan, dealbhan, coinnlean, siabann, An Clò Hearach, agus briosgaidean. Bidh leabhraichean Gàidhlig agus cèol Gàidhlig ri rèic, cuideachd.

Bidh Gàidhlig air a h-uile càil anns an ionad: na soidhnichean, an clàr-bìdh, agus na docamaidean a’ ghnìomhachais. Bidh Beurla ri taobh na Gàidhlig no fon Ghàidhlig far am bi feum, leithid na soidhnichean air na dorsan-èiginn agus docamaidean laghail. Bidh Gàidhlig aig na luchd-obrach, agus tòisichidh iad a h-uile còmhradh ann an Gàidhlig.

Bidh tachartasan Gàidhlig againn, leithid ceòl tradaiseanta, bàrdachd, òraidean air an eachdraidh ionadail no air an àrainneachd, feasgaran-teatha, agus leughaidhean leabhraichean (dha cloinn agus dha na h-inbhich). Bidh sinn a’ ruith clubaichean sòisealta cuideachd, leithid diofar chearcallan còmhraidh (dha luchd aig diofar ìrean comais-labhairt), clubaichean phàrant agus phàiste, agus clubaichean leughaidh.

Mar sin, bidh rudeigin ann dha: (1) luchd-labhairt fhileanta na Gàidhlig a tha a’ sireadh beatha sòisealta anns a’ Ghàidhlig; (2) luchd-ionnsachaidh a tha a’ sireadh chothroman cleachdaidh agus air a bhith air am bogadh; (3) teaghlaichean a tha a’ sireadh rudan ri dhèanamh còmhla ris a’ chloinn; agus (4) luchd-turais a tha airson cultar an eilein fhaicinn.

Tha sinn airson leigeil ris dhan t-saoghal gur e cànan beò a th’ anns a’ Ghàidhlig agus gun dèan an cànan airgead.

Ach, tha sinn feumach air bhur cuideachadh. Tha duaisean ri fhaighinn ma bheireas sibh tabhartas dhuinn! Agus, ma tha beachd sam bith agaibh air tachartas nuair a bhios sinn fosgailte, cuir fios thugainn! tearlach@taighceilidh.co.uk

 

English here:

I'm Charles, though my Leòdhasach family and friends know me as Teàrlach, even in English! I'm part Leòdhasach, part Glaswegian, and part Welsh! In 2016, my Welsh mum, Margaret Wilson, founded Tolgate Coffee in Strood, Kent. It had always been a dream of hers to have a sophisticated coffee shop with the heart of the community at its centre. After hard work and dedication, with some help from family and friends, she now owns one of the nicest coffee shops, with some of the best food and drink, in Kent.  Now, expanding on Tolgate, I have joined the team to make Tolgate Coffee a national, family-run business, offering a unique side to coffee shops: local culture. There's plenty to choose from in the UK, but the Outer Hebrides of Scotland have some of the oldest, most traditional ways of life in Europe. Tolgate Coffee is going to use its Kent branch as a foundation for its daughter branches, but each will have their own unique take on the local culture of their locations. 

And so, An Taigh Cèilidh was born.

When I lived in Italy and Poland, I had a genuinely immersive experience in the cultures and languages. This made my languages progress. When I did my PhD in Gaelic, I found that not only were there few (if any) immersive experiences for learners, there were few public spaces for more fluent and native speakers. I was particularly surprised to find no dedicated Gaelic spaces in Stornoway - the so-called "Capital of the Western Isles" - and the Western Isles being the so-called "Traditional Gaelic Heartland". Now that I teach Gaelic, students often ask for recommendations for immersive experiences. This is where Gaelic differs fundamentally from, say, Italian. And, living in Stornoway, my guests often ask me where they can experience local culture. As a Leòdhasach ùr ('New Lewisperson'), I am also concerned about the stability of the local culture, and I truly believe (as do organisations such as Bòrd na Gàidhlig, University of the Highlands and Islands, Visit the Outer Hebrides, and the Scottish Government) that Gaelic is not just of cultural value to Scotland, but also of genuine economic value. 

So, An Taigh Cèilidh will provide the immersive experience for learners, the social space for speakers, the flavour of the island to visitors, and the economic support to Gaelic arts and traditional industries. The space we intend to buy is on Cromwell Street in the heart of Stornoway, next door to the old Town Hall, the Stornoway Historical Society, and the Story of Harris Tweed exhibition. We are close to the ferry pier, the bus station, free and paid parking, An Lanntair arts centre, and most town centre accommodation. We will be on the pedestrianised section of Cromwell Street, which will allow us to open up onto the street, which will make Stornoway particularly lively on a good day! Therefore, we will be normalising Gaelic that can be used as an everyday language in public spaces, just as you'd find, say, Polish in Poland.

All staff will be Gaelic-speaking, and every interaction will start in Gaelic. We will host events and performances in Gaelic, such as talks about local history, singing, poetry recital, book readings, and traditional music. We will house Gaelic social clubs, such as a Gaelic book club for adults, a Gaelic book club for children, a Gaelic club for parents with children in Gaelic schools, a Gaelic knitting club, and a Gaelic dog club. We will have a daily conversation circle for Gaelic learners, and Gaelic-medium lessons for things such as art and French.

We will sell Gaelic books, Gaelic greetings cards, Gaelic post cards, Gaelic CDs, and Gaelic DVDs. We will sell gift items, such as soap, candles, tweed items, art, photos, frames, and cups - made by Gaelic speakers and all labelled in Gaelic. This will be good for gift ideas, souvenirs, and supporting Gaelic talent and economy. Some of our profits will go into developing a Gaelic Scrabble and a Gaelic Monopoly board games. The in-house coffee shop will use local products from the island where possible (e.g. Stornoway black pudding), with our baristas trained to make truly artisan coffees. There will be no plastic in the hub, and part of our mission is to highlight and educate on environmental issues, especially those affecting the Outer Hebrides. The walls of the hub will be used as space to showcase gift items (especially art and photography), as well as an exhibition space (especially educational exhibits, such as environmental issues).

As well as ethical pay initiatives to support our staff and suppliers, we will also invest in mentorship and internship programmes. We will support our suppliers in taking on mentees to help people - especially young people - to train in arts and traditional industries, such as Tweed making. We will invest in internships in the centre to help learners and young people to develop business skills that will help with a Gaelic and island economy. If the hub does well, this model can be replicated elsewhere, and our interns can go off to develop the other hubs, or develop their projects and ideas.

An Taigh Cèilidh will be a Gaelic-focused cultural centre with events and performances in Gaelic, gift items made by Gaelic speakers and labelled in Gaelic, housing Gaelic social activities. We will be investing in Gaelic speakers and the island economy. Above all, it will appeal to everyone, whether they are  a native speaker or have no Gaelic at all. Whether you just want to experience local culture, or whether you want to find friends with similar interests, and have a place where you can, well, just use Gaelic.

 

We are really excited to launch this concept and we hope you are too. If you love coffee culture and your local culture - we'll help you marry the two! Thank you for taking the time to read our story and we look forward to welcoming you into An Taigh Cèilidh very soon.

’S e iomairt shòisealta a th’ annainn a tha airson a’ Ghàidhlig a bhrosnachadh ann an Steòrnabhagh. ’S e ar n-amas gum fosgail sinn ionad Gàidhlig ann an Steòrnabhagh far am bith cafaidh, bùth, agus àite airson tachartasan. Bidh na trì pàirtean dhen ionad (cafaidh, bùth, agus àite-thachartasan) am measg a chèile los gum bi cothrom aig ‘cèilichean’ air strùpag agus biadh a ghabhail fhad ’s a tha iad a’ coimhead air na rudan ri reic agus air na tachartasan.
Chuir Dr Teàrlach Wilson An Taigh Cèilidh air chois. Tha teaghlach aige ann an Leòdhas agus rinn e PhD ann an Gàidhlig. A-nis, tha e a’ feuchainn ri cothroman cleachdaidh a thogail dha luchd-labhairt agus luchd-ionnsachaidh na Gàidhlig. Tha cafaidh aig a mhàthair Chuimreach, Maighread Wilson. Còmhla ri chèile, tha iad ag obair air gnìomhachas teaghlaich agus a’ cur an eòlasan ri chèile airson ionad Gàidhlig fhosgladh ann an Leòdhas. Bidh cafaidh, bùth, agus àite thachartasan ann.
Anns a’ bhùth, bidh sinn ag rèic rudan a bhios dèanta air an eilean le luchd-labhairt na Gàidhlig, leithid ealan, dealbhan, coinnlean, siabann, An Clò Hearach, agus briosgaidean. Bidh leabhraichean Gàidhlig agus cèol Gàidhlig ri rèic, cuideachd.
Bidh Gàidhlig air a h-uile càil anns an ionad: na soidhnichean, an clàr-bìdh, agus na docamaidean a’ ghnìomhachais. Bidh Beurla ri taobh na Gàidhlig no fon Ghàidhlig far am bi feum, leithid na soidhnichean air na dorsan-èiginn agus docamaidean laghail. Bidh Gàidhlig aig na luchd-obrach, agus tòisichidh iad a h-uile còmhradh ann an Gàidhlig.
Bidh tachartasan Gàidhlig againn, leithid ceòl tradaiseanta, bàrdachd, òraidean air an eachdraidh ionadail no air an àrainneachd, feasgaran-teatha, agus leughaidhean leabhraichean (dha cloinn agus dha na h-inbhich). Bidh sinn a’ ruith clubaichean sòisealta cuideachd, leithid diofar chearcallan còmhraidh (dha luchd aig diofar ìrean comais-labhairt), clubaichean phàrant agus phàiste, agus clubaichean leughaidh.
Mar sin, bidh rudeigin ann dha: (1) luchd-labhairt fhileanta na Gàidhlig a tha a’ sireadh beatha sòisealta anns a’ Ghàidhlig; (2) luchd-ionnsachaidh a tha a’ sireadh chothroman cleachdaidh agus air a bhith air am bogadh; (3) teaghlaichean a tha a’ sireadh rudan ri dhèanamh còmhla ris a’ chloinn; agus (4) luchd-turais a tha airson cultar an eilein fhaicinn.
Tha sinn airson leigeil ris dhan t-saoghal gur e cànan beò a th’ anns a’ Ghàidhlig agus gun dèan an cànan airgead.
Ach, tha sinn feumach air bhur cuideachadh. Tha duaisean ri fhaighinn ma bheireas sibh tabhartas dhuinn! Agus, ma tha beachd sam bith agaibh air tachartas nuair a bhios sinn fosgailte, cuir fios thugainn! tearlach@taighceilidh.co.uk
 
English here:
I'm Charles, though my Leòdhasach family and friends know me as Teàrlach, even in English! I'm part Leòdhasach, part Glaswegian, and part Welsh! In 2016, my Welsh mum, Margaret Wilson, founded Tolgate Coffee in Strood, Kent. It had always been a dream of hers to have a sophisticated coffee shop with the heart of the community at its centre. After hard work and dedication, with some help from family and friends, she now owns one of the nicest coffee shops, with some of the best food and drink, in Kent.  Now, expanding on Tolgate, I have joined the team to make Tolgate Coffee a national, family-run business, offering a unique side to coffee shops: local culture. There's plenty to choose from in the UK, but the Outer Hebrides of Scotland have some of the oldest, most traditional ways of life in Europe. Tolgate Coffee is going to use its Kent branch as a foundation for its daughter branches, but each will have their own unique take on the local culture of their locations. 
And so, An Taigh Cèilidh was born.
When I lived in Italy and Poland, I had a genuinely immersive experience in the cultures and languages. This made my languages progress. When I did my PhD in Gaelic, I found that not only were there few (if any) immersive experiences for learners, there were few public spaces for more fluent and native speakers. I was particularly surprised to find no dedicated Gaelic spaces in Stornoway - the so-called "Capital of the Western Isles" - and the Western Isles being the so-called "Traditional Gaelic Heartland". Now that I teach Gaelic, students often ask for recommendations for immersive experiences. This is where Gaelic differs fundamentally from, say, Italian. And, living in Stornoway, my guests often ask me where they can experience local culture. As a Leòdhasach ùr ('New Lewisperson'), I am also concerned about the stability of the local culture, and I truly believe (as do organisations such as Bòrd na Gàidhlig, University of the Highlands and Islands, Visit the Outer Hebrides, and the Scottish Government) that Gaelic is not just of cultural value to Scotland, but also of genuine economic value. 
So, An Taigh Cèilidh will provide the immersive experience for learners, the social space for speakers, the flavour of the island to visitors, and the economic support to Gaelic arts and traditional industries. The space we intend to buy is on Cromwell Street in the heart of Stornoway, next door to the old Town Hall, the Stornoway Historical Society, and the Story of Harris Tweed exhibition. We are close to the ferry pier, the bus station, free and paid parking, An Lanntair arts centre, and most town centre accommodation. We will be on the pedestrianised section of Cromwell Street, which will allow us to open up onto the street, which will make Stornoway particularly lively on a good day! Therefore, we will be normalising Gaelic that can be used as an everyday language in public spaces, just as you'd find, say, Polish in Poland.
All staff will be Gaelic-speaking, and every interaction will start in Gaelic. We will host events and performances in Gaelic, such as talks about local history, singing, poetry recital, book readings, and traditional music. We will house Gaelic social clubs, such as a Gaelic book club for adults, a Gaelic book club for children, a Gaelic club for parents with children in Gaelic schools, a Gaelic knitting club, and a Gaelic dog club. We will have a daily conversation circle for Gaelic learners, and Gaelic-medium lessons for things such as art and French.
We will sell Gaelic books, Gaelic greetings cards, Gaelic post cards, Gaelic CDs, and Gaelic DVDs. We will sell gift items, such as soap, candles, tweed items, art, photos, frames, and cups - made by Gaelic speakers and all labelled in Gaelic. This will be good for gift ideas, souvenirs, and supporting Gaelic talent and economy. Some of our profits will go into developing a Gaelic Scrabble and a Gaelic Monopoly board games. The in-house coffee shop will use local products from the island where possible (e.g. Stornoway black pudding), with our baristas trained to make truly artisan coffees. There will be no plastic in the hub, and part of our mission is to highlight and educate on environmental issues, especially those affecting the Outer Hebrides. The walls of the hub will be used as space to showcase gift items (especially art and photography), as well as an exhibition space (especially educational exhibits, such as environmental issues).
As well as ethical pay initiatives to support our staff and suppliers, we will also invest in mentorship and internship programmes. We will support our suppliers in taking on mentees to help people - especially young people - to train in arts and traditional industries, such as Tweed making. We will invest in internships in the centre to help learners and young people to develop business skills that will help with a Gaelic and island economy. If the hub does well, this model can be replicated elsewhere, and our interns can go off to develop the other hubs, or develop their projects and ideas.
An Taigh Cèilidh will be a Gaelic-focused cultural centre with events and performances in Gaelic, gift items made by Gaelic speakers and labelled in Gaelic, housing Gaelic social activities. We will be investing in Gaelic speakers and the island economy. Above all, it will appeal to everyone, whether they are  a native speaker or have no Gaelic at all. Whether you just want to experience local culture, or whether you want to find friends with similar interests, and have a place where you can, well, just use Gaelic.
 
We are really excited to launch this concept and we hope you are too. If you love coffee culture and your local culture - we'll help you marry the two! Thank you for taking the time to read our story and we look forward to welcoming you into An Taigh Cèilidh very soon.

story:
Who We Are

Canada Comics Open Library (CCOL) is a non-profit and volunteer-run comics library located in Regent Park, Toronto, Ontario. CCOL was founded in the springtime of 2018. Our mission is to help make comics more accessible while increasing representation of marginalized communities in comics, with a focus on BIPOC (Black, Indigenous and People of Colour), LGBTQ+, disabled, and women creators. We are working to achieve our mission through our library collection and space, online resources, and community events.

Our Team

We have a diverse board of directors made up of artists, librarians, and other professionals, the majority of which are women. In addition, we have 3 external advisors with experience in the comics industry, and over 20 volunteers who help run the library and events. You can read our bios here! We share a passion for comics and graphic novels, filling gap areas in comic arts accessibility, and encouraging community building through the arts and literature.

Our Work

We are a grassroots library and a giant labour of love that is very meaningful to the people involved and the community it serves. We have over 145 members now! We hope with your support we can continue to operate as an inclusive (and cozy) community space and library. CCOL was made possible through a lot of hard work and there have been a few challenges along the way, but the library is able to better fulfill its mission as a result. We have made several changes to our space based on feedback from library members and volunteers and aim to continue to grow the project in this way. Our long term goal is to grow CCOL into a nationwide comics library system, while reaching demographics that do not have access to comics.

We opened the comics library in March 2019 and have been in our library space at the Centre for Social Innovation (CSI) Regent Park for over 6 months now! Here are some of the things we've accomplished since our last campaign: 

  • Held regular library hours 5 days a week where we operate as a non-circulating special collection and community space
  • Hosted Drawing Club every week on Sunday from 11am to 2pm
  • Hosted free drawing workshops for the public
  • Held pop-up libraries
  • Trained over 25 volunteers to help us run the library
  • Continued to build our online platform (including resources such as our blog and aggregated web resources)
  • Updated out Canadian Cartoonists Database to include over 600 entries
  • Spoken at academic conferences and universities about the politics of comics librarianship and comics.
    • 2019:
      • “Comics and Cartoonists in the Library” Panel, and paper presentation “Reading the Shelves: The Politics of Creating a Diverse Comics Library”, 2nd Annual Conference of the Comics Studies Society – COMICS/POLITICS – Ryerson University 
      • “Panel Discussion with the Canada Comics Open Library & iJournal” Panel, Information & Museum Studies Conference – Community Knowledge: Shared Practices of Sense-Making, Communication, & Collaboration – University of Toronto
      • Upcoming:
        • “Building a Community Comics Library” Presentation, Ontario Library Association Super Conference 2020 –  Dream Big! – Metro Toronto Convention Centre, Toronto, Ontario
  • And most recently, we were awarded a Literary Project Grant through the Toronto Arts Council to host 5 Comics Creator Residencies prioritizing women, trans, and non-binary comics creators.

Right now, our collection includes over 1320 comics, graphic novels, and zines —almost 3 times more than when we launched our last campaign— and it continues to grow. Just check out our online catalogue! 

Here are a few collection stats to give you an idea of our focus areas:
10.2% of collection are LGBTQ+ comics (136 comics)
15% of collection are made by BIPOC creators (Black, Indigenous, people of colour) (203 comics)
11% of collection cover the topic of mental health, mental illness (146 comics)
3% of collection are comics that focus on physical health, disability (37 comics)
26% of collection are comics made by women (350 comics)

Workshop participants for Building Resilience with Art

Impact

The last several months have been spent learning about the community the library exists within. We are working to make the library a welcoming space where you can drop by to read comics and speak with other people interested in comics and comic arts. You can also hang around to work on your own comics and art, use the tools in the library and CSI lounge, and participate in workshops and other events!

Comics can be hard to come by for a variety of reasons, such as the higher cost of their production, the limited distribution of self-published zines, indie comics that have limited runs for editions that go out of print, and the way they are organized or lack representation in public spaces. We want to support and grow the already vibrant comics community in Toronto and across Canada, as well as introduce the medium to new readerships who have previously lacked access to comics.

From its diverse and vibrant comics community, to the retail locations, and festivals, Toronto has been the perfect first home for our comics library.

It has been rewarding seeing the community surrounding our library grow, but, as a non-profit library, there have been many challenges and we need some extra help. This year we need your help to continue operating, and we want to make some big changes!

We hope that we will have the opportunity to show the community what we can do with more funding.

The Next Year

What we need

  • Continue to keep our doors open and pay rent for a year! #keepccolopen
    $3,396 rent for one year (12 months)
    • Thanks to an amazing partnership with the Centre for Social Innovation, which enables us to rent a fully AODA accessible space for an affordable rate, and the help of dozens of volunteers, we are able to operate at a lower cost than our original estimate last campaign. We will be able to direct our funding to areas where it will make the most impact.
  • Cover administrative costs for the year
    $1,441 Administrative costs and supplies: insurance for one year ($1,291) and general library supplies including printing, cataloguing, and office supplies ($150)
  • Make our collection circulating!
    $700 to cover costs related to circulation                                                                                               
    • This will involve adding barcodes and call number stickers to comics. To do this we will need to purchase a scanner and barcode printer, and to spend time preparing our system. 

Total for basic operating + making the collection circulating = $5,537 at minimum.

What else we would like to do

  • Pay senior staff, artists, and workshop facilitators
    $7,000+ per year towards fair pay for our administrative staff member. We are currently volunteer-run, but we would like to pay a fair salary to current staff. 
    • One important principle of ours is to remove financial barriers to access to the comics medium. To do this, we keep our yearly library cards Pay What You Can (PWYC), and all workshops have been free. We have a $5 suggested amount per year and consider anything over this to be Pay-it-Forward...why? Because we will not turn anyone away! This means our memberships do not generate much revenue, and as a non-profit, revenue is how we do what we do. However, it takes a lot of work to build and run our library system. Currently, the entire library is run by volunteers! Eventually, we want to create a salary for our senior staff member. Extra money will also go towards paying artists to make art, present, and host community events at CCOL.
  • Pay artists to hold public workshops
    $2,733+ for honorariums for artists, guests, panelists + workshop and event supplies (in addition to grant-funded projects). 

We are asking for funding to be able to do a lot more than just remain open during staffed hours— although being able to continue to operate as a special collection would still be amazing!

Total with EVERYTHING (basic operating + extras) = $15,270

Goals

If we reach the following funding goals this is what we can do this year!

  • If we raise $3,396 ...
    • We stay open for another year operating the library. We aim to run CCOL as an important public service and community hub promoting literacy and the arts through comics and graphic novels. Help us achieve our mission by raising this funding goal.
  • If we raise $4,837 ...
    • We are able to cover all of our administrative costs. These are important to make sure everyone is covered in case of accidents, the library branch can operate daily, and we have supplies available to community in the space.
  • If we raise $5,537 ...
    • We make the CCOL collection a circulating one! This means you can checkout books and take them home to enjoy. We are very excited to meet this goal and hope you will help us get there!
  • If we raise $12,537 ...
    • We pay our dedicated staff member a salary. They can spend more time making sure that the library runs and meets its goals towards our mission.
  • If we raise $15,270 ...
    • We pay Toronto artists fair honorariums to run public events including artists talks, workshops, and readings. We love to see people come and enjoy the space, learn something, and engage with artists and each other. Help us bring community members together with comics!
  • If we raise $30,000 ...
    • We run a BUNCH more events, keeping them all free, and we pay writers to regularly contribute to our blog!
  • If we raise $50,000 ...
    • Our part-time staff position becomes a full time position! This allows them to focus on: grant applications, outreach, website resources, acquisitions, project development, community partnerships, creating more opportunities for community members to engage with comics, and generally growing the project!
  • If we raise $100,000 ...
    • We hire additional part-time staff or two! This allows us to expand our resources, find and build new revenue streams, and grow more!
  • If we raise $200,000+ ...
    • We will pick a prairie city, and open a new branch ;)
  • If we raise, $2 000,000 + (we can dream)
    • We buy a building and open our own comics library, coffee shop, and art gallery!

Challenges

Because we are still a new and volunteer-run non-profit organization, we’ve encountered several challenges this past year:

Grants: We submitted 4 grants applications this year so far, and we received our first project grant! However, we still don’t have the financial or social history required to qualify for any larger operating grants. There are also very few grants for non-profits that are not charities (and we are not a charity), and since we are unable to offer tax receipts, this understandably means less private donations as well.

Rent: Although we are very lucky to be able to rent an accessible space at CSI, we still need to raise money for rent for the year. Our annual membership is free or PWYC with a suggested donation of $5 per year, and we will ALWAYS have a pool of free memberships for community members; we want to keep this affordable/free, but this also means less income for the project.

Additional perks info

T-shirt Designs

We are offering 2 design options for our t-shirt and tote bag perks, the CCOL logo, designed by artist Scott A. Ford, and this design made by Toronto Lowbrow artist Bo Doodley!:

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to contribute regularly?

We have a Patreon where you can donate for as little as $1 a month (every amount helps!) This includes perks like library updates and a look at journal entries made by volunteers during their shifts!

You can also donate to the comics library any time through Paypal!

Are you an artist/comics creator?

If you are an artist/comics creator, you can contribute artwork (designs) to support the comics library! We will be using selected designs for t-shirts and other merchandise for fundraising in our online store, which we hope to launch in a few months.

You can read more about this and contribute here: https://www.canadacomicsol.org/donate/donate-art/

Have an extra copy of your comic zine or book around? Donate a copy of your zine/comic to CCOL for community members to read! More info on book donations here.

Sharing

We would be thrilled if you would help spread the word on social media, re-tweet us, share your thoughts, and share events and pages from the website! Share our crowdfunding page through Indiegogo's sharing tools :) 

Volunteering

If you want to do more and volunteer your time to the project, please email us at: volunteer@canadacomicsol.org to let us know your interest. View our volunteer page for more information on regular volunteer roles! 

Statements of support 

This year

“7 months ago I read about an incredible community resource needing a home: I learned that The Canada Comics Open Library is an educational, and recreational resource that uses comics and graphic novels as a catalyst to hold safe space to explore and have conversations about things like LGBTQ Identities, Mental Health,  intersectional issues, AND that it is the only resource in NORTH AMERICA dedicated solely to comics accessibility. 6 months ago, The Canada Comics Open Library moved into the CSI Regent Park space transforming a former coat closet into a magical space. We have seen the incredible way they invite the community in to explore art, and enjoy comics. We now know first hand what an incredible resource CCOL is, and are so happy to have them here with us!” 

-Denise Soueidan-O'Leary, Community Manager, Centre for Social Innovation, Regent Park

“CCOL has been an invaluable resource for me. I’ve been able to build community around my love of comics. I love being able to sit in the space, talk about new books, and get recommendations for something new to read. It’s one of my favorite places in Toronto. Thank you CCOL for all your hard work!” 

-Sophie Kaufman, Volunteer Librarian at CCOL

“The CCOL is a fantastic place - a quiet place for reading comics, or for exploratory artmaking and community. The CCOL's Database gives a long-needed central point for Canadian creators, spread out as we are. I was recently invited to the Whitby Comics Arts Festival, and learned they'd found me through the CCOL Database. I recommend all creators ensure they're there, and that they also drop in and witness the gorgeous collection and space at the Canada Comics Open Library.” 

-Jep Clayton, Cartoonist and Educator

“...the little comics library that could is continuing to prove that a comics library is not only wanted, but very much a needed part of the literary community.”

-Wendy Browne, Women Write About Comics

https://womenwriteaboutcomics.com/2019/09/the-c...

“CCOL offers a vital space of community in the face of cuts to public services – more than just comic books, it’s a place of resistance to the status quo.”

-Rebecca Radevski, Law Librarian and Board Member at CCOL

Last Campaign

“Over the years of running The Beguiling, and helping start TCAF, few things have been clearer than the benefits of getting comics into the hands of more readers.  It may seem strange for someone whose business is selling comics to put efforts into methods that allow people to borrow them for free, but projects like CCOL can only benefit the whole comics community by growing a new readership, particularly among audiences that haven't had access to comics, and who have traditionally not found themselves represented there."

-Peter Birkemoe, owner of The Beguiling and co-founder of the Toronto Comic Arts Festival

“As an educator and cartoonist I am very excited about The Canada Comics Open Library.  Having a resource for comic books, graphic novels, zines, cartoonists, collectives, and related activities in one spot is going to be a game changer in Toronto and beyond. Cartooning tends to be a lonely activity and the opportunity to join forces in these troubled times is a great thing. Comics have become one of the best mediums for empowering activism and creating change. Woot, Woot, CCOL!!”

-Fiona Smyth, cartoonist, illustrator, and instructor at OCAD University and the Art Gallery of Ontario

"Comics have become one of the most powerful forms of contemporary storytelling, whether they are about superheroes or everyday people, fantasy worlds or local neighbourhoods, major world events or deeply personal experiences. The Canada Comics Open Library will unfold this diverse world of comics in exciting new ways for both die-hard fans and new readers. Making comics accessible in a community space, identifying them by interests, themes, and topics, and organizing them to showcase their wealth of visual styles are all brilliant ideas to make the space welcoming and inclusive. The plans to host events and showcase comics creators will add to Toronto’s already vibrant comics scene and support local artists. Every city needs a branch of the Canada Comics Open Library!"

-Candida Rifkind, Associate Professor, Department of English, University of Winnipeg & Vice-President, Comics Studies Society

The public lounge at the Centre for Social Innovation, Regent Park (our library is against the back wall!)
