The Next Year
What we need


Continue to keep our doors open and pay rent for a year! #keepccolopen$3,396 rent for one year (12 months)Thanks to an amazing partnership with the Centre for Social Innovation, which enables us to rent a fully AODA accessible space for an affordable rate, and the help of dozens of volunteers, we are able to operate at a lower cost than our original estimate last campaign. We will be able to direct our funding to areas where it will make the most impact.


Cover administrative costs for the year$1,441 Administrative costs and supplies: insurance for one year ($1,291) and general library supplies including printing, cataloguing, and office supplies ($150)

Make our collection circulating!$700 to cover costs related to circulation                                                                                               This will involve adding barcodes and call number stickers to comics. To do this we will need to purchase a scanner and barcode printer, and to spend time preparing our system. 


Total for basic operating + making the collection circulating = $5,537 at minimum.
What else we would like to do


Pay senior staff, artists, and workshop facilitators$7,000+ per year towards fair pay for our administrative staff member. We are currently volunteer-run, but we would like to pay a fair salary to current staff. One important principle of ours is to remove financial barriers to access to the comics medium. To do this, we keep our yearly library cards Pay What You Can (PWYC), and all workshops have been free. We have a $5 suggested amount per year and consider anything over this to be Pay-it-Forward...why? Because we will not turn anyone away! This means our memberships do not generate much revenue, and as a non-profit, revenue is how we do what we do. However, it takes a lot of work to build and run our library system. Currently, the entire library is run by volunteers! Eventually, we want to create a salary for our senior staff member. Extra money will also go towards paying artists to make art, present, and host community events at CCOL.


Pay artists to hold public workshops$2,733+ for honorariums for artists, guests, panelists + workshop and event supplies (in addition to grant-funded projects). 

We are asking for funding to be able to do a lot more than just remain open during staffed hours— although being able to continue to operate as a special collection would still be amazing!
Total with EVERYTHING (basic operating + extras) = $15,270
Goals
If we reach the following funding goals this is what we can do this year!


If we raise $3,396 ...We stay open for another year operating the library. We aim to run CCOL as an important public service and community hub promoting literacy and the arts through comics and graphic novels. Help us achieve our mission by raising this funding goal.


If we raise $4,837 ...We are able to cover all of our administrative costs. These are important to make sure everyone is covered in case of accidents, the library branch can operate daily, and we have supplies available to community in the space.


If we raise $5,537 ...We make the CCOL collection a circulating one! This means you can checkout books and take them home to enjoy. We are very excited to meet this goal and hope you will help us get there!


If we raise $12,537 ...We pay our dedicated staff member a salary. They can spend more time making sure that the library runs and meets its goals towards our mission.


If we raise $15,270 ...We pay Toronto artists fair honorariums to run public events including artists talks, workshops, and readings. We love to see people come and enjoy the space, learn something, and engage with artists and each other. Help us bring community members together with comics!


If we raise $30,000 ...We run a BUNCH more events, keeping them all free, and we pay writers to regularly contribute to our blog!


If we raise $50,000 ... Our part-time staff position becomes a full time position! This allows them to focus on: grant applications, outreach, website resources, acquisitions, project development, community partnerships, creating more opportunities for community members to engage with comics, and generally growing the project!


If we raise $100,000 ...We hire additional part-time staff or two! This allows us to expand our resources, find and build new revenue streams, and grow more!


If we raise $200,000+ ...We will pick a prairie city, and open a new branch ;)


If we raise, $2 000,000 + (we can dream)We buy a building and open our own comics library, coffee shop, and art gallery!



Challenges
Because we are still a new and volunteer-run non-profit organization, we’ve encountered several challenges this past year:
Grants: We submitted 4 grants applications this year so far, and we received our first project grant! However, we still don’t have the financial or social history required to qualify for any larger operating grants. There are also very few grants for non-profits that are not charities (and we are not a charity), and since we are unable to offer tax receipts, this understandably means less private donations as well.
Rent: Although we are very lucky to be able to rent an accessible space at CSI, we still need to raise money for rent for the year. Our annual membership is free or PWYC with a suggested donation of $5 per year, and we will ALWAYS have a pool of free memberships for community members; we want to keep this affordable/free, but this also means less income for the project.
Additional perks info
T-shirt Designs
We are offering 2 design options for our t-shirt and tote bag perks, the CCOL logo, designed by artist Scott A. Ford, and this design made by Toronto Lowbrow artist Bo Doodley!:


Other Ways You Can Help
Want to contribute regularly?
We have a Patreon where you can donate for as little as $1 a month (every amount helps!) This includes perks like library updates and a look at journal entries made by volunteers during their shifts!
You can also donate to the comics library any time through Paypal!
Are you an artist/comics creator?
If you are an artist/comics creator, you can contribute artwork (designs) to support the comics library! We will be using selected designs for t-shirts and other merchandise for fundraising in our online store, which we hope to launch in a few months.
You can read more about this and contribute here: https://www.canadacomicsol.org/donate/donate-art/
Have an extra copy of your comic zine or book around? Donate a copy of your zine/comic to CCOL for community members to read! More info on book donations here.
Sharing
We would be thrilled if you would help spread the word on social media, re-tweet us, share your thoughts, and share events and pages from the website! Share our crowdfunding page through Indiegogo's sharing tools :) 
Volunteering
If you want to do more and volunteer your time to the project, please email us at: volunteer@canadacomicsol.org to let us know your interest. View our volunteer page for more information on regular volunteer roles! 

Statements of support 
This year
“7 months ago I read about an incredible community resource needing a home: I learned that The Canada Comics Open Library is an educational, and recreational resource that uses comics and graphic novels as a catalyst to hold safe space to explore and have conversations about things like LGBTQ Identities, Mental Health,  intersectional issues, AND that it is the only resource in NORTH AMERICA dedicated solely to comics accessibility. 6 months ago, The Canada Comics Open Library moved into the CSI Regent Park space transforming a former coat closet into a magical space. We have seen the incredible way they invite the community in to explore art, and enjoy comics. We now know first hand what an incredible resource CCOL is, and are so happy to have them here with us!” 
-Denise Soueidan-O'Leary, Community Manager, Centre for Social Innovation, Regent Park
“CCOL has been an invaluable resource for me. I’ve been able to build community around my love of comics. I love being able to sit in the space, talk about new books, and get recommendations for something new to read. It’s one of my favorite places in Toronto. Thank you CCOL for all your hard work!” 
-Sophie Kaufman, Volunteer Librarian at CCOL
“The CCOL is a fantastic place - a quiet place for reading comics, or for exploratory artmaking and community. The CCOL's Database gives a long-needed central point for Canadian creators, spread out as we are. I was recently invited to the Whitby Comics Arts Festival, and learned they'd found me through the CCOL Database. I recommend all creators ensure they're there, and that they also drop in and witness the gorgeous collection and space at the Canada Comics Open Library.” 
-Jep Clayton, Cartoonist and Educator
“...the little comics library that could is continuing to prove that a comics library is not only wanted, but very much a needed part of the literary community.”
-Wendy Browne, Women Write About Comics
https://womenwriteaboutcomics.com/2019/09/the-c...
“CCOL offers a vital space of community in the face of cuts to public services – more than just comic books, it’s a place of resistance to the status quo.”
-Rebecca Radevski, Law Librarian and Board Member at CCOL
Last Campaign
“Over the years of running The Beguiling, and helping start TCAF, few things have been clearer than the benefits of getting comics into the hands of more readers.  It may seem strange for someone whose business is selling comics to put efforts into methods that allow people to borrow them for free, but projects like CCOL can only benefit the whole comics community by growing a new readership, particularly among audiences that haven't had access to comics, and who have traditionally not found themselves represented there."
-Peter Birkemoe, owner of The Beguiling and co-founder of the Toronto Comic Arts Festival
“As an educator and cartoonist I am very excited about The Canada Comics Open Library.  Having a resource for comic books, graphic novels, zines, cartoonists, collectives, and related activities in one spot is going to be a game changer in Toronto and beyond. Cartooning tends to be a lonely activity and the opportunity to join forces in these troubled times is a great thing. Comics have become one of the best mediums for empowering activism and creating change. Woot, Woot, CCOL!!”
-Fiona Smyth, cartoonist, illustrator, and instructor at OCAD University and the Art Gallery of Ontario
"Comics have become one of the most powerful forms of contemporary storytelling, whether they are about superheroes or everyday people, fantasy worlds or local neighbourhoods, major world events or deeply personal experiences. The Canada Comics Open Library will unfold this diverse world of comics in exciting new ways for both die-hard fans and new readers. Making comics accessible in a community space, identifying them by interests, themes, and topics, and organizing them to showcase their wealth of visual styles are all brilliant ideas to make the space welcoming and inclusive. The plans to host events and showcase comics creators will add to Toronto’s already vibrant comics scene and support local artists. Every city needs a branch of the Canada Comics Open Library!"
-Candida Rifkind, Associate Professor, Department of English, University of Winnipeg & Vice-President, Comics Studies Society

The public lounge at the Centre for Social Innovation, Regent Park (our library is against the back wall!)

story:
Who is ShanghaiPRIDE? 

ShanghaiPRIDE, which began in 2009, is an annual festival that celebrates diversity. This festival is organized entirely by volunteerswith the support of individuals, media, businesses, and foreign consulates. We aim to raise awareness and visibility, and to promote self-acceptance and acceptance for the LGBTQ community through sports, cultural, educational, and social activities. We also encourage the community and partners to support LGBTQ-related projects and initiatives.  ShanghaiPRIDE promotes cross-cultural exchange locally as well as with LGBTQ festivals across the globe.

  • Become one of the leading cultural festivals in Shanghai to help increase diversity and acceptance in the city.
  • Become the most important and influential event on the LGBTQ calendar in China.  
  • Attract top academics, prominent social figures, and a large number of LGBTQ individuals and allies in China.
  • Become an international LGBTQ festival attended by LGBTQ communities from around the globe
  • Collaborate with communities, organizations, sponsors across the globe
  • Bring together international and local communities from diverse backgrounds to network, share, and support.
  • Work with various LGBTQ groups and allies to keep up-to-date on important LGBTQ-related issues in China and around the world.

In 2014, the ShanghaiPRIDE team was awarded “Shanghai Hero” by Time Out Shanghai and in 2018 the “Best Event Organizer in East China” by Huodongxing.

ShanghaiPRIDE 2019– Pride11 will be held from the 13th to the 16th of June.

What We Need & What You Get

As we are all volunteers and taking time away from our day jobs, we are looking to raise support to fund our trip so we can continue to learn, grow and be a stronger community.  You support can help us in many ways: 

Travel: flights from Shanghai to NYC, Lodging in an AirBnB, Visa costs, local transportation, etc.  

Educational seminars/events: while in NYC we want to learn more from other Pride organizations, stock up our library of materials that are not available in China

What you get for support: for your support you will receive exclusive ShanghaiPRIDE Pride11 swag from t-shirts, tote bags, and array of various other swag created exclusively.  We will also send you a detailed trip overview of our trip to NYC highlighting our finds and exchanges. 

The Impact

Your contribution will send the core leadership team from Shanghai, China to NYC to attend World Pride.  

ShanghaiPRIDE team will have the opportunity to collaborate with other global LGBTQ communities, leaders and allies.  We will also be meeting business leaders with operations in China to help share about the LGBTQ community in China.  We want to reach companies and other communities to build relationships and deeper understanding of the over 70+million LGBTQ in Greater China.  

  • Become one of the leading cultural festivals in Shanghai to help increase diversity and acceptance in the city.

>>Become the most important and influential event on the LGBTQ calendar in China.  

>>Attract top academics, prominent social figures, and a large number of LGBTQ individuals and allies in China.

>>Become an international LGBTQ festival attended by LGBTQ communities from around the globe

>>Collaborate with communities, organizations, sponsors across the globe

>>Bring together international and local communities from diverse backgrounds to network, share, and support.

>>Work with various LGBTQ groups and allies to keep up-to-date on important LGBTQ-related issues in China and around the world.

 

Risks & Challenges

There are always challenges with our team going to represent ShanghaiPRIDE in another country.  We feel safe going to NYC and celebrating with our LGBTQ community from around the world, but we also acknowledge the risk of back home with various regulations and more.  We are a team of business professional that work full time in various companies and MNCs in Shanghai.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Share our campaign.  If you know others who are from Shanghai or the region and will be at World Pride, we would love to connect.  If your business wants to hear about the LGBTQ climate in Shanghai and throughout the region, we would be glad to share.  

Together, we are excited to take a huge step and venture to the other side of the world.  We are a strong team and supports the LGBTQ community throughout our region on a yearly base.  We thank you in advance for your support!  Jiaoyou! 

 

LEARN MORE ABOUT SHANGHAIPRIDE : www.shpride.com

story:
Aux confins littéraires

Fierté littéraire combat l'isolement causé par la pandémie de la COVID-19, des auteurs-trices et des poètes-poétesses de la diversité sexuelle et de genre lisent pour vous. Du confort de leur maison, iels liront un extrait de livre, un ou deux poèmes ou un récit de leur cru. Ce n'est pas parce qu'on ne peut plus organiser de soirée littéraire qu'on ne va pas trouver une façon de partager nos mots, nos émotions et nos histoires. Nous organisons donc une soirée virtuelle le 30 mars à 20 heures en ligne.

Soutien aux auteurs et autrices qui vivent la précarité

Nous en profitons pour organiser une collecte de fonds pour certains.es auteurs-trices qui vivent déjà dans la précarité et que la crise actuelle précarise davantage.  Les fonds seront distribués par Fierté littéraire aux auteurs-trices qui feront des lectures et qui déclarent vivre une situation de précarité.

Pour voir l'événement en direct ou en différé 

Événement Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/events/1060355694349060/

YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnfcQr55CS9-n7... 

(Note: La vidéo de Céline Bélanger a été échappée au montage. Vous la verrez à la suite dans ce playlist)

story:
FarmProv began when a group of passionate friends who lived together on a farm Riverside wanted to help each other use their talents by throwing comedy events at their home. They built a stage, prepared food we grew and raised, and had a ton of fun hosting over 150 diverse people at each show.

After we all moved, we went our separate ways, but after a few meaningful contributions to society, we are returning to form FarmProv, an initiative to build funnier, healthier communities across the Southeast.

Our goal is to generate revenue for sustainable farms, and bring improv troupes, comedians, and musicians to new audiences. We’ll also raise money for Wholesome Wave Georgia at each FarmProv event, to make the food grown on those farms more accessible for everyone.

We are starting at Urban Sprout Farms, a space for good food and entertainment in Lakewood. It’s a small farm with big dreams of becoming a pillar for entertainment and fresh food in the Lakewood community. We want to help them grow, and establish a home for FarmProv in 2019.

Urban Sprout Farms built a stage this year, but the stage needs to be covered to host events and classes during inclement weather. With a stage covered by solar panels, they will be able to host and power workshops, classes, and events all year -- including FarmProv -- adding a significant revenue stream to the operation. FarmProv is looking to purchase lighting, sound, and stage equipment to give attendees the full experience.

Donate to our campaign to help take FarmProv and Urban Sprout Farms to new heights. Together, we can laugh our way to a better future!

Each FarmProv event is designed to accomplish main goals:

  • Pay the farm and the performers a reasonable wage for their work.
  • Purchase products grown or made on the farm to use in the food served at the event.
  • Raise money for Wholesome Wave Georgia, which doubles the value of SNAP/EBT at farmers markets.
  • Bring diverse audiences together to build community through laughter and food.

Here’s The Team

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Katie Elkins, Founder

Katie Elkins is a founder of FarmPROV. She is driven by her passion to create live theater experiences for those who may never see themselves entering the traditional theater establishment by creating fun multifaceted events. After a year in Denver, CO, Katie is excited to return to her hometown of Atlanta, Georgia to give back to the community that she loves most. Katie is responsible for booking the comedy side of FarmPROV and overseeing the production of the event.

In addtion to FarmPROV, Katie Elkins is a performer herself and loves teaching preschool aged children who remind her what it means to be fearlessly themselves.

Kyael Moss, Founder

Kyael Moss is a founder of FarmPROV. He enjoys the cultural impact and community based aspects of live performance. To him FarmPROV is a culmination of appreciation for the outdoors, quality food, and diverse creative expression. Kyael is responsible for booking the music side of FarmPROV and ensuring the general flow and appearance of the event space.

In addition to FarmPROV, Kyael Moss is a master of cutting through the fluff and getting down to what's important. He makes his own music and manages Mac's Beer and Wine.

James Carr, Chief Herding Officer

James Carr is the founder of Longleaf Media, marketing chair for TEDxAtlanta, and the board secretary for Georgia Shift. James aims to create a healthier culture by improving our relationship with our food. He also likes to plant fruit trees.

James has managed communications and events for Food Well Alliance, the Atlanta Mayor's Office of Resilience, Georgia Organics and Move This World, written for Appen Media, Bleacher Report, The Shadow League, and Fox Sports Southeast, and was the Sports Director for WUOG 90.5 FM.

Here’s Where Your Money Is Going:

Urban Sprout Farms:

Solar Panel Stage Cover: 10,000

FarmProv:

Lighting / Sound Equipment: 4,000

Traveling Stage: 2,000

Chairs, tables, and tents: 2,000

Licensing, Insurance, and other Event Costs: 2,000

Stretch Goal:

Stage cover equipped with solar panels -  30,000 

**Our top priority is to establish Urban Sprout Farms as a venue where FarmProv can thrive for the upcoming season. If we do not reach our goal, one hundred percent of funds will go towards bolstering infrastructure to enable multiple FarmProv shows, jams, classes, and workshops at Urban Sprout Farms in 2019.

If you can’t donate to our campaign, we still love you! Please spread the word on social media, text your friends, and thank a farmer. We’ll see you at the farm!

story:
Para ver información en Español o Portugués ir a la parte inferior

What is FIC?

The International Community Festival (Festival Internacional Comunitario) is a shifting space of dialogue, in which we seek to strengthen the communal values through social theatre on communities that have been segregated by the stigma of violence.

We organize it in a self-managed way, consisting of day by day collectives, and our commitment to taking care of the communal spaces in our respective locations. 

The first International Community festival: Living without borders! Was done on the community of La Carpio, Costa Rica, in the year 2016. We were able to enroll more than 500 people, from 12 different nationalities on the activities that we created together.

The second International Community Festival: Living Together in Freedom?, will be taking place in January 2019 at the venue of “Grupo Iuna de Capoeira” Angola in Belo Horizonte, Brazil. 

Everyone interested in promoting, contributing and being part of this encounter, are welcome to join! The FIC is being offered in a free and community funded way!

This festival’s production has an approximate cost of $35.000. This amount is possible thanks to the collaborative work and material contribution of people, government organizations, NGOs, families and neighborhood organizations from the locality in which the encounter takes place.

With the money that was left from 2016’s FIC ($1000) and the donations from the involved organizations, we only have $11.000 left to pay; this is for the air tickets of 8 people from the production team, lodging, transportation around the city, food for everyone involved with the FIC, materials for the workshops and necessary improvements in the capoeira school’s main room (as a contribution of solidarity for hosting the festival). 

Thank you for believing in this community initiative!

To learn more about the FIC, click here…

Did you knew that?

1. Two young people from the popular community of La Carpio (where the first edition took place) are working toguether with us producing the second edition?

2. Again, we will have the presence of two members of the CECOSESOLA network (Barquisimeto, Venezuela) who will be providing all their community experience?

3. Both “Asociación Masaya” and “Grupo Iuna Capoeira” (host for the 2019 Brazil’s FIC) have been cultural points?

4. Cori and Dé, during their trip of 2016 from Brazil to Costa Rica (and their return by bicycle) started the viagensemeducacao initiative?

PORTUGUÉS:

O que é o FIC?

O Festival Internacional Comunitário (FIC) é um espaço  itinerante de diálogo para seguir aprendendo através do teatro social junto às comunidades segregadas pelo estigma da violência e/ou insegurança.

 

Organizado de forma autogestionária por coletivos que no nosso dia a dia e nas nossas respectivas localidades nos dedicamos ao cuidado de espaços comunitários.

 

O 1ero Festival Internacional Comunitário: ¡Conviviendo sem Fronteiras!  o fizemos na comunidade La Carpio, Costa Rica, no 2016. Consiguindo envolver a mais de 500 pessoas de 12 nacionalidades diferentes, nas atividades que em coletivos fizemos.  

 

2do Festival Internacional Comunitário: Conviviendo em libertad?!

O realizaremos no mês de janeiro de 2019 nos bairros Vera Cruz e Alto Vera Cruz de Belo Horizonte, Brasil.

A temática desta edição surge do contexto no qual nos encontramos. É visível no bairro Vera Cruz e Alto Vera Cruz, assim como os bairros próximos a persistência e luta de pessoas e grupos culturais, como o Grupo Iúna de Capoeira Angola (uma das sedes do 2do FIC) que mantêm trabalhos voltados para as questões sociais e culturais com amadurecimento político e vontade de transformação, o que faz com que o tema “Convivendo Liberdade?!” faça sentido para uma reflexão acerca do que seja essa convivência. Estamos realmente vivendo em liberdade? O que, dentro da realidade de violações de direito em que vivemos atualmente podemos considerar como liberdade? O que implica estar livre? e o que nos tira o direito de sermos livres dentro de uma região estigmatizada? São perguntas que  fazemos e que o FIC poderá facilitar o diálogo para discuti-las.

Todas as pessoas que estejam interessadas em promover, contribuir e ser parte deste encontro são bem-vindas! O FIC é oferecido de forma gratuita e financiado comunitariamente!

A produção deste festival tem um custo aproximado de $35.000. Montante que é possível reunir através do trabalho colaborativo e a contribuição material de pessoas, organizações governamentais, ONG´s, famílias e organizações do bairro onde se realiza o encontro.

Com dinheiro que ficou do FIC 2016 (1000$), junto com as doações (contrapartidas) que temos feito as organizações envolvidas, já só nos faltam 11.000$ para pagar as passagens aéreas de 8 pessoas da equipe produtora, divulgação do festival, transporte na cidade, e a realização de melhorias na sala principal da Escola de Capoeira do Grupo Iuna, como aporte solidário por ser a sede do 2do FIC.

¿Qué es el FIC?

El Festival Internacional Comunitario (FIC) es un espacio itinerante de diálogo donde buscamos fortalecer lo comunitario a través del teatro social junto a comunidades segregadas por el estigma de la violencia.

Lo organizamos de forma autogestionada, colectivos que día a día y en nuestras respectivas localidades nos dedicamos al cuidado de espacios comunitarios.

El 1er Festival Internacional Comunitario: ¡Conviviendo sin Fronteras! lo realizamos en la comunidad La Carpio, Costa Rica, en el año 2016. Logrando envolver a más de 500 personas, de 12 nacionalidades distintas, en las actividades que en colectivo realizamos.

En el mes de enero de 2019 realizaremos en la sede del Grupo Iuna de Capoeira Angola en Belo Horizonte, Brasil, El 2do Festival Internacional Comunitario: Conviviendo en libertad?!

¡Todas las personas que estén interesadas en promover, contribuir y ser parte de este encuentro son bienvenidas! ¡El FIC es ofrecido de forma gratuita y financiado comunitariamente!

La producción de este festival tiene un costo aproximado de $35.000.  Monto que es posible reunir gracias al trabajo colaborativo y contribución material de personas, organizaciones gubernamentales, ONG´s, familias y  organizaciones del barrio donde se realiza el encuentro.

Con el dinero que nos sobró del FIC 2016 (1.000$), más las donaciones (Contrapartidas) que hemos aportado las organizaciones involucradas, ya solo nos faltan: 11.000$ para pagar pasajes aéreos de 8 personas del equipo productor, divulgación del FIC, transporte en la ciudad y la realización de mejoras en la sala principal de la Escuela de Capoeira, como aporte solidario por ser sede de este 2do FIC.

Barrio de Vera Cruz...algunos datos:

Vera Cruz, es un barrio localizado en la región Este de Belo Horizonte donde hay una efervescencia cultural ligada al Samba de Raiz, Pagode y Cultura Hip Hop, además de Capoeira Angola, Capoeira Regional y otras manifestaciones artísticos culturales que son características también de los barrios aledaños Alto Vera Cruz, Taquaril, Saudade e Jonas Veiga, donde hay una escuela de Futbol. El barrio Vera Cruz abrió la Escuela de Samba Unidos del Vera Cruz que en año 2000 reavivó los desfiles de Carnaval en Belo Horizonte después de algunos años sin evento. Situada en los márgenes de la ciudad, el barrio está marcado por la carencia social, y el estigma de ser un barrio violento, como sus barrios vecinos. Sin embargo, existen en ellas espacios como escuelas, centros culturales, e instituciones públicas y privadas que posibilitan proyectos y servicios sociales a la población. Como el Grupo Iuna de Capoeira Angola, ONG dedicada a la preservación y divulgación  de la Capoeira Angola, espacio sede de los talleres del 2do FIC.

¡Gracias por creer en esta iniciativa comunitaria!

  5. El 100% de las actividades del FIC son gratuitas, para todo público, e incluye alimentación para todas las personas que asistan?

story:
Nasty Theatre Company was founded by four fierce females who all graduated from Oklahoma City University. We have theatre backgrounds and wanted to dive back in and make art that is passionate and that we can be proud of. Thus, Nasty Theatre Company was born. Nasty Theatre Company's mission is to produce culturally relevant and thought-provoking theatre, in an environment for all artists, that creates a positive dialogue and inspires change. We are influenced by those who march to the beat of their own drum, who want to see better things happen in the world, and who are, yes, a little nasty. In picking our first show, we knew it had to be one that celebrates women and diversity, has a positive message and is pertinent today. We chose Stop Kiss, a play about two women who explore their true feelings for the first time and endure backlash and judgment rather than support. These two women decide to be true to themselves in spite of this and we wanted to share their story and remind our audiences to love who they are and one another.

It’s easy to think, “It's 2017, things have already gotten so much better!” While certain conditions have improved in America since the Stonewall Riots in 1969, there is much progress that still needs to be made. Take a look at Chechen, Russia, where gay men are being detained in detention centers and tortured. Take a look at Kenya, Ethiopia, Pakistan, India and over 25 other countries in which being gay is considered illegal, not to mention the 10 countries in which it is punishable by death. Take a look at Texas, whose governor signed a bill allowing state-funded adoption and foster care agencies to discriminate against same-sex couples, and would also allow the practice of “conversion therapy”. According to research done by the Trevor Project, “the rate of suicide attempts is 4 times greater for LGB youth and 2 times greater for questioning youth than that of straight youth”, and that isn’t even including transgender youth. Past crusaders have helped pave the way for LGBT rights, but it is up to us to keep the fight going and ensure a better future for generations to come. We at Nasty Theatre Company plan to advocate these rights and beliefs with our production of Stop Kiss in more ways than one. On opening night, we will donate half of our ticket sales to the National Center for Lesbian Rights, an organization dedicated to LGBT rights and protection through litigation, legislation, policy and public education.

Now that we’ve discussed the importance of your donation, let’s talk details! We are looking to raise $9,000 for this production. That may sound like we’re overshooting, but when you include the rental fees for the theatre, rights for the production, sets, costumes, advertising and payment for our actors, money disappears quickly. We’re hoping to put on the best production of this show possible and we cannot do that without your support! We have a ton of prizes to offer, including stickers, t-shirts, hats, free tickets to our show and even free drinks at the show! Any little bit helps and no donation is too small (except pennies, those are worthless). We will be posting updates on our website, Instagram and Facebook page so you can see exactly what your money is going to. Even if you can’t donate, please feel free to share this page and show your support to others and help us get the word out! We have a cast and crew of talented and dedicated individuals who are excited to share this important story and eager to entertain our wonderful supporters.

Below is the website for the National Center for Lesbian Rights and we will be including a link to our website as soon as it launches! We only have a little over a month to reach our goal, so help us make art and change happen!

http://www.nastytheatrecompany.com

http://www.nclrights.org/

story:
For the past ten years, People's Kitchen Collective has created accessible and delicious dining experiences with the belief that good food should be for the people. This year, we have embarked on a meal series taking place over the course of a year. “From the FARM, to the KITCHEN to the TABLE to the STREETS!” will culminate in a historic, public meal for five hundred people in the streets of West Oakland in May, 2018, and we need your help to make it possible.  

This seated meal spanning three city blocks will bring together artists, activists, musicians, performers, and social justice organizations to advocate for the issues most urgent to our communities. We crave spaces that deliberately center the voices and experiences of people of color. Our lives are shaped by displacement, migration, loss of land, and access to resources. In the absence of land, we create space through ritual in the form of a meal. In the face of a gentrifying Oakland, this is how we feed a revolution.

Our community dining is rooted in:

  • JUSTICE. We use the art and ritual of gathering to expand on histories of political movement, community migration, and joyous political critique. We advocate for the critical social justice issues of our time.
     
  • COLLABORATION. We work with artists, poets, researchers, and activists as a multi-sensory, immersive, creative production of cultural resilience.
     
  • CONNECTION. Our participants are engaged in a direct, personal, and lasting way over the course our focused and intimate meals. Participants learn together and are enriched by each other’s voices and experiences.

We need your support. $30,000 goes toward supporting a VAST infrastructure including creative collaborations, research, outreach, ingredients, cooking equipment, rentals, and documentation.

Our Mission 

People’s Kitchen Collective believes in radical hospitality and uses food as a critical tool for self determination and social justice.

Our collective works at the intersection of food, art, and activism to produce political education projects (workshops, community dining, and art installations) that center the experiences of people of color.

Based in Oakland, California, our projects reflect the diverse backgrounds and experiences of co-founders Sita Kuratomi Bhaumik, Jocelyn Jackson and Saqib Keval.

PHOTO: Sana Javeri Kadri | VIDEO: Fox Nakai | ILLO: Kristyn Leach

La Pelanga 

A DJ collective born out of Cali, Colombia, and based in Oakland/San Francisco - has teamed up with PKC once again to offer a special FARM, KITCHEN, TABLE, STREETS edition, highly flavorful, food centered mixtape. This lovingly curated CD/digital download perfectly pairs La Pelanga's obsession with afro-latino diasporic music with PKC's dedication to grounding our identities in delicious food. Message and mood music for your garden work, in the kitchen, and in your headphones!

We need your support. $30,000 goes toward supporting a VAST infrastructure including creative collaborations, research, outreach, ingredients, cooking equipment, rentals, and documentation.Our Mission People’s Kitchen Collective believes in radical hospitality and uses food as a critical tool for self determination and social justice.Our collective works at the intersection of food, art, and activism to produce political education projects (workshops, community dining, and art installations) that center the experiences of people of color.Based in Oakland, California, our projects reflect the diverse backgrounds and experiences of co-founders Sita Kuratomi Bhaumik, Jocelyn Jackson and Saqib Keval.PHOTO: Sana Javeri Kadri | VIDEO: Fox Nakai | ILLO: Kristyn LeachLa Pelanga A DJ collective born out of Cali, Colombia, and based in Oakland/San Francisco - has teamed up with PKC once again to offer a special FARM, KITCHEN, TABLE, STREETS edition, highly flavorful, food centered mixtape. This lovingly curated CD/digital download perfectly pairs La Pelanga's obsession with afro-latino diasporic music with PKC's dedication to grounding our identities in delicious food. Message and mood music for your garden work, in the kitchen, and in your headphones!

story:
Whatever it may take, we’ve decided to follow our dream till the end and do our best to launch a long-awaited DIY music cultural centre in Vilnius. Planned to open in the fall of 2019, the centre will welcome free minds from all around the world:

  • Musicians and sound artists will come here to not only perform, but also reside, experiment, collaborate, record and release their creations.
  • Visual, interdisciplinary and other artists will collaborate with musicians, or simply enjoy the possibility to exhibit their creations to the public.
  • Everyone from the public will get the possibility to
    • attend our concerts, performances, exhibitions, workshops and other events,
    • start practicing music or sound art using music instruments and sound equipment available at the centre,
    • seek yet another way to get involved into centre’s activities, and become a vital part of the community.

No matter the form of participation, everyone at the centre will be expected to share a common interest in independent creation, DIY philosophy or self sustaining living. Fostering these values, as well as evolution of culture in general, is the ultimate goal we seek.

For the centre to work properly, we’ll provide our residents and guests with all needed facilities:

  • a concert hall,
  • a recording studio,
  • a music library,
  • a gallery space,
  • a projection room,
  • a residency,
  • a canteen and cafe.

We believe the centre will be a significant step forward in DIY music culture, at least in the region, as no similar space has ever existed before in Lithuania or anywhere in the Baltics.

To keep up with our dream, we first had to find a place that would suit the centre best. We’ve been hunting for the spot for quite a while and finally found an ideal fit:

  • Abandoned two-floored building of 550 sq. meters
  • Former factory area located in city district Naujoji Vilnia
  • Accessible by public transport or train
  • 20-minute drive from Vilnius downtown
  • Cozy yard with the Vilnelė river just 50 meters away

And now, this building is on sale.

We didn’t want to miss the chance, so we acted fast to save the building for the centre by signing a preliminary sale-purchase contact. Under the agreement, we must pay the whole price for the building by the 1st of May.

Needless to say, we did pool all our personal savings together. However, the amount we've got is enough to cover a half of the price.

The other half is the reason why we are asking for your support now.

Please note:

  • We are a non-profit organization. When organizing all our events, we have never charged more than minimum amounts, needed to finance each individual event. That’s how we ended up being short in funds to purchase the building in the required time by ourselves.
  • We refuse corporate sponsorship. Any corporate dependency is just the opposite of our beliefs rooted in the idea of independent creation and DIY philosophy.
  • Squatting is practically impossible in Vilnius. For those who’ve heard little about it - Vilnius is a quite tiny city. And squatting - especially on a large scale - is not common here, simply because the real estate market is super transparent, intense and controlled.
  • Renting a place for the centre is not an option either. The choice for spaces possibly suitable for our needs is poor, and the prices are far from affordable for non-profit communities such as ours. We did try, believe us.

That’s why owning the building is the only long-term option left for us.

We could keep waiting for someone else to bring us the music we love, or - start doing it ourselves.

That’s how 8 years ago we, a bunch of friends at that time, got into organising events of alternative music in Vilnius. By alternative, we mean music of any genre and style that is created outside mainstream industry and public grant systems.

Independent creation, the core of music we foster, has also always been a fundamental principle of the way we work. When organising concerts or our annual summer festival, we

  • oppose following predefined standards and, instead,
  • support DIY production based on intuition, experimentation and enjoyment of creative process.

In all these years of activity, we grew from a few friends to a whole community, and it’s time for us now to take a significant step forward - to finally launch our own permanent place.

For more impressions on our current and past activities, please browse http://emptybrainresalt.us

You are welcome to take a better look at dozens of perks* we offer in exchange to your support:

  • Free entrance to the centre after the opening
  • Tickets to our summer festival Braille Satellite
  • First residencies at the centre since its opening
  • Tons of undiscovered music to download, on a tape, a cd or a vinyl
  • Our first music compilation release by various artsits
  • Other unique works by our talented friends and supporters

Please keep in mind all perks that need to be shipped will be delivered by April, 2018.

IMPORTANT! Some people face difficulties trying to donate. A reason can be this: European banks don't allow card payments in so called "unsafe countries" and that option is set by default when you receive your card. Usually it can be changed manually in your online baking system. You need to enable the payment possibility in insecure zones for the card you are trying to use for the backing our campaign.

story:
It’s time for the Astrodome to lift off once again!

We at the National Trust for Historic Preservation, in collaboration with Heineken USA and the Astrodome Conservancy, are on a mission to show the world how its “8th Wonder” can be reimagined as Houston's next great public space. This multi-day festival will be the launch of the Astrodome's next chapter as a civic space for all of Houston to enjoy. With your support, we’ll be one step closer to ensuring that this icon gets the comeback it deserves.

Opened in 1965 to shield baseball fans from the nagging mosquitoes and oppressive heat of coastal Texas, the Astrodome put Houston on the map as the home of the first domed stadium on the planet. But that wasn’t the only first. In addition to giving the world “Astro Turf,” the Dome was home to the first skybox and the first animated scoreboard. And with the largest indoor space ever created by mankind, it certainly gave credence to the expression that everything is, in fact, bigger in Texas.

The Dome was home to so much more than its MLB namesake, the Houston Astros. Everyone from Evel Knievel and Muhammad Ali to Elvis and the Supremes thrilled packed audiences inside the Astrodome. Bobby Riggs and Billie Jean King competed in the “Battle of the Sexes” tennis match there in 1973, and Nolan Ryan threw one of his seven no-hitters under that awe-inspiring ceiling. And then there was pro football (remember the Oilers?) and years of rowdy livestock shows and rodeos. Simply put, this is where Houston came to play.

Unfortunately, its quirky design and engineering feats weren’t enough to keep the Dome afloat. Over the years, its core tenants gradually peeled away to newer stadiums, including one that was constructed just feet from the Dome itself. And just like that, the soaring structure that shocked the world now sat empty.

The party was over—or so some people thought.

Today, ambitious plans are afoot to bring the legendary landmark back as a vibrant public space. But what exactly does that look like? 

The Astrodome Conservancy envisions a multi-day festival that previews the Astrodome’s future use by showcasing innovative public art, exciting sports activities, and one of the Dome's great strengths—live music. In this way, Dome lovers can experience this iconic place in a new light, and a new generation of Houstonians will get the chance to meet the “8th Wonder.”

Success! We're happy to report that our campaign raised $40,060! That's $25,060 above our original goal of $15,000!

Thanks to the generous support of our backers, we will soon show the world that the groundbreaking Astrodome still has plenty of days left and new generations to enjoy it.

Please stay tuned to the updates section of this page for additional project news.

I claimed tickets to the Bruno Mars: 24K Magic World Tour as my perk and have questions.

Thank you for supporting our project! You will find answers to your questions in our FAQ. If you have specific questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com. Enjoy the show!

What is the National Trust for Historic Preservation?

The National Trust for Historic Preservation, a privately funded nonprofit organization, works to save America’s historic places. We are the cause that inspires Americans to save the places where history happened. The cause that connects us to our diverse pasts, weaving a multi-cultural nation together. The cause that transforms communities from places where we live into places that we love. As the leading voice for preservation, we are the cause for people saving places.

Our mission is to protect significant places representing our diverse cultural experience by taking direct action and inspiring broad public support.

Where is my donation going?

More than 90% of all funds raised will support the cities' projects and the National Trust’s ongoing work to save historic places in Houston and around the country. Up to 10% will cover Indiegogo costs and processing fees as described in Indiegogo’s Terms and Conditions. 

When will I get my perk (non-ticket)?

Perks will be delivered later this summer (July/August).

Can I visit the project site?

Yes! You can drive around, but at the moment you cannot go in. Our goal in resurrecting the 8th Wonder is to invite more visitors inside.

When will the project be complete?

Saving places takes time! But with your generous support, we hope to get the Houston Astrodome project completed as soon as possible.

How do I get support for my project? Or can I submit a project for consideration?

We at the National Trust are always interested in hearing about what is important to you. Although we may not be able to save it immediately, you can always contact your state’s historic preservation office and see how you can get started on the road to preservation!

Is the National Trust involved in other restoration projects?

Yes! We’re the country’s leading advocate for saving historic places. As such, we’re on the ground in communities across the nation. Visit our website to explore other National Treasures like the Astrodome.

Media Inquiries:

For further media inquiries about these projects, check out our Press Center.

My question wasn’t answered above. Who can I contact?

First, please see the full FAQ for the Cities Project.

If you have questions about the projects or how to claim perks other than tickets, please email cities@savingplaces.org.

If you have questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com.

If you have questions about the Cities Project, please email corporaterelations@heinekenusa.com.

story:
Our installation in South Africa  will include :

- a Kaddish installation consisting of reproducing pages of a 1940 Lithuanian telephone book giving names addresses, professions and telephone numbers of the perished community

- the Kaddish prayer printed on fabric and the haunting soundscape by Phillip Miller which was based on the Yiddish lullaby Oyfn Propetshik.

-  2 embroidered maps - one of the mass killing sites of Lithuania and the second of the Jewish  population of Lithuania in 1897.

- an audio interview with David and Lily Goldblatt 

- a film of survivor testimonies

We need help with funding to:

Edit a  film of survivor testimonies  $4,000

Re-create the Kaddish installation with sound and lighting  $8,000

Print 1940 Lithuanian phone book as wallpaper   $3,000

Print and frame photographs of Kovne buildings of Jewish community use at the time of the war   $2,000

Edit and print catalogue  $3,000

story:
¿Por qué esta campaña?

En los últimos años estamos viendo cómo la figura de Cristóbal Colón está siendo atacada desde diferentes ámbitos utilizando argumentos de escaso rigor histórico.  Desde The Hispanic Council queremos reivindicar el legado de Cristóbal Colón, que protagonizó una de las mayores gestas de la Historia uniendo a dos mundos.  

 

A través de esta campaña queremos conseguir fondos para: 

  • Elaborar una publicación que ayude a hacer frente a los ataques injustificados contra la figura de Cristóbal Colón aportando argumentos objetivos y rigurosos.  Su autora será la profesora María Saavedra, profesora de la Universidad San Pablo CEU y gran experta en América.  El informe llevará por título "¿Columbus Day? Sí, gracias. Manual práctico para entender la figura de Cristóbal Colón".

 

  • Organizar conferencias y actos de divulgación histórica sobre la figura de Cristóbal Colón y su legado en Estados Unidos.

 

  • Generar impacto en la opinión pública a través de los medios de comunicación y las redes sociales. 

 

¿Qué necesitamos?

 

  • Cubrir los costes de la producción e impresión del informe.

 

  • Difundir nuestros contenidos y nuestro mensaje: ¡Compártelo con tus contactos!

 

  • Que se escuche la voz de aquellos que quieren promover la cultura hispana y defender el legado de figuras históricas como Cristóbal Colón. 

 

¿Por qué colaborar?

 

  • Porque estarás contribuyendo a difundir la cultura hispana en España y EE.UU.

 

  • Porque es necesario que desde la sociedad civil y el mundo académico nos movilicemos frente a la manipulación de la Historia. 

 

  • Porque disfrutarás de importantes ventajas: tu nombre en los agradecimientos del informe; un ejemplar dedicado en tu domicilio; acceso a nuestro Club de Amigos y muchas más.

DRAG SHOW VIRTUEL - Édition Sherbrooke
27 août - 20h00 sur Youtube
Animé par Gina Gates

 

Malgré les nouvelles règles de limitation des rassemblements à travers le Québec, nous avons cru nécessaire d'offrir un spectacle virtuel afin de faire profiter à un plus grand nombre de gens, ce divertissement qui saura mettre de la couleur dans votre soirée. 

Cette collecte de fonds a pour but de soutenir les artistes drags de ce spectacle numérique de grande envergure. 

Nous voulons également donner une partie du montant final au GRIS Estrie, apprenez-en davantage sur leur travail : https://grisestrie.org

L'animation et la technique se feront de manière bénévole.

Merci de votre support! C'est grandement apprécié.

story:
THE EVENKI

Set in the sweeping wild landscape of deepest Siberia, in a land called Evenkia, the Udygir family and their ancestors have been nomads for hundreds of years.

This is where I met Vladimir Udygir, "my Evenki Grandpa" and I felt I've known him for ever.
I also saw that most of the Evenki families have already given up on the traditional way of living. His family was one of the last to live in the forest: Grandpa, his adult children and grandchildren.

The Evenkis’ reindeer are domesticated and they are essential to living in the forest. They have small herds and they treat the animals with care and affection: the herding is based on a close relationship between the deer and the humans. These animals are rather transport than food source through the vast taiga forest and uniquely the Evenki even ride special “saddle-reindeer” which have an intimate bond with their riders.

But due to a sad series of unfortunate family events (that you can read about in the Impact part), the Udygir family recently lost their reindeer herd, and without them they cannot live and travel out in the forest. If they give up, as so many Evenki families already have, this unique and ancient way of being will be lost forever...

Vladimir’s deepest desire is to keep the nomadic tradition alive. He must pass on his knowledge and passion while he can.

But without reindeer it’s impossible.

Their future is now in our hands.
 

A FILM STORY

(Please note this crowdfunding is JUST for the reindeer - this is not fundraising for the documentary film).

I met Vladimir more than ten years ago and we started shooting a film about the Evenki way of life, living and traveling together in the taiga forest. I was amazed to see this kind of way of life in the 21st century. More amazingly they seemed a truly happy family unlike the other Evenki families in the villages, who gave up their culture and often got caught in the deadly spiral of alcohol addiction.  

It was obvious that the health and the well being of the Evenki people is directly tied to their life in the forest and with their reindeer.

But then I lost the track of Vladimir for a decade, though I never gave up my dream to complete the film about their remarkable life.

Miraculously I recently found a bunch of old photos from the 1930's taken by missionaries who interacted with the Udygir family’s direct ancestors!

I believe the Udygir family must also see these pictures.

Even though I kept trying to contact the family I met 10 years ago, I had no idea even if Grandpa Vladimir was still alive.  

And then, thanks to social media I found Jordan, a young American who happened to live with our Evenki Grandpa’s son-in-law for several years! Jordan told me that Grandpa is still OK and had been asking for many years about why I had never returned!
I was touched... But I also heard from Jordan that tragically he has lost all his reindeer.

This is when we decided to start this campaign to help them and at the same time to save a small part of a disappearing culture.

This is also a beautiful opportunity to finish the film, that I started 10 years ago, as Grandpa gets back his herd of reindeer and with them his heritage and hope for his family for the future.
 

THE PROJECT

The plan is to buy a small herd of 20 reindeer which is sufficient to restart the Udygir family’s nomadic way of life.
One reindeer costs about $600 USD, so we need to raise $12,000 USD to buy the herd alone. Above that are the costs of transporting the animals to the family from where they are purchased in other locations in Siberia.

Obviously the more money we raise, the more reindeer we’re going to be able to buy... and that helps a lot to keep their way of life and culture alive!
Also, if we raise money for enough reindeer, we also intend to donate some animals to other families in the tribe.

We will film the whole reindeer-operation, the intimate moment when Grandpa Vladimir and his family get back the reindeer herd. With the addition of our footage from 2005-2006 we can complete the film about this unique family.
 

IMPACT

You may raise the question what happened to Vladimir’s reindeer...? Well, since 2006 he went blind and the people that he was travelling with in that time were not keen on reindeer herding and gambled away his animals. Vladimir was unable to keep the reindeer alone.

But recently he reunited with one of his daughters, Valya, and his grandchildren. Valya is also determined to keep the traditions alive and save their culture. They even organize "taiga schools" for the small children to be able to get education in the forest. If we manage to get them reindeer, then no doubt they will be in the right and competent  hands. 

Vladimir is with Valya’s family and still going strong. He has now the opportunity to pass his invaluable knowledge on to the next generations.

But only with your help.
 

WHO WE ARE

Zoltán Török
I’m an award-winning filmmaker based in Sweden mostly telling stories from the last parts of the shrinking wilderness around the globe. If you like nature films then there is a some chance that you might have seen some of my works on tv.
Some more info and clips on my website:  www.wildtales.net

And my reindeer story… I started a feature documentary with Vladimir in Evenkia in 2005-2006 when I spent several weeks with him and his family. But due to unforeseen reasons the film has never been completed. It has always disturbed me a lot that I couldn’t keep my promise to Vladimir: to make a film about his family and the Evenki culture! (Here you can read about our first encounter in the winter taiga).

Recently the filming has got support from a tv foundation in Hungary (where I’m originally from). And thanks to Rachel and her brother, Jordan, who spent lots of time with the same tribe, I found Vladimir again! And he still has the deepest desire to preserve and pass on their unique way of life, but needs some help from the outside world...

Jordan Jonas
I spent several years in Russia before meeting an Evenki hunter who invited me to the north and with whom I spent a season fur trapping in the Siberian wilderness. He then introduced me to his nomadic reindeer herding cousins, and upon meeting them and seeing their way of life I was blown away. I did not know people still lived as they did and between 2010 and 2016 i would spend over 3 years living amongst them, learning their ways, and becoming intimately aware of the harsh beauty of their forest life. They quickly became like family to me and we shared in both the highs and lows of life. Unfortunately their culture faces unique hurdles it will have to overcome if it is to survive and pass its richness on to future generations. If the last herders give up their way of life for the ease and alcohol of the village like so many already have, this unique and ancient way of being will be lost forever. I believe it is indescribably valuable not only to the individual Evenki but also to the whole of human culture to support those still practicing their ways and make sure they can successfully pass it on. You can watch some videos from Evenkia on my youtube channel .

Rachel Jonas
I am a freelance photo journalist who spent a summer with the Evenki in 2015. During my time there, I was so impressed by the them.  The Evenki are a resilient, resourceful, warm people with a strong connection to the reindeer and the nature they share.  I remember more than once hearing the herders say that their life in the forest teaches them only to take what they need not more. They live with respect for the nature around them. In fact, it was more than respect.  It was a kind of rare harmony that lacked the neurosis of the modern world.  But life for the tribe, is under threat.  Their sustainability is directly tied to the reindeer and now they need our help.  I am excited about this project and the prospect of helping restore to them some hope for continuing this invaluable way of life. My website: racheljonas.com

THE EVENKI
Set in the sweeping wild landscape of deepest Siberia, in a land called Evenkia, the Udygir family and their ancestors have been nomads for hundreds of years.
This is where I met Vladimir Udygir, "my Evenki Grandpa" and I felt I've known him for ever.I also saw that most of the Evenki families have already given up on the traditional way of living. His family was one of the last to live in the forest: Grandpa, his adult children and grandchildren.
The Evenkis’ reindeer are domesticated and they are essential to living in the forest. They have small herds and they treat the animals with care and affection: the herding is based on a close relationship between the deer and the humans. These animals are rather transport than food source through the vast taiga forest and uniquely the Evenki even ride special “saddle-reindeer” which have an intimate bond with their riders.

But due to a sad series of unfortunate family events (that you can read about in the Impact part), the Udygir family recently lost their reindeer herd, and without them they cannot live and travel out in the forest. If they give up, as so many Evenki families already have, this unique and ancient way of being will be lost forever...
Vladimir’s deepest desire is to keep the nomadic tradition alive. He must pass on his knowledge and passion while he can.
But without reindeer it’s impossible.
Their future is now in our hands.

story:
What do ‘WE REPRESENT’?

Imagine a future where a new generation of leaders accurately reflects the diversity of our world- that’s what WE REPRESENT.

The most formative years of a young person’s life occur during high school - the media, the imagery, and the examples that our youth see are integral to the opportunities they view for themselves. Youth in Canada spend an average of 6-8 hours/day consuming media of some sort - and in times of late there’s been a shift of the tides for the better. Finally, we’re living in a world that understands the power and strength of diversity. But we’ve got a long way to go.

Recent examples of representation in the media and our world: 

From top left to right clockwise: Lilly Singh becomes first Indian-origin woman to host a Late night show; Most Diverse Congress in US History; Black Panther smashes box office records; Hidden Figures highlights the accomplishments of African American women at NASA in the 50's and 60's; Crazy Rich Asians becomes the first all-asian Hollywood blockbuster and smashes records as well

We hear a lot about the gender gap, but what about the mindset gaps that young underrepresented groups face? How do we fix the problem at the top of the pipeline?

That’s where we come in. We believe that when we equip our youth with the mindset that their dreams and identities have validity to become realities, we all win. We believe that through leveraging the age old power of storytelling to showcase underrepresented narratives,  we can create a new generation of leaders that will reflect the world we walk through. Through telling these stories, it reveals what is possible - suddenly becoming a tech founder, a CEO, an award-winning artist, a Prime Minister - all become much more real.

 

How do 'WE REPRESENT'?

We believe in the power of “If you can see it, you can be it.”

At WE REPRESENT, we’re bringing together, and putting youth across the Greater Toronto Area in the driver’s seat of re-telling the stories of impactful, yet underrepresented women in history.

Our 2019 Competition is themed “Re-Writing History: Her-Story” - chosen to elevate the stories of women past, and present, who’s stories can reshape our collective mindsets around what leadership looks like. From spoken word to art installations, from musical compositions to choreographed performances and short films - our inaugural Creative Competition needs YOU to be brought to life.

 

Our Goal? To Find our Tribe of Partners.

You want a society that represents us all - and we are here to find our tribe of partners, not a finite dollar amount - we're looking for 100 backers.

This is our way to share our story directly with young Canadians, organizations, and community leaders everywhere to join us on this journey. Our goal is to find at least 100 backers who believe in this mission as much as we do.

This campaign isn’t about an end fundraising goal, it isn’t about a set dollar amount - it’s about finding our tribe of people who believe in what WE REPRESENT, and want to join us in this journey. By joining us and contributing in any way, you become our partner in representation, and we can’t wait to have you.

When you back WE REPRESENT, you become one of our valued partners. What does that mean? It means that you share our commitment to standing with today's youth, and pledging that we will work together to create corporations, governments, startups, artistic excellence, and every facet of society in between, that represents the world we all live in.

Impact to Date:

  • 30 Student Ambassadors representing 15 schools across the GTA
  • 5 workshops delivered to 500+ youth with mission-aligned community and education partners

Our Student Ambassadors hail from 15 schools across the GTA from ages 12-17! 

Where your contribution will go/ Use of funds:

As a WE REPRESENT Partner, you join our growing community of individuals, corporations and foundations dedicated to propelling Canadian youth forward. Primarily, your support will be integral in bringing our 2019 WE REPRESENT Showcase to life, prizing for our competition winners, and resources to further their learning and growth. Core areas will be:

  • Funding student tickets
  • Prizing and leadership opportunities for students
  • Representation materials

Other ways to support!

We understand if you are unable to make a financial contribution to help us reach our goal. But if you are interested in WE REPRESENT, there are a few other ways you can support:

1. Spread the word! Share our message with the high school students you know to apply to our competition! 
2. Follow us on Instagram: www.instagram.com/werepresentco
4. Follow us on Twitter and retweet our posts: www.twitter.com/werepresentco
5. Use the hashtag #WEREPRESENT2019 on all social media platforms.

 

And guess what? Our creative competition is currently accepting submissions!

Share this with a high school student you know in the GTA and get them to apply by March 31st!

 

Last but not least... meet our team!

We're a team with backgrounds in technology, business and non-profits, who all share a love for storytelling and have felt the impact of creativity in our formative years firsthand. 

Read more about us below! 

Sonia Sidhu: Hailing from the West Coast, Sonia is a Next 36 alumni and previously founded an e-commerce startup. She currently works on the product team at RBC Ventures, where she works on a venture called Arrive to support newcomers to Canada. In her spare time, Sonia has a passion for writing and film. Contact her at sonia@werepresent.co

Tricia Jose: Tricia is a co-founder of Arrive - a social and professional community for newcomers to Canada, and holds a MASc in Biomedical Engineering from the University of Toronto. Previously, she founded a Fintech startup, and co-wrote and directed a non-profit musical that has raised over $250k for local/international charities. In her spare time, Tricia loves making music with her family.  Contact her at tricia@werepresent.co

Jamila Hu: Jamila is a financial consultant for mergers and acquisitions at PwC and is working towards becoming a chartered professional accountant. In her space time, Jamila has a passion for yoga, travelling and cooking for her friends and family. Contact her at jamila@werepresent.co

Mikey Jose: Mikey Jose is a 3rd year student at UBC, majoring in Cognitive Systems. He is interested in the intersection of neuroscience and technology towards improving the medical landscape. After hours, he pursues music composition and production; with his family, he created an original non-profit musical at the age of 15 that has raised over $250k to date. Contact him at mikey@werepresent.co​

If it's not accessible to the poor it's neither radical nor revolutionary. 

Westfest is a FREE, diverse, art & music festival in Ottawa going on 15 years thanks to our generous sponsors and partners. Now we're inviting you to be a DONOR! 100 per cent of your big-hearted donation to the Westfest Indigogo campaign will go directly to supporting the festival and the talented artists who perform, which in turn, allows the festival to remain FREE for EVERYONE to attend! 

Ottawa, this is YOUR city, YOUR festival... help keep it free!

Give #westfestlove and get awesome perks like Westfest VIP Passes and chances to win the Ultimate Westfest Experience Package (UWXP2018)* and more!

*What is the Ultimate Westfest Experience Package?

  • Two (2) nights airbnb, one block from stage  (Friday June 8 & Saturday June 9)
  • Two (2) breakfasts in Hintonburg, just steps from your airbnb (Saturday, June 9 & Sunday June 10)
  • Food Truck lunch for two (Saturday June 9th and Sunday June 10th)
  • 2 VIP passes for each night of the festival 2 pm – 10 pm, includes complimentary beverages, all night catering, private washrooms, seats next to stage. (Friday June 8, Saturday June 9 and Sunday June 10)
  • Backstage tour, meet and greet with Headliners each night.  (Friday June 8, Saturday June 9 and Sunday June 10)
  • Contest winner will be drawn June 1, 2018.

Donate for your chance to WIN and celebrate 15 years of Westfest in style on June 8-10, 2018!
