This year we have groups coming from Cuba, Colombia, China, Ukraine, Ethiopia, Ecuador, Mali, Peru and Puerto Rico. Several groups based in the US will be traveling to here from across the country as well as local groups based in the DC area. While we are hoping to cover most their performance fees by charging admission there are still many costs involved like lodging, transportation and basic hospitality. We want to keep the ticket prices low to keep the concerts accessible and  your donations will help us offset these costs as well as help us pay for other productions costs like venue fees, paying for PA equipment and sound engineers as well as marketing costs so we can reach as many people in the region as possible. We are also be showing four films with post-screening discussions and plan on paying for screening fees and providing honorariums to the filmmakers and guest speakers.Beyond helping us with the festival budget, your contribution is essential to making the festival a reality for the city, the artists, and the community. Currently we have no institutional support or endowments so the festival is completely independent and reliant upon public support. Your support. By making it happen this year it will help us get the attention and support of the city, local business, and arts organizations and then the festival will continue to grow year after year, you can help this become an annual city tradition.For the full schedule of the festival visit this link HEREBelow is a list of just some of our confirmed groups for this year's festival. Just click on the name to learn more about these amazing groups!Fendika (Ethiopia)Anbessa Orchestra (Israel/Brooklyn)Mamadou Kelly (Mali)Rio Mira (Equador/Peru)Septeto Santiaguero (Cuba)Kombilesa Mi (Colombia)Orquesta el Macabeo (Puerto Rico)Zhou Family Band (China)Takht-Al Nagham (Syria/NYC)Kurbasy (Ukraine)Radio Jarocho (Mexico/NYC)and many more!

story:
UPDATE: Whoa, we funded this theater in just 2 days!  Thank you for being so insanely generous. Let's try for one more theater and send some more kids to see themselves on screen.  Each theater costs about $1500.  Let's do it!

The short version

  1. Raise $ to buyout a theater (~$1,500 per theater or ~88 seats at $17 per seat.)
  2. Donate the tickets to organizations such as Big Brothers Big Sister
  3. Kids and their guardians get to go on a crazy rich movie-going adventure to see themselves on screen for the first time

​The more money we raise, the more theaters we can buy out, and the more kids can see this movie!  

The long version

We're organizing buyouts of Crazy Rich Asians and donating tickets to community organizations such as Big Brothers Big Sister.  This is similar to what was done by the African-American community for the launch of "Black Panther."

It's the first US movie in 20 years with an all Asian cast.  Growing up, it was rare to see people that look like us on screen.  Now we have the chance to give that opportunity to the next generation and tell Hollywood representation means business!

You don't have to be Asian or Crazy Rich to join. In fact, diversity is the whole point. So show some love! Let's buy out a theatre (or two), get this movie a #goldopen, and donate the tickets so young people can see themselves in a story!

<3  From Big Brothers Big Sisters NYC

We need crazy collaborators.

Donate some cash-o-la to this. All of the funds go towards buying out the theatre. 

  • Sponsor one ticket or a few!  
  • Spam the company-wide email list and tell your coworkers to join you!
  • Post it on Facebook so your mom and aunties will see!

But really though, anything will help.

 

Why Participate?

Stephanie Foo in her Vox article said it best:

"It was a little surprising for me to burst into tears 10 minutes into the movie. I understood the power of story and of representation in media. But I couldn't have predicted how impactful seeing my story onscreen would be..."

 

And Director Jon Chu:

"Crazy Rich Asians is more than just a movie, it's a movement."

 

And Bing Chen follows with...:

"EVERY MOVEMENT NEEDS ITS MAFIA."


    (We're the MAFIA!)

    Risks & Challenges

    It’s a simple plan: buy out showings and donate the tickets to community organizations.  But maybe you're worried about...

    • What if the movie is terrible? Nope, it's CERTIFIED FRESH on Rotten Tomatoes - currently at a very fresh 93%.
    • What if you run away with the money? We'll send all supporters receipts of how the money was spent.  If there's any money left at the end, we'll donate it to a local nonprofit.
    • Am I just supporting a movie studio? You can think about it that way... or you can think about it as giving kids the gift of seeing themselves on screen for the first time and voting for diversity with your dollars!  We want to show the movie industry representation means BUSINESS!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't sponsor a ticket right now? We understand - there are other ways to help:

    • Send this campaign to your company mailing list!  Large companies usually have interest groups that would love to help. 
    • Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and email.
    • Help us organize the event (Slide into our DM)

     

    Who are you & why are you doing this?

    No, we don't work for Warner Brothers.  We're just big believers in representation and the power of media to shape the national conversation.

    Gwen Nguyen: Gwen is VP of Enterprise at Indiegogo (an insider!) and previously co-founded (along with James), OneConnect, a platform to disrupt the flow of $600 billion in remittances each year.

     

    James Bao: By day James runs a creative digital agency, Pixel SF, by night he's on the board of the Center for Asian American Media, a 38 year old nonprofit dedicated to bringing Asian American stories to light.

    Thao Nguyen: We're pretty sure Thao is going to be the president of Vietnam one day.  For now, she's in Operations at Indiegogo (another insider!)

    Mic Nguyen: Writer, digital strategist, and runs a killer podcast called AsianNotAsian.

    Special Thanks

    • Thanks to Philip Fung and Alex Wu from A3 Foundation for leading the charge in the Asian American community and inspiring this campaign.
    • Thanks to Naja Lockwood for being the connector that made this happen

La Coopérative École Cindy Mae Danse est une entreprise à but non lucratif qui a pour mission de développer la danse, de promouvoir cet univers artistique et physique et de permettre aux citoyens de tous les âges des Îles de la Madeleine d’être plus actifs.  e service saisonnier est offert de septembre à juin. Il se divise en trois sessions distinctes, soit deux sessions consacrées aux classes technique et une session afin de préparer les danseurs à présenter le spectacle de fin d’année coopérative a comptabilisé 210 inscriptions pour les cours offerts à des élèves âgés entre 3 et 83 ans. Ces cours touchent les domaines de la danse contemporaine, de la danse créative, de la danse classique et de la mise en forme.  Le service saisonnier est offert de septembre à juin. Il se divise en trois sessions distinctes, soit deux sessions consacrées aux classes technique et une session afin de préparer les danseurs à présenter le spectacle de fin d’année.  Une à deux semaines s'ajoutent pendant la période estivale, lors du camp de danse d'été. La Coopérative École Cindy Mae Danse (CÉCMD) est une coopérative de travailleurs qui a été fondée en janvier 2017 par Cindy Mae Arsenault, Cybèle Pelletier et Joana Landry. 

La Coopérative École Cindy Mae Danse est présentement en démarrage et ses membres sont activement à la recherche de financement afin d'améliorer la qualité du service offert.

Le projet d’expansion, c’est quoi?

- La construction d’une salle de danse; 

- L’achat d’un plancher de danse professionnel et de barres de ballet;

- Un mur entièrement recouvert de miroirs;

- L’acquisition de matériel d’appoint spécialisé;

- L’assurance d’un service de meilleure qualité par le biais d’installations sécuritaires et favorables à l’apprentissage de la danse;

- Une vision à long terme afin de permettre la pérennité de l’entreprise;

- Un projet d’une envergure de plus de 80 000$.

story:
Who We Are

We are Rapsodi, a team of five 15-year-old students (Sebastiano, Margherita, Marco, Stefano, and Rocco) from H-International School in Treviso, nearby Venice, in Italy. We derive our name from ancient Greek rhapsodes, poets who used to travel around the world to learn and tell incredible stories, to transmit culture and preserve it from oblivion.

We want to be 21st-century rhapsodes and tell stories from all over the world, amplifying the power of cultural heritage as a way to inspire and connect people.

As part of a year-long school project, the "Acceleration Lab", we were tasked with finding a new way to promote local cultural heritage. In order to do so, with the help of professional mentors, we turned into a mini-startup and worked with different roles (from communications to business development, to graphic design) in order to devise our first product, a tabletop game named CoolTour – Sile Edition.

Our Challenge

"Culture" surely is a big word. But what is culture, specifically? This was not an easy question to answer, but a necessary one in beginning our project. 

We started by giving our own definition of culture, drawing a big mind map of the concept, and writing our manifesto, mission, and vision for this project. Then we jumped into research, in order to find an opportunity to promote our local cultural heritage.

During our research, we found our inspiration. We met Glauco Stefanato, one of the last sailors of the Sile (a river flowing near our school, approximately from Treviso to Venice). Glauco, once a fluvial shipper, found a way to keep doing what he loves – sailing the rivers that flow into the Venetian lagoon – by turning his boat trips into guided historical and cultural tours of the region short after the decline of commercial fluvial transportation, in the '70s. The deep knowledge and passion we found in his tales made us realize we had a cultural treasure flowing right by our school – and yet, little did we know about a river that was even mentioned by Dante in the Divina Commedia. 

We thought: why don't we know more about these exciting stories of the past, of our past? Can we possibly leverage these stories to promote our cultural identity among new generations and attract tourists that usually know much about the (overcrowded) city of Venice, but very little about the surrounding region? How do we do this in a new, engaging way?

Our Solution

CoolTour, the heart of our project, is how we intend to make people more aware of the past in order to inspire their future. CoolTour Sile is our first project, based on the cultural heritage connected to the Sile river, flowing between Treviso and Venice – but we hope many others will come, inspired by faraway places and other beautiful stories.

CoolTour Sile is a board game that will capture the silent culture floating on the waters of this river, collecting piece by piece of its millennial history – the Venetian dominion, the rural culture of its people, the gypsy tales of its sailors, and much more – within a game that will bring people together and pass these thrilling stories on.

The game will be centered on the perspective of the barcari, the sailors of the Sile that used to roam the river with their burci boats carrying all sorts of goods for sale and living a fascinating lifestyle.

How CoolTour Works

A game of CoolTour will include 3 to 6 players, all of whom will play as barcari. The goal of the game is to be the "wealthiest" of all the barcari, but wealth in this game is defined in a very peculiar way – that is how many legends, anecdotes, stories, and insights about local culture, from ancient times to the Serenissima and up to present day, each player will be able to collect during the game.

Moving up and down the river with their burci, the typical boats used for fluvial and lagoon navigation in Venice, players must collect and deliver all sorts of goods (represented by "Mission Cards"): hay used as fuel, animal feed, and litter; bricks produced by the furnaces located on the river; cellulose coming from Northern Europe, to be used in the paper mills; old rags and clothes coming from the United States that humble villagers can reuse (roba da occhei), and much more.

On their path, players can sell and buy goods at various local markets, and will encounter unexpected events (both positive and negative) of all kinds, represented by special "Event Cards". Players will face contraband fishers and rat infestations, deal with unforgiving weather conditions, engage in boat races, fall in love with local villagers, and so on.

Playing the game, players will get in touch with the forgotten stories, unique anecdotes, local legends, and fascinating traditions we are collecting through our meticulous research work, both by reading local history books and interviewing local experts – all with the goal of preserving and spreading this inestimable treasure of local knowledge and identity among younger (as well as older) generations.

How We Will Use The Funds

We have already developed a first working prototype of our game. We need to further develop the game before we can release it. The funds we will collect through this fundraising campaign will help us:

- continue our research, including: purchasing books, financing field trips, arranging interviews with local experts, and more;

- get the help of professional designers who can support us in the playtesting phase, improving game mechanics to make it even more fun and entertaining;

- finance the cost of prototyping materials, as we figure out the best way to physically produce our game;

- take other steps in the development of the game as needed. This may include: setting up a website and other communication channels, organizing events to test and launch the game, and more.

Your help in this phase will make sure we can continue developing CoolTour Sile. By donating to this campaign, you will be included in our list of supporters and will be notified of all future updates. We are aiming at an early 2019 release.

story:
Help push the restoration of a true Washington, D.C. icon over the finish line!

For years, experts have been working tirelessly to restore Union Station’s soaring Main Hall. Fast-forward to today, where this monumental project is just one crucial step away from completion.

We at the National Trust for Historic Preservation, in collaboration with Heineken USA and Union Station Redevelopment Corporation, are on a mission to help complete Union Station's restoration by repairing four of the station’s 46 legionnaire statues. With your support, we’ll be closer than ever to returning Union Station to its full historic grandeur.

Designed by legendary architect Daniel Burnham, Union Station is a masterpiece that set the standard for monumental Washington as we know it. When it was completed in 1908, Union Station covered more ground than any other building in the country and was the largest train station in the world. In fact, the building is so vast that the Washington Monument could lie entirely on its side within the station’s concourse!

Over the years, the historic Main Hall underwent drastic changes as the popularity of rail travel ebbed and flowed, chipping away at the architect’s original vision of a unique open environment. At one point, a circular, two-story cafe was added smack in the middle of the Main Hall, making it hard to appreciate the station in all its glory.

Recently, however, that all changed.

Five years ago, the Union Station Redevelopment Corporation started turning back the hands of time to return the Main Hall to its heyday. Today, for the first time since the 1970s, the jaw-dropping room is revamped and 100% unobstructed. The dramatic 96-foot ceiling has also been brought back to life, thanks to 120,000 sheets of new gold leafing. It’s a new day for this very old place, but one final piece of this legendary puzzle needs help to be completed.

Every year, nearly 40 million visitors pass under the watchful eyes of 46 carved soldiers perched throughout the station. Commissioned in 1905, these imposing Roman-style legionnaires were meant to symbolize the number of States in the Union at the time of the station's opening in 1907.

While they have guarded Union Station well for over 100 years, today they’re in need of a little TLC. That’s where you come in.

Success! We're happy to report that our campaign raised $41,429! That's $26,429 above our original goal of $15,000!

Thanks to the generous support of our backers, we'll soon kick-start the repair of the station’s legionnaires by funding an important pilot restoration of the four statues that stand over the entrance to the West Hall.

Please stay tuned to the updates section of this page for additional project news.

I claimed tickets to the Bruno Mars: 24K Magic World Tour as my perk and have questions.

Thank you for supporting our project! You will find answers to your questions in our FAQ. If you have specific questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com. Enjoy the show!

What is the National Trust for Historic Preservation?

The National Trust for Historic Preservation, a privately funded nonprofit organization, works to save America’s historic places. We are the cause that inspires Americans to save the places where history happened. The cause that connects us to our diverse pasts, weaving a multi-cultural nation together. The cause that transforms communities from places where we live into places that we love. As the leading voice for preservation, we are the cause for people saving places.

Our mission is to protect significant places representing our diverse cultural experience by taking direct action and inspiring broad public support.

Where is my donation going?

More than 90% of all funds raised will support the cities' projects and the National Trust’s ongoing work to save historic places in Washington, D.C. and around the country. Up to 10% will cover Indiegogo costs and processing fees as described in Indiegogo’s Terms and Conditions. 

When will I get my perk (non-ticket)?

Perks will be delivered later this summer (July/August).

Can I visit the project site?

Yes! Union Station is open to visitors, including the newly completed Main Hall. If traveling by train,the main entryway is hard to miss. That’s why, with your support, this project will make a huge difference in helping the legionnaires shine again.

When will the project be complete?

Saving places takes time! The Main Hall is complete. With your generous support, the four Legionnaires in the West Entrance will be repaired as soon as possible!

How do I get support for my project? Or can I submit a project for consideration?

We at the National Trust are always interested in hearing about what is important to you. Although we may not be able to save it immediately, you can always contact your state’s historic preservation office and see how you can get started on the road to preservation!

Is the National Trust involved in other restoration projects?

Yes! We’re the country’s leading advocate for saving historic places. As such, we’re on the ground in communities across the nation. Visit our website to explore other historic places that we are trying to save like the Legionnaires of Union Station.

Media Inquiries:

For further media inquiries about these projects, check out our Press Center.

My question wasn’t answered above. Who can I contact?

First, please see the full FAQ for the Cities Project.

If you have questions about the projects or how to claim perks other than tickets, please email cities@savingplaces.org.

If you have questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email  fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com.

If you have questions about the Cities Project, please email corporaterelations@heinekenusa.com.
story_txt: Help push the restoration of a true Washington, D.C. icon over the finish line!For years, experts have been working tirelessly to restore Union Station’s soaring Main Hall. Fast-forward to today, where this monumental project is just one crucial step away from completion.We at the National Trust for Historic Preservation, in collaboration with Heineken USA and Union Station Redevelopment Corporation, are on a mission to help complete Union Station's restoration by repairing four of the station’s 46 legionnaire statues. With your support, we’ll be closer than ever to returning Union Station to its full historic grandeur.Designed by legendary architect Daniel Burnham, Union Station is a masterpiece that set the standard for monumental Washington as we know it. When it was completed in 1908, Union Station covered more ground than any other building in the country and was the largest train station in the world. In fact, the building is so vast that the Washington Monument could lie entirely on its side within the station’s concourse!Over the years, the historic Main Hall underwent drastic changes as the popularity of rail travel ebbed and flowed, chipping away at the architect’s original vision of a unique open environment. At one point, a circular, two-story cafe was added smack in the middle of the Main Hall, making it hard to appreciate the station in all its glory.Recently, however, that all changed.Five years ago, the Union Station Redevelopment Corporation started turning back the hands of time to return the Main Hall to its heyday. Today, for the first time since the 1970s, the jaw-dropping room is revamped and 100% unobstructed. The dramatic 96-foot ceiling has also been brought back to life, thanks to 120,000 sheets of new gold leafing. It’s a new day for this very old place, but one final piece of this legendary puzzle needs help to be completed.Every year, nearly 40 million visitors pass under the watchful eyes of 46 carved soldiers perched throughout the station. Commissioned in 1905, these imposing Roman-style legionnaires were meant to symbolize the number of States in the Union at the time of the station's opening in 1907.While they have guarded Union Station well for over 100 years, today they’re in need of a little TLC. That’s where you come in.Success! We're happy to report that our campaign raised $41,429! That's $26,429 above our original goal of $15,000!Thanks to the generous support of our backers, we'll soon kick-start the repair of the station’s legionnaires by funding an important pilot restoration of the four statues that stand over the entrance to the West Hall.Please stay tuned to the updates section of this page for additional project news.I claimed tickets to the Bruno Mars: 24K Magic World Tour as my perk and have questions. story:
If a city could speak, what would it say?

With your help, we’re about to find out in Chicago through an innovative audio installation called Voiceover.

We at the National Trust for Historic Preservation, along with Heineken USA and Latent Design, all love a good story, especially when it’s about what makes a city an incredible place to live. With your support, we’ll turn the mic on Chicago to record personal narratives on its streets and in its neighborhoods, then broadcast them for everyone to hear on the city’s elevated Bloomingdale Trail—the heart of The 606. 

Voiceover is an intimate, two-part public installation that will gather neighborhood narratives and share them in a citywide public broadcast. If you live in Chicago, this is your chance to tell the world those things you’ve always wanted to say about your city. What you love. What drives you nuts. What you’re hopeful of. What you wish would go away.

Participants will share one- or two-minute stories by stepping up to a private recording booth that will travel the streets and public spaces of Chicago. The unique space will be a cathartic moment allowing you to freely speak your mind in response to a variety of prompts. No name required, just a truth or two about the city where you live.

We will then juxtapose the privacy of this anonymous story with the exhibitionism of public space by broadcasting these responses in a continuous story via special speakers that will be installed on The Bloomingdale Trail. And as joggers and cyclists make their way down the trail, they will be able to hear the unfiltered and unscripted story of one of America’s greatest cities.

Success! We're happy to report that our campaign raised $36,930! That's $21,930 above our original goal of $15,000!

Thanks to the generous support of our backers, we're one step closer to building the Voiceover kiosk and getting it out into the world this summer.

Please stay tuned to the updates section of this page for additional project news.

I claimed tickets to the Bruno Mars: 24K Magic World Tour as my perk and have questions.

Thank you for supporting our project! You will find answers to your questions in our FAQ. If you have specific questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com. Enjoy the show!

What is the National Trust for Historic Preservation?

The National Trust for Historic Preservation, a privately funded nonprofit organization, works to save America’s historic places. We are the cause that inspires Americans to save the places where history happened. The cause that connects us to our diverse pasts, weaving a multi-cultural nation together. The cause that transforms communities from places where we live into places that we love. As the leading voice for preservation, we are the cause for people saving places.

Our mission is to protect significant places representing our diverse cultural experience by taking direct action and inspiring broad public support.

Where is my donation going?

More than 90% of all funds raised will support the cities' projects and the National Trust’s ongoing work to save historic places in Chicago and around the country. Up to 10% will cover Indiegogo costs and processing fees as described in Indiegogo’s Terms and Conditions. 

When will I get my perk (non-ticket)?

Perks will be delivered later this summer (July/August).

Can I visit the project site?

Yes! You can visit the Bloomingdale Trail in Chicago, and once the stories are completed with support from people like you, you’ll be able to hear people’s memories of Chicago as you make your own!

When will the project be complete?

Saving places takes time! But with your generous support, we hope to get Voiceover started as soon as possible.

How do I get support for my project? Or can I submit a project for consideration?

We at the National Trust are always interested in hearing about what is important to you. Although we may not be able to save it immediately, you can always contact your state’s historic preservation office and see how you can get started on the road to preservation!

Is the National Trust involved in other restoration projects?

Yes! We’re the country’s leading advocate for saving historic places. As such, we’re on the ground in communities across the nation. Visit our website to explore other historic places that we are saving like Chicago.

Media Inquiries:

For further media inquiries about these projects, check out our Press Center.

My question wasn’t answered above. Who can I contact?

First, please see the full FAQ for the Cities Project.

If you have questions about the projects or how to claim perks other than tickets, please email cities@savingplaces.org.

If you have questions about how to redeem your tickets, please email  fulfillment@lifeinmobile.com.

If you have questions about the Cities Project, please email corporaterelations@heinekenusa.com.

story:
Dear friends,

Folk traditions are strong because they combine the strength of the past with the vitality of now. The folklife of North Carolina—our music, craft, food, stories—is world-famous. Rising generations of North Carolinians continue to learn and love age-old practices, using and adapting traditions to engage the world today.

 

For 44 years, the North Carolina Folklife Institute (NC Folk) has worked to document, preserve, and share our unique heritage. Today we are looking to the future with plans for community and artistic collaborations that will reflect the emergent and dynamic folk practices and traditions of our state.

 

Will you help us build that future? 2018 is going to be a crucial and very busy year for NC Folk, and we need your support!  Your tax-deductible contribution will help make it possible for us to carry out these important projects:

 

  • Collaboration with Native tribes and organizations across the state to support community-led documentary projects.

 

  • A study of the rich (but under-recognized!) folk traditions of Bertie, Northampton, Hertford, and Gates Counties.

 

  • Digitizing the Jack Guy Collection, 1960s home recordings of old-time, bluegrass, and gospel music, hundreds of photographs, and other treasures from the legendary musical community around Beech Mountain, North Carolina.

 

  • Partnership with traditional musicians in Warren, Vance, and Halifax Counties to develop online presentations of field recordings

 

  • All this work allows us to continue our role as North Carolina’s go-to resource for information about the folk arts, artists, and traditions that make this state so special—connecting artists with opportunities, community scholars with technology and training, and North Carolinians with each other.

 

Please contribute to the future of the NC Folk, and the future of the arts and culture of North Carolina!

Gratefully,

Sarah Bryan, Executive Director

story:
My name is Byb Chanel Bibene; I am the Artistic Director of Mbongui Square Festival. I am originally from the Republic of Congo, central Africa. I found my new homes in San Francisco and Oakland. The Bay Area has been such a welcoming place where I have been able to express my artistic vision in dance and choreography by leading multiple dance productions that the art community has supported throughout the past seven years. And I am grateful for the many opportunities that the Bay Area arts scene has offered. 

Creating Mbongui Square Square has been my contribution to reinforce and promote the integration of communities in the Bay by encouraging multidisciplinary arts. The Bay Area is a place that perpetually seeks for social equity,  justice, and cultural diversity. Mbongui Square Festival reinforces this vision of a society that coalesces through the art of dance, music, spoken word, and visual arts. 

However, to make such a platform possible is the reason why, we the Mbongui staff, are asking for your financial support. Our goal is to raise $4,000. This amount will help us afford theater rental, studio rental for rehearsals, and accommodate our guest artists traveling from France, Germany and North Carolina. Your contribution will assure a successful festival, a growing number of ethnically diverse audience, an international artistic input via the talent of our guest artists, and the interconnectedness of the artists and the audience that represent the colors the Bay Area is made.   

As an acknowledgment of your contribution, we engage our effort to offer different packages that are comprised of the festival t-shirts, artistic hand made Africa-fabrics, cultural ornament for your gifts, a DVD of the festival, a CD with selection of soulful music, a particular seat in the theater, organic food and beverages, professional quality performances, and lots of fun.

By contributing, you participate in our endeavors to enrich and transform our Bay Area by keeping it an inspiring, informative, healing, transformative, and welcoming place. By contributing, you play a tremendous role in the emergence and discovery of new talents in dance, music, spoken word, and visual arts.  

One of the successes of Mbongui Square Festival is the projects collaborations between the Bay artists and our international guests allowing then a cross Atlantic representation of the Bay talent.

Our biggest obstacle in organizing Mbongui Square Festival is facing the unpredictable, that come in either the difficulty for our international guests to get visas, our non-local incapacity to afford air fares, or last minute withdrawals of artists. However, with the financial and moral and physical support of our friends in the community, we lay strategies to overcome these difficulties.  

Ways you can help us produce a successful festival is to either make a financial contribution, or promote the festival by sharing this campaign, spreading the word, or by volunteering during the festival. 

I appreciate your time and contribution.

 

Best Regards

Byb Chanel Bibene

story:
The Future Arts Foundation (FAF) was named one of the "Five Non-Profits Making a Difference in Colorado" by Boulder Lifestyle Magazine, and now they're trying to take it one step further.

The Colorado Bluebird Project is a year long fundraising campaign to open a youth arts house on the Front Range of Colorado. The arts house, to be named the Bluebird Arts House, will offer free and reduced rate music and art lessons, as well as host community events, films, and concerts. 

Started as a mission of the FAF, the idea quickly spread though the state and is now backed by dozens of local, national, and international musicians, as well as over 100 Colorado businesses!

 

How can you support the project?

There are many ways in which you can support the project...

 

Click "Back It" at the top of the page. 100% of your donation will go toward  opening the youth arts house in Boulder County in 2019. 

 

Purchase the FAF  Logo T-Shirt or Sticker under "Perks"- Both Men's and Women's  FAF Logo T-Shirts can be found under "Perks"

Attend the Bluebird Music Festival - From April 19th-April 26th, there will be a series of events taking place in Boulder, Ft. Collins, and Denver benefiting the project. The highlight of this series of concerts, the Bluebird Music Festival, will be held at Macky Auditorium on Saturday, April 21st. It will feature The Tallest Man on Earth (for his first Boulder performance in six years), Langhorne Slim, Josiah Johnson of The Head & The Heart, Paper Bird, Gasoline Lollipops, and Sun Jr. A limited number of tickets to this SOLD OUT concert can be found under "Perks."

There is also an Early Show that day featuring the debut performance from The Colorado Bluebirds featuring members of Yonder Mountain String Band, Elephant Revival, and more.

Tickets and info can be found at www.coloradobluebirdproject.com.

 

Visit our silent auction at Macky Auditorium on April 21st- There you will find signed memorabilia that was sent to the foundation from:

 

Phish

Jack Johnson

The Lumineers

Wilco

The National

Langhorne Slim ​

The Avett Brothers

Nathaniel Rateliff & the Night Sweats

Yonder Mountain String Band​

as well as festival perks!

 

Attend the kickoff dinner and concert - On April 19th, we will be hosting a kickoff dinner and concert featuring Langhorne Slim, Josiah Johnson of The Head & The Heart, The Hop Pickers, and Sun Jr. Details can be found at www.coloradobluebirdproject.com.

 

Donate - Donate and receive a tax deductible receipt at the top of this page or at www.futureartsfoundation.org. The Future Arts Foundation is a 501(c)3 organization.

story:
*English below*

На что?

Высокая стоимость участия в соревнованиях по нырянию в глубину объясняется особенностями безопасности и организации. Всегда задействовано много человеческих и технических ресурсов для страховки спортсменов. Расходуется много топлива на доставку нас к месту ныряния  - ребята-то мы не "мелкие" и на своих двоих не доплывешь до нужной глубины :). Поэтому задействуются лодки, катера и выбираются особые места для ныряния. Кроме этого, для успешного выступления на соревнованиях необходимо "разныряться" на месте, как мы это называем: почувствовать воду (течения, температуру, соленость) и подобрать соответствующее снаряжение. Т.е. провести еще несколько предварительных дней.

Вот примерно так и набегает сумма в пару тысяч долларов:

  • размещение + тренировки в течении соревнований + стартовые взносы 110 евро\ночь. 1-8 октября = 8 ночей (вылет обратно поздно 8го октября) = 880 евро
  • дополнительная неделя тренировок до стартов 110 евро\ночь с аналогичным пакетом, как и во время стартов. 6 ночей * 110 = 660 евро
  • авиаперелет Шарм - Даламан - Шарм. Даламан - Шарм уже есть и обошелся мне в $250. Возможно, что в Даламан я полечу не из Шарма. Но эти планы пока под вопросом. На данный момент Шарм-Даламан стоит $100-150
  • мелочи: трансфер из\в аэропорт, спортивная страховка, некоторое снаряжение, кислород для восстановления между тренировками, оплата организации глубоких тренировок в Египте и тд.
  • итого: (880 евро + 660 евро) + $350 = 1540 евро + $350 = $1820 + $350 = $2170 + "мелочи".

В благодарность

Я предлагаю самое ценное, что у меня есть: мой опыт и знания O:).
Большую часть времени я провожу в Дахабе, где можно понырять со мной в море или потренироваться в бассейне. Но если этот тихий городок не стоит в вашем маршруте, то вот еще предложение: с этого года я активно работаю над системой дистанционных тренировочных программ. English

This is my campaign for participation at freediving European Championship under CMAS rules. 

I am Nataliia Zharkova, multiple medalist of World freediving championships, multiple record holder for Ukraine and one of the top female freedivers. Freediving is a new sport and it's just starting to grow. But even for the best of us there is no queue of sponsors :). Therefore, we, freedivers, are looking for the opportunity to participate in the competitions on our own . After all, everyone wants to realize their potential at any price ... Especially when applying for first places and records ;). That's why I'm here. And this is my opportunity ...

Expenses

The high cost of participation in depth freediving competition explains with particular features of safety and organisation. Always there are a lot of human resources involved to provide safety for the athletes. The tones of fuel being burned to take us to a diving site: we are not "shallow" guys and it is hard to reach a deep enough spot from a shore with our own two fins :). In addition, to compete successfully you need to explore the spot: to feel water (currents, temperature, salinity) and to pick out the appropriate equipment. Means to spend few more additional days on the spot. 

That's how accumulates the sum of couple of thousand dollars:

  • accommodation + trainings during the competition + competition fees = 110 euros per night. October 1-8th = 8 nights (departure late Oct 8th) = 880 euros. 
  • an additional training week before the competition has the same rates: 110 euros per night with the same package included. 6 nights * 110 euros = 660 euros. 
  • Sharm - Dalaman - Sharm flight. DLM - SSH is already booked and costed me $250. It is possible that I will fly to Dalaman not from Sharm el-Sheikh. But it's up in the air. At the moment, Sharm-Dalaman costs $100-150.
  • "trivia": transfer from/to the airport, sports insurance, some equipment, oxygen for recovery between training sessions, payment for organization of deep training in Egypt, etc.
  • Total: (880 euros + 660 euros) + $ 350 = 1540 euros + $ 350 = $ 1820 + $ 350 = $ 2170 + "trivia."

My gratitude

I offer the most valuable thing that I have: my experience and knowledge O :). 

Most of the time I spend in Dahab, where you can freedive with me at sea or practice in the swimming pool. But if this quiet town does not stand in your route, then here's another suggestion: starting  from this year I'm actively working on a system of distance training programs. I still can not teach from scratch on-line :), but those who already freedive can significantly improve their results. If you are interested - contact me zharkova.nataliia@gmail.com or @natzharkova on facebook (and the specified contacts).

In addition to intellectual property, there are more material equivalents of my appreciation. More in the section "PERKS" ->.

If the required amount is not collected

Even if so, I'll still look for an opportunity: I'll walk to Kash from Sharm, I'll  live on the beach ))). Save as much as I can, but dive! In the worst case, if I  still can not go, the collected funds I will hold until the next competition.

I believe in the help of friends, fans and just sympathizers! If you do not have the opportunity to support my campaign financially, then you can help a lot by sharing a link to this page in social networks!

Please, spread a word for me O:). 

Sincerely. Nat.

Perks.

  • $25. Postcard. A printed picture with the warmest words of appreciation (image is an example only).
  • $50. On-line consultation. 30 mins chat about freediving. Advice, recommendations, questions about the trainings (how to plan, what to do etc).
  • $80. Discount $80 for a wetsuit from "Apnea" (if to order with me).
  • $100. Two training sessions in the sea, three pool sessions  or one session in the sea + two pool sessions, or "a deposit" for any other course. Plus a postcard.
  • $200. Personal training program 2*1 month + postcard + your sticker at my fins.
  • $500. Personal training program 3*1 month + a t-shirt of my freediving school "Deep Division" (picture represents a sample, design might vary) 
  • $1000. Champion's fins or monofin. The first equipment, what will pass a mark of 100m or sets up a record with me in it :).

story:
What We Imagine

Feast World Kitchen will be a downtown restaurant (3rd & Cedar) for Spokane's immigrant and former refugee community to share their culture through excellent international cuisine. We hope to showcase food from several continents: a different style of cuisine for each night Feast is open -- for both walk-up and order-ahead customers! We may start with takeout, but eventually our dining room will be a hub for cross-cultural community. Feast will be a place for empowerment and small business training. It will be a place for friendship. It will be a place for fun cooking classes and private events... even food truck rallies and fundraisers! If we have space, it will also be a home-base commissary kitchen for caterers and food trucks who want to rent some prep space (generating some self-sustaining revenue). This is what we imagine. Let's make it a reality.

Our goal is to create an incubator kitchen and community gathering space, which will feature a rotating group of immigrant and former-refugee chefs. Amazing international cuisine, available several nights a week on a rotating basis! Hypothetical Example: Wednesday is Middle Eastern / Mediterranean, Thursday is Inland Curry, Friday is Senegalese (West African), and so on...

All the while, our chefs will have a chance to start their own food businesses and make connections in the community, building their own brands through private catering gigs when it isn't their own featured night. Feast World Kitchen will provide a platform for exposure that will allow them to make vital income for their families. Our chefs will be purchasing their own ingredients and renting their time in the kitchen (at very reasonable rates), so they are full partners in this effort -- they don't want handouts, but they could use a hand up. To that end, Feast will help navigate the permitting processes, provide some startup funding, and hook chefs up with optimal small business training, so they can begin building a local food presence to share their culture -- without the barriers of major financial risk or trying to navigate the long, difficult road to success on one's own.

The Back Story: A Community Effort... to Build Community

In the past few years, Dan Todd and Ross Carper have been walking parallel paths. Dan launched Inland Curry, a weekly pop-up carryout spot at 9th & Walnut (operates out of the Woman's Club). A couple blocks away at 10th & Maple, Ross rolled out The Compass Breakfast Wagon. Both live just a few blocks from the places they serve food to neighbors. And both have been greatly blessed by friendships with former refugees in Spokane -- Dan through hosting a successful monthly refugee-chef dinner series, and Ross through his work at First Presbyterian Church (FPC), helping organize World Relief "Good Neighbor Teams" and befriending international kids and families on the lower south hill. FPC has a long history of befriending immigrant neighbors, including The Barton School, a free ELL program beginning its 51st schoolyear.

When the former Arctic Circle / Sushi Yama building came available and FPC purchased it as an investment (both financially and as a way to impact the good of the neighborhood), Dan and Ross saw an opportunity. They began exploring (with several other neighbors) the idea of taking a big leap: forming a new nonprofit that combines their love of food and cross-cultural friendship. Maisa Abudayha joined the conversation and began taking on new leadership opportunities. Over the summer, she used Ross's food trailer to serve awesome Jordanian food as a pilot project, cooked as a sub at Inland Curry, and served in leadership with Feast's newly forming group of international chefs. A board was formed that includes friends with tons of wisdom. Papers were filed.

And so, after months of conversation, dreaming, planning, and action -- and FPC's generous offer to rent the building at a discounted rate -- Feast World Kitchen is being born into the world this fall. And we think it's going to be a beautiful baby! But we need lots of "midwives" (YOU) for this project to come to life :).

Will you join our circle of neighbors, who aim to create a new space for food, friendship, and empowerment?

In addition to Dan and Ross, included in Feast's board and core group of partners/advisors:

  • Sajda Nelson, former refugee from Iraq who works as World Relief's Friendship Center Coordinator
  • Luke Baumgarten, co-founder of Spokane arts nonprofit Terrain
  • Beth Killian, licensed mental health counselor
  • Matt Goldbloom, neighborhood/nonprofit organizer
  • Maisa Abudayha, former asylum-seeker from Jordan, Mediterranean chef
  • Tony Epefanio, president of Greater Spokane Food Truck Association
  • Pingala Dhital, Bhutanese chef and World Relief staff member
  • First Presbyterian Church Spokane, our gracious landlord
  • The Smith-Barbieri Progressive Fund, generously serving as fiscal agent and startup partner as we get rolling.
  • Treatment, a local creative firm, offering up their branding/design/photo/video expertise!
  • ...and a network of great cooks from places like Bhutan, Senegal, Syria, Iraq, Mexico, Afghanistan, Jordan, Ghana, and more! We'll be introducing these folks individually as we go!

Feast Collective (our nonprofit name) holds the following vision and mission. These dreams will only come to life through your support!

Vision: We will be satisfied only when all former refugees and immigrants
living in the Spokane area have experienced welcome and inclusion and are
flourishing, as full, active community members.

Mission: Feast Collective will celebrate and empower immigrants and former
refugees and reduce community tensions through education, story-telling and meaningful
cultural exchanges.

What We Need & What You Get

There are many, many needs related to operating a new nonprofit that is also a business incubator and functioning restaurant! We are currently hoping to receive lots of "sweat equity" help and raise at least $25,000, which will support:

  • Many licensing and permitting fees and processes already in progress, both for Feast World Kitchen itself and to assist on the individual business and catering licenses for each chef, so they can eventually function independently, taking on catering jobs of their own and, if they choose, blossoming into their own restaurants, catering companies, or food trucks.
  • Transformation of our well-worn building into a clean, fully functioning, up-to-date commercial kitchen... We're going to be honest: it has lots of equipment that works and "good bones" but this old burger/shake joint turned sushi spot needs some serious work. But we can see its potential: first for takeout on limited evenings, and ASAP: we will be finishing off attractive, comfortable indoor and outdoor dining areas for people to linger and enjoy the flavors together!
  • Bringing on our Executive Director (Daniel Todd of Inland Curry) and hopefully an administrative specialist in staff roles.
  • Special extras like transforming the former Sushi Yama front counter into a massive professional chef's table that will host many fun cooking classes and special gatherings!

By donating toward these needs, you'll get some great perks, but the biggest perk is the positive impact you will have on our city's culture.

The Impact

By contributing your time, talents, and funds to Feast, you are making a statement. We believe former refugees and immigrants in Spokane should be met with love, hospitality, celebration, friendship, opportunity, and shared cultural learning and understanding. We don't believe they should be met with fear, racism, bigotry, scapegoating, and suspicion. Feast World Kitchen creates a needed space for the former, as we try to do our part to dismantle the latter.

Help us:

  • Bring the community together joyfully around food, a universal language.
  • Provide opportunities for flourishing for our neighbors from around the world.
  • Make Spokane a better, more hospitable (and flavorful!) place.

Risks & Challenges

To be honest, all food-related operations come with risk. They are costly to start and maintain, and profit margins can be tight. However, with an existing restaurant building, low rent rates, and lots of experienced partners and advisors, we believe we can overcome these challenges.

By presenting a compelling story that people want to participate in, and by pursuing excellence and integrity in all aspects -- from our incubator program to our financial transparency to our food quality and safety -- we will succeed. There will be bumps along the way, but Spokane is ready for this. In fact, you're still reading this because perhaps you're ready to participate somehow, too.

Other Ways You Can Help

Aside from funding, we need physical help from volunteers! Sweat Equity Crew: Fill in this quick form if you want to physically help us do work!

In addition, it really helps if you share this campaign far and wide, especially when you share it one-on-one in a message or conversation with someone you know will be excited about it! And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools to post about Feast anywhere and everywhere!

Bringing on our Executive Director (Daniel Todd of Inland Curry) and hopefully an administrative specialist in staff roles.

Special extras like transforming the former Sushi Yama front counter into a massive professional chef's table that will host many fun cooking classes and special gatherings!

By donating toward these needs, you'll get some great perks, but the biggest perk is the positive impact you will have on our city's culture.

The Impact
By contributing your time, talents, and funds to Feast, you are making a statement. We believe former refugees and immigrants in Spokane should be met with love, hospitality, celebration, friendship, opportunity, and shared cultural learning and understanding. We don't believe they should be met with fear, racism, bigotry, scapegoating, and suspicion. Feast World Kitchen creates a needed space for the former, as we try to do our part to dismantle the latter.
Help us:

Bring the community together joyfully around food, a universal language.
Provide opportunities for flourishing for our neighbors from around the world.
Make Spokane a better, more hospitable (and flavorful!) place.


Risks & Challenges
To be honest, all food-related operations come with risk. They are costly to start and maintain, and profit margins can be tight. However, with an existing restaurant building, low rent rates, and lots of experienced partners and advisors, we believe we can overcome these challenges.
By presenting a compelling story that people want to participate in, and by pursuing excellence and integrity in all aspects -- from our incubator program to our financial transparency to our food quality and safety -- we will succeed. There will be bumps along the way, but Spokane is ready for this. In fact, you're still reading this because perhaps you're ready to participate somehow, too.

Other Ways You Can Help
Aside from funding, we need physical help from volunteers! Sweat Equity Crew: Fill in this quick form if you want to physically help us do work!
In addition, it really helps if you share this campaign far and wide, especially when you share it one-on-one in a message or conversation with someone you know will be excited about it! And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools to post about Feast anywhere and everywhere!
