story:
Please help now because your contribution will directly fund the launching of this much needed movement, that will make all the difference in saving lives.

TEAM EARTHQUAKE's mission is to protect children in major earthquake disasters of the San Andreas or other damaging faults. It begins by giving parents the "BIG PUSH" to honestly look at their own lack of training and first aid skills and the absence of available first responders in their neighborhoods and schools when a major earthquake hits. 

Calculations estimate that serious injuries will be upward of 52,000 people, doubling with fire complications. NOBODY IS COMING to HELP YOU unless you organize it now. WE ARE NOT PREPARED.  Where will you go for help when "BIG ONE" hits? It seems like every community has no clue. There isn't even a meeting place for those that need help or can help. WHY NOT? Local and City Governments are slow and too cautious with liability, jurisdiction, and just plain afraid of stepping on toes. In the end, we all lose out with weak disaster plans that lack sufficient human man power for medical first aid and search and rescue in our schools, neighborhoods and homes. Nobody is taking charge. It's up to us.

We will lose many lives if we don't organize now.  It may be our own life or a family member's. We have a duty to at least try our best to get it right  before the earthquake, at least for our children's sake. Dead is dead. We may not get a second chance if we get it wrong. 

Our Strategy :Together is Better

This campaign aims to bring action by focusing on parent volunteer groups that already have the experience of working together such like schools, PTA, Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts, AYSO, Little League, YMCA, any other organizations with community/parent volunteers. We will work to coordinate, togetherness now , a melting pot of volunteers of different organizations for the common cause of community disaster first response and relief. 
These groups can supply valuable information to fire departments, search and rescue volunteers, and emergency services about what needs to be done, what has been lost, and who is missing or injured. They know each other and have established a social network which will be important in figuring things out quickly , in saving lives when the chaos surrounds us in the earthquake aftermath.
This is not another talk plan, or useless call tree (at a time no phones will be working). This is an ACTION PLAN and it goes into action the moment the ground starts shaking. Until that day, we will actively push parents to 'Get off Their Butts' and get CERT training (FEMA's Community Emergency Response Teams) and earthquake FIRST AID even for the kids. 

TEAM EARTHQUAKE is the Big Push for disaster preparedness in schools and in communities.  We will strive to get a 'Neighborhood Earthquake Response Station'  in front of Every Public School with trained CERT volunteers leading the community. We will be relentless in targeting established organizations to 'GET OFF THEIR BUTTS'  to prepare for this horrible disaster. We will make it our job to pull everyone together , to plan together, to work together, to train together. Together is better.  It's our only hope to get through it all. It's  COMMUNITY RESILIENCE and we have to begin now.

"As Mayor, I have no greater responsibility than the public safety of Los Angeles. And here in our city, it's not a question of if the so-called "Big One" will hit. It's a matter of when.  So we cannot afford to be complacent. The known risks- to life, property and our overall economy- are too great. " -Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti

The 2015 Los Angeles seismic report and plan, 'Resilience by Design'  points out that "non-ductile reinforced concrete buildings are among the deadliest buildings in earthquakes around the world...and are currently used as apartment complexes, schools, hospitals, office buildings, warehouses and more. 

AB 300 Report, titled "Seismic Safety Inventory of California Public Schools"  was enacted to determine the  seismic safety of our public schools K-12. The shocking results  9,659 school buildings are on the AB 300 list, with about 7,500 school buildings that were deemed by the state as potentially hazardous and in need of a detailed structural evaluation, according the Californiawatch.org. 

The Disaster Ahead (in case you don't know)
The Southern San Andreas Fault was studied by the top experts and seismologists such as Lucy Jones of U.S. Geological Survey. The result was The ShakeOut Scenario detailing the estimated 50,000 plus emergency care injuries, 1,800 fatalities, and doubling those figures if the estimated 1,600 ignited widespread fires could not be controlled. Secondary hazards such as thousands of landslides of rock and soil, ground liquefaction, tsunamis, and seiches will all pose a significant impact on disaster response, complicating relief efforts.

The Lack of Planning

Many school districts currently hold the "we've got it covered" attitude. They "don't want screaming parents running to the schools" after a major earthquake. Hmmm?.  School boards discourage parents from organizing disaster response at schools ,fearful of liability yet most teachers and staff are sadly not trained in earthquake injuries or basic search and rescue. Many medically skilled and qualified parents will be locked outside the gates of the school after the disaster strikes even if the building has collapsed or is on fire.

Fire fighters will be dealing with the many fires around the city  Law enforcement, will be protecting the law. Relief workers will need days to reach us if they decide to come to our area. All communication will be down. Who will help? Who will be there for our children?

TEAM EARTHQUAKE ; Together is Better

We will strive to get CERT volunteer run NEIGHBORHOOD EARTHQUAKE RESPONSE STATION  in front of every public school with a tree of trained community first responders , skilled residents, ready to be there, for our children and for us . The moment will come without warning and the force of the powerful San Andreas will pound away at our doors and rattle our homes.  Will we be ready? Who will help?

Please help now because your contribution will directly fund the launching of this much needed movement, that will make all the difference in saving lives.

story:
Short Summary

The social center ДЦ КРОВ (“Social Center ROOF”) is a new community space located in Belgrade. It is a creative hub powered by an original membership system, which we are now extending through this campaign. We are a non-corporate union of NGOs; the three founding communities of ROOF are Visual Anthropology Center – VAC; Center for Ethno-musicological Activities – CED and Collective VIZANTROP cooperating with various organizations and individuals.

Furthermore we offer our members diverse programs connected to visual anthropology and ethno-musicology:  local and international workshops of documentary film-making and photography, workshops on ethno music, film screenings, artist residencies for socially engaged filmmakers and social scientists, not to mention various lectures, concerts and other social events.

This campaign is fundamental for us to overcome limitations of borders and other boundaries that would keep us from having a truly global community. We invite you not simply to support a cause but to become a member and actually join this community. All the perks related to the campaign serve this purpose. Our mid-term goal is to continue with this campaign in further phases (in demand) and update it accordingly, so please follow the developments as there will be more to come.

We just opened our doors for the public this Spring, but after the great start raising a lot of interest, we had to temporarily close them again because of the CoVid19 pandemic. This means all but stopping our new activities, as a matter of fact it means we have to come up with more.

This campaign was supposed to focus only on the physical development of ROOF, but due to the global crisis we need to work also on new methods and immediately establish a workflow also in the digital space.

Hence, as you will see in our video presentation, the campaign sets milestone goals. The first goal is basic survival and establishment of the ROOF, the further goals its development to reach its full potential.

What We Need & What You Get

We need new members to join our local and global creative community. A successful campaign wouldn’t simply mean a good start for us, it would serve as the foundation of both our digital community and of DC KROV as a community space – a real social network. A hub of people sharing interests and passions in the field of social sciences, video and photography and ethno music.

Your contributions will improve the Roof with a silent room/recording studio and a video studio for audio and video production and post production, both equipped to suit all professional requirements.  International and local independent filmmakers and documentary enthusiasts and scholars will get a space to work and network, discuss and realize new ideas together in an inspiring environment.

As a first step in these hard times we will update our programs with digital courses and and workshops. Then, as soon as possible we will open the editing facilities for distance work or for individual sessions on-line workshops.

All the perks related to the campaign get you a membership in our community wherever you are in the world. To enjoy all benefits of the membership you will have to visit us once life gets back to normal, but there is a lot we can achieve together before that happens. We offer digital courses, lectures, workshops and we are determined to share our resources with all of our members in these times of crisis. For more details check out the perks!

We will do our best to provide all the programs and activities we offer even in case this campaign should not be successful. We are counting on your support and we're confident that our minimal goal will be met, however many of our future project are based on support exceeding the minimal goal.

Supposing the smallest perks would be more popular, reaching 1600  euros would not just mean we are safe for the next three months and we can finish the audio studio, but that we can count on 2-300 new members who would be interested in the programs and services we can offer.

In the range of 3000 euros we could also complete upgrading the video studio with the best available performance technology. That would also mean that we'd have a large local and international member base.

Around 5000 euros we could complete all of the above, plus we could upgrade the residence room to be more comfortable and have a powerful editing machine itself.

In the range of 10000 euros the Roof would be fully equipped and renovated and our running costs would be guaranteed for 2020 regardless of the major catastrophe that is disrupting social life in the first months of the year.

In short, we need you and your contribution to the community and if you are the kind of person this campaign is meant for what you get is exactly the kind of place that you need for working and networking.

 

The Impact

ROOF will be able to function as a professional hub offering the highest technical quality for independent audio-video productions.  We will never compromise any of our community principles to match the corporate competition but we will always  meet the highest professional and creative standards. ROOF as a social center located in the center of Belgrade will serve as a meeting point for creators and their audience while the development of digital strategies will strengthen our international network to reach beyond borders. In times when measures of social distancing are crucial for public health, ROOF as a social center and a community has to find ways to prevent these measures from alienating people. Solidarity and a sense of community can’t be limited by restrictions of movement. We can keep working on these together no matter how many miles or walls between us.

 

Risks & Challenges

The main challenge we are facing right from the start is to keep our newly opened social center alive and grow the community despite of the radical measures of social distancing taken by the state(s) recently. Our society had severe issues that were only aggravated by the pandemic of CoVid19. We founded the Roof to tackle these issues, we believe that the harder the times we are living the most crucial it is for socially engaged, creative people to find new ways to reach out to the world.  

Our ethnographic film workshops, as well as individual and group residency programs have to be delayed until the end of the pandemic due to limitations of the freedom of movement. We will use these times to develop digital strategies, but connecting to our audiences without the chance of meeting in person is a great challenge.

While we firmly believe in transparency and keeping people informed, in our view corporate media is often contributing to the panic. People feel that viral infection is the biggest threat, social distancing is advised as an epidemologic measure. While we do what we can as responsible citizens, we must also look for ways to strengthen and spread social solidarity in our communities with the audio-visual content we create. Visual anthropology and ethnographic methods in creating visual content is essential in the interpretation of adaptive social life in times of crisis.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support our campaign you can always  share it. Follow VAC', CED and Vizantrop on social media and don't miss out on our activities. Every post click matters in sharing awareness about us and we will be grateful if you share your views with us. We are open for your suggestions as well so don't hesitate to contact us if our community raised your interest.

story:
Let's keep this simple...

Videodrunk has been one of Toronto's most eclectic and adventurous film festivals since 2014.

For our 2019 edition, happening November 28-30 at the Grand Gerrard, we want to make our festival the biggest and best it has ever been. In order to do this we need your help.

Our goal of this campaign is the raise enough funds to cover the cost of our venue rental ($1500) or as much of it as possible. We're looking for this amount because it will allow us a lot more funds to use for promotion and to put towards the fun stuff (aka beer, with and without alcohol and comedians). And of course helping filmmakers attend.

The festival will happen with or without these funds.

story:
The Portland Seedhouse was founded in 2014 in Portland Oregon, where it maintains a diverse seedbank of culturally significant varieties with remarkable flavors and stories. We find and breed rare, diverse and resilient seed varieties for farmers, gardeners and seed savers.  

We are honored to have been selected as one of the 500 US delegates to attend biennial Terra Madre & Salone del Gusto global food and farming conference hosted by Slow Food International from September 20-24 in Turin, Italy. This year's Terra Madre theme 'Food for Change' embodies what is at the very heart of the Seedhouse. As agricultural biodiversity continues to decline at alarming rates, we need to change the way we look at and eat food - from the ground up!

Terra Madre provides an excellent opportunity to build relationships, provide platforms for sharing stories and cultural traditions, while suporting ideas for crafting a new vision for our global food system. Working together, we can promote agricultural diversity and the value of seeds.  

Follow the Snail: 

Following Slow Food Terra Madre, Seedhouse Stewards, will embark south to prominent agricultural regions (Apulia, Basilicata, and Calabria), collecting the seeds and stories from those farmers who have worked so diligently to preserve them over the years.

Inspired by promoting good, clean and fair food, the Seedhouse believes that diversity is key to our food security. Historically, about 10,000 plant species have been used for human food. Today, only 150 plant species make up more than 70 percent of our food. Nearly 75 percent of the genetic diversity of agricultural crops have been lost since the early 1900's. Climate change, habitat destruction, land subsidence, and even war and social unrest have decimated our world seed supply. This loss in biodiversity decreases our resiliency, but also threatens a traditional way of life for many. Preserving diverse seeds promotes the preservation of traditional cultural practices and values. 

Seedhouse Curator, Evan Gregoire, found his calling in 2004 when he became a Master Gardener and unearthed a love for soil nutrition, biodiversity, organic methods, and community involvement. He soon recognized the necessity for a new generation of farmers and started educating and empowering others about sustainable food production practices. On the farm, he now specializes in preserving heirlooms and open pollinated vegetables, flowers and heritage animals. Joining the Seedhouse in 2015, Amber Ayers, brings her passion for sustainable food systems and resiliency planning together with Gregoire to create a dynamic team dedicated to making a difference in the future of food.

Support the Seedhouse and "follow the snail" as we embark on our travels through Italy to find the most resilient and flavorful varieties to share with you, collecting stories about the passionate communities that have cherished and preserved seeds for generations. Seedhouse ambassadors will strengthen existing relationships and bring back Italian biodiversity to the PNW, making these culturally rich and flavorful varieties available through our website and select stores so that you can be part of this seed saving journey. 

Why now?

Genetic diversity is crucial for adapting to new environmental conditions, as more variation in genes leads to more favorable traits within plants that can adapt to our changing climate. Farmer-developed varieties that are adapted to local environmental conditions are one of the strongest defenses to sporadic and unpredictable changes. Italy has a similar climate to Oregon and the Seedhouse will collect seeds and gain traditional wisdom from communities that have been raising animals and plants for thousands of years.

With further commercialization and consolidation of seeds, a shift over the control of seed ownership has fundamentally changed farming in the U.S. Instead of allowing farmers full access to seeds that they have cultivated over centuries, recent laws and regulations have led to mega-corporations having a dominant control over the world’s seed supply. For centuries; gardeners, breeders, and farmers have fostered genetic biodiversity in seeds by selecting for locally adapted varieties to thrive in diverse soils, geographies, and climates. Keeping a diverse seed stock is not only important for farmers, consumers, and priority interest’s groups but also the economy.

As delegates, Slow Food, pays for conference admission, meals and lodging while at Terra Madre. Connecting with farmers through the Slow Food network, the Seedhouse will travel south to the Puglia region, which contributes to about 22% of the Italian vegetable be growing area. The region is particularly rich in local vegetable varieties, obtained from farmers themselves after repeated selections generation after generation. The funds the Seedhouse raises will pay for airfare, transportation and lodging to search for vegetable seeds from farmers, distributors and seedbanks.

The Seedhouse has been featured by Portland Monthly, Capitol Press, Eater PDX, Slow Food Portland, Modern Farmer, 1854 Magazine, Williamette Weekly, Portland Mercury, Edible Portland and other national publications. Since 2014, the Seedhouse has filled backyards, gardens, and farmers with thousands of seeds over 50+ varieties from the 2014 trip alone.

Thank you so much to all donors for your amazing generosity, time and consideration in helping make this vision a reality.

Special thanks to:

Pizzeria Otto, Gather and Feast Farm, Burrasca Italian Restaurant, Domenica Marchetti and many others who help make a difference by supporting regional biodiversity. 

*******************************

Please help us get the word out by sharing this link with others you feel might wish to donate and please post it to your Facebook, Twitter or wherever!  Thank you so much! 

Eating is an agricultural act - WB

This year's Terra Madre theme 'Food for Change' embodies what is at the very heart of the Seedhouse. As agricultural biodiversity continues to decline at alarming rates, we need to change the way we look at and eat food - from the ground up!Terra Madre provides an excellent opportunity to build relationships, provide platforms for sharing stories and cultural traditions, while suporting ideas for crafting a new vision for our global food system. story:
The Festival

EveryBody Outside Festival
Saturday, July 6
1pm - 11pm
Location: Coronation Park (Lakeshore & Strachan) 

Hi, we're EveryBody - a monthly dance party hosted by Danny Thrax and Me Time. You may remember us from such epic nights at Round Venue as EveryBody Move, Sweat, Out There and Dream. Can't remember? This should help.

Now it's time to take EveryBody OUTSIDE for a dance party in the park - from family-friendly afternoon wiggles to sultry sunset vibes making way for a twinkling summer night. We'll dance in the sunshine with grass between our toes, lay out picnic blankets, shop local artists and listen to sweet house music wafting across Lake Ontario.

A Special Celebration

Did we mention it’s also EveryBody co-founder, Me Time’s birthday?! Our resident fruit-bearing bass witch is turning FUN years old, so we’re calling all our festie besties to help her celebrate in style. 

Dress to Express

:: Costumes Encouraged ::
Theme: FESTIVAL FANTASY - Dust off those Burner threads, throw on some fairy wings and kitty ears, snatch your wig, and dust yourself in glitter, we don't care that we're in the city, we're living the full festival fantasy without sleeping in a tent. 

Your Impact

This is a donor-supported initiative and your donations will cover the essentials of the event:

  • 15,000+ watts of sound, powered by Tarna's QSC KLA System
  • Cleanup to leave our park better than we found it
  • Event staff to keep the environment safe and positive
  • Basic lights, permits, toilets, staging, and other necessities

Our commitment to you is:

  • A DJ lineup of our faves that just won't quit 
  • An market of local artisans to help your festival outfits pop
  • A flow arts jam for the love of wiggling
  • Surprise performances cuz who doesn't love surprises
  • An accessible, intentional, safer space for all bodies to move feely 

Contributors will be issued a wristband to show they were a crucial supporter, and made this whole event possible. 

Let's be the Music City we wish to see in Toronto 

This open-access festival is made possible by the City of Toronto and the Grassroots Digital Arts Association entrusting us to bring our beautiful community vibes to the park. With the city losing its most cherished music venues, this is our chance to be the Music City we know we can be. 

But we can’t do it without you!

Our ability to host this event relies upon the generosity of our donors. Permits, staff, insurance, and equipment are all ready to go, but we have to reach our target for us to create the kind of event everyone will love.

Please spread the word and thank you for all of your support!

RSVP on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/441637506401112​

Photos by Kieran Meyn (@sojufancyhuh)

story:
The journey of Julia Pastrana -a Mexican Carnival artist who lived in the 19th century- packs enough oddities for a whole Netflix series but remains unknown by most. As a bearded lady, Pastrana traveled all over Europe and the US throughout her life and after it. Let us explain: for over a hundred years after her death, her mummified body was passed on from hand to hand being exhibited around the world. Enter NYC-based visual artist Laura Anderson Barbata* who in 2013 managed to arrange the transferring of her body to her hometown in Mexico to finally -more specifically 153 years later- be buried.

On July 29th, 2017, a pool of creatives who have produced something inspired by Pastrana’s story will be gathering at the Museum of Art and History in Santa Cruz (CA) to celebrate her life and share their work with the community.

A symbol of disrespect and exploitation, Julia’s story speaks directly to the souls of anyone who has been rejected and/or vilified for being "different” and to all those of us who fight for equality. Given the current sociopolitical landscape of our country, it becomes crucial to foster the conversation regarding the rights of women, immigrants, African Americans, the LGBTQ community and minority groups.

*Miembro del Sistema Nacional de Creadores de Arte

Who we are

Dr. Kathleen Godfrey, a Ph.D. from Arizona State University, has developed a historic database containing documents (newspaper advertisements, marriage records, pamphlets, etc.) related to the artist's life. Both will be with us to speak and share about how they came across the story of Julia, how it affected them and about what they produced as a result of this encounter.

 

 

Physical actor and comedienne Larissa Garcia has produced and performed in San Francisco A  (Bearded) Lady, an award-winning solo play greatly inspired by the story of Pastrana, which she will be sharing with the Santa Cruz community. Larissa has been seen in the Magic Theatre's production of The Lily's Revenge (by and starring New York based performer Taylor Mac) and worked as a performer in the San Francisco street promotion Cirque du Soleil's project OVO.

 

 

 

Laura Anderson Barbata,  through her project The Repatriation of Julia Pastrana, achieved the feat of successfully removing the body of Julia Pastrana from the Schreiner Collection in Oslo to be repatriated and buried in Sinaloa, Mexico, Pastrana´s birth state. The project initiated in 2004 and continues with an upcoming publication and Opera. We will be sharing the body of work she has produced inspired by Pastrana.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Besides offering talks and a play, the event includes a series of audience  engaging activities and an opportunity for local business and artists to showcase their work and support our community.

story:
**CORRECTION**

Estimated date for COMADRE PERK is June 29, 2017

 

WE CAN DO THIS TOGETHER!

14 years ago, Celebrate Mexico Now established itself as the first (and only!) festival committed to promote contemporary Mexican art and culture in New York City. We have been a platform for over 300 talented visual artists, musicians, dancers, authors, chefs and filmmakers to showcase their work in over 50 cultural organizations around the city.

Our festival has presented world premieres of performances, talks and exhibitions by Natalia LaFourcade, Ely Guerra, Alondra de la Parra, Ricardo Legorreta, Enrique Norten, Rafael Lozano-Hemmer, Erick Montes and Elena Poniatowska, among others.

This year, we are thrilled to announce that Celebrate Mexico Now is going beyond New York City. We are partnering with The Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C. and the Los Angeles Philharmonic at the Walt Disney Concert Hall for additional performances from festival artists!

Join us October 14-22, 2017 in New York City for outstanding events including film screenings, concerts, culinary programs, panels, and performances.

 

OUR IMPACT

For over a decade, Celebrate Mexico Now has highlighted the creativity, ingenuity, heritage, and heart that contemporary Mexican artists bring to every arts discipline and creative industry. Venturing into to the cutting edge of contemporary expression, Celebrate Mexico Now will bring New Yorkers an exclusive glimpse into how today’s Mexican artists reflect on and reshape Mexican identity in an evolving global context.

Funding for the arts has been cut dramatically in recent years, but we haven’t let that stop us. We have successfully completed 5 Indiegogo campaigns that have let us bring the most dynamic cultural offerings to you.

The performances some of our artists will offer in Los Angeles and Washington, D.C., will further expand the Festival’s multi-disciplinary nature. Mexico Now’s mission involves offering a comprehensive cultural snapshot of the passions and concerns that make today’s Mexico so rich, complex and fascinating.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word with your friends and family about this campaign and Celebrate Mexico Now Festival. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to stay updated on everything happening as we get closer to our 14th edition!  


START HERE!

Donate and use #fundmxnow to share your support to our campaign on social media. The bigger our family, the better!

story:
There is no parallel to the loneliness felt by service members and their families when we send them to war... With exception to the loneliness felt upon their return. Barely into my twenties, after years behind the fraternal shield of protection and accountability granted by military life, I attempted transitioning back to the civilian world for the first time.  Late adolescence is confusing for everyone and when mine ran in tandem with the dramatic shift from a tribe based community to a solitary existence: I failed very hard, very fast.  I was depressed, anxious, and seemingly incompatible with, “normal” life.  Outside of the two-day transition course given by the military to all personnel before separation, in which you are firehosed with impersonal and seemingly unimportant information; I had no idea who, where, or what I was supposed to be.  Overwhelmed, I regressed back to the comfort of war, spending ~4 more years as a security contractor in violent parts of the world that to me seemed much less dangerous than the potential failures of reintegration with American life. 

Determined to build a modern solution to this old problem, in 2015 I returned and created, Victor. Victor is a bridge across the military-civilian gap that aims to make life after service less complicated and more socially empowered by connecting veterans and their families with the people, places, and information they need to smooth their transition and ease stress.  In return for a community being veteran friendly, Victor gives local businesses in that community the opportunity to market products, discounts, and jobs directly to a well-respected and widely known but elusive and not well understood demographic.

This campaign is not here to fix veterans; this campaign is here to build a community worthy of their return. We'd be honored to have your help on this mission, so please contribute in accordance with your capacity to help and desire to bring pragmatic changes to the veteran experience. If you are in tune with our message, we have two problems that you can help us fix:

1. Financial- Each monetary contribution will go directly into operational expenditures: Finishing the final stages of development and paying our bills.

2. Spreading the word- Each share, repost, like, or tag will directly affect our ability to help new veterans and communities build & find one another!  

Check out the article Founders Wire wrote about Victor App <Click here

story:
Help the Sing for Freedom Choir keep singing!

 

**UPDATE 23rd July 2020** We are delighted to have reached our initial fundraising target, thank you so much to everyone who has supported us!  We are keeping the fund open and welcome all additional donations - the choir costs upwards of £25000 a year to run so every penny will help us secure their long term future and reach even more people.  This year we want to increase the pastoral support we can offer our members and also reach new singers, and your donations will support us to do so.


The Sing for Freedom Choir is a very special organisation. Made up of refugees and asylum seekers, survivors of torture, and local community members, it's a vital support network for people who have experienced extreme difficulties in their countries of origin. This year, the choir has performed at a sell-out concert at Union Chapel and in a virtual choir video with the world-renowned King's Singers. We meet weekly to share our love of singing and build connection through music. 


It's no exaggeration to say the therapeutic impact of being part of the choir changes lives. As one of our members said, "One of the worst things about torture is that it silences you….the choir has given me back a voice".    


We want to continue giving these vulnerable people a voice in our society, but the ongoing Covid-19 crisis is putting a considerable pressure and strain on the lives of many of our members - who are already more at risk. 


Which is where you come in


We've been able to keep our choir going with online rehearsals and we're working on exciting projects for  Singing Our Lives.

Your support will enable us to continue rehearsing online and provide a vital lifeline to our choir members. Specifically, your support will go towards:

- covering staffing costs of the music director and administrator
- helping our members connect to online rehearsals by providing second-hand devices or smart phones
- helping our members pay their phone bills and access internet
- ensuring we can keep being a part of meaningful special projects, concerts and performances. 

 On behalf of our choir members, thank you so much for your generous support!

story:
Felabration Budapest is the second event in Hungary dedicated to celebrate the life and music of Nigerian musician, composer and human rights activist Fela Kuti. Among Fela’s original Egypt 80 band member, keyboard player and singer Dele Sosimi and Budapest’s brand new all-star afrobeat ensemble, The Mabon Dawud Republic, we have some of the city’s finest singers joining forces on stage: Sena Dagadu, M3nsa and Saïd Tichiti.

A crucial artist of afrobeat, Fela passed away 20 years ago, in 1997. It was during a ten-month tour in the United States that he came to know the organizations that fought for civil rights. Upon returning home, his music and way of life became radicalized. His lyrics would speak out against social injustice, he and his band Africa 70 would give five concerts a week, and the events would include political speeches and religious ceremonies. He lived in a commune with his closest followers and his family, which they symbolically declared to be an independent republic, and which gave work to hundreds of people. Fela was routinely imprisoned and beaten after the release of an anti-governmental song; he was arrested over two hundred times.

Felabration is a music festival founded in 1998. The original event in Lagos is a one-week happening, with countless guest performers, concerts and other events. For many years, independent, one-day Felabration concerts have been held in a growing number of cities around the world (London, New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo).

Fela was routinely imprisoned and beaten after the release of an anti-governmental song; he was arrested over two hundred times.Felabration is a music festival founded in 1998. The original event in Lagos is a one-week happening, with countless guest performers, concerts and other events. For many years, independent, one-day Felabration concerts have been held in a growing number of cities around the world (London, New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo).

story:
About Me

My name is Gloria Church and I am an ambassador in Girl Scout Troop 1512 Natchitoches, Louisiana.  Currently, I’m working on my Gold Award project to acquire a state historical marker at Briarwood Nature Preserve for Caroline Dormon.

Summary of Caroline Dormon

Caroline Dormon was born at Briarwood in Saline, Louisiana in 1888. During her time, Dormon accomplished a great number of things for Louisiana.  In 1921, Dormon became the first woman to work for the United States Forestry Department, and she later took major part in establishing Kisatchie National Forest, the only national forest in Louisiana.  Dormon is mostly known for her work in studying and domesticating the purple/ blue Louisiana wild irises.  The great pioneer also was the author and illustrator for a hand full of books about wildlife, including “Flowers Native to the Deep South” and “Bird Talk.”  In 1936, Dormon was recruited by Franklin D. Roosevelt to represent Louisiana on the De Soto Commission, board of five people who mapped out the route of the explorer De Soto.  Dormon is also considered the first nature conservationist in Louisiana because of her work with conserving native wildlife through landscaping.  Dormon worked for Huey P. Long on the Highway Commission Beautification Project, where she preserved native plants along the highways.  In 1965, Caroline Dormon was awarded an honorary doctorate in botany and horticulture from Louisiana State University.  Dormon’s legacy became Briarwood Nature Preserve after she passed in 1971. 

Why You Should Donate

I chose to do my Gold Award project on Caroline Dormon because she is underrepresented in the local community considering her great amount of accomplishments.   By establishing a state historical marker, not only does it share the history of Dormon, the sign will attract people into Briarwood Nature Preserve to see her legacy.  I believe that women who had smaller, but important, accomplishments in local regions are not given the credit they deserve.  The sign is a small step, but a push into encouraging other girls to represent historical women in their local regions.     

Where the Funds go.

Most of the funds will be going toward the bronze marker and some of the funds are going toward installing the sign.  Once the money needed on the marker is used, all extra proceedings will be donated to Briarwood Nature Preserve. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways you can help fund the marker is by sharing this Indigogo page with friends and family who you believe will care about the cause.  Also, you can help underrepresented women by reading about historical women in your area.

story:
QUI NOUS SOMMES/WHO ARE WE

La Fonderie Darling est un centre d'arts visuels unique fondé et géré par Quartier Éphémère, organisme de bienfaisance reconnu entreprise d’économie sociale. Situé au cœur du Vieux-Montréal, cet espace soutient la création, la production et la diffusion d’art actuel, local et international. C’est dans le cadre exceptionnel de l’ancienne usine iconique de la Fonderie Darling, composée d’espaces d'exposition, d’ateliers et résidences d'artistes et de sa Place Publique, que nous diffusons une programmation exploratoire diversifiée accessible à tous.

---

The Darling Foundry is a unique visual arts center led by Quartier Éphémère, a registered charitable organization and social economy enterprise. Located in Old Montreal, the Darling Foundry supports the creation, production, and dissemination of contemporary art, and has served as an essential meeting place for local and international artistic communities for over twenty years. Through the Darling Foundry’s exhibition spaces, artist studios, residencies, and Place Publique that make up this exceptional former industrial site, we offer a diversified and exploratory programming that is accessible to all.

 

NOTRE PROJET/OUR PROJECT

La conservation du patrimoine bâti est un enjeu essentiel de revitalisation des quartiers et de préservation de la mémoire collective. La Fonderie Darling est un des derniers symboles de l’ère industrielle du XIXe siècle à Montréal. Aujourd’hui, avec la multiplication de vastes projets de construction domiciliaires et urbains des quartiers de l’Ouest de l'Île, une condition d’urgence a émergé: le devoir de protéger un édifice historique qui a su résister au temps. Le devoir, aussi, de protéger nos artistes, la création, et la pérennité de notre mission artistique au service de la communauté.

Pour en savoir plus sur notre histoire, visitez : http://fonderiedarling.org/historique.html

---

The conservation of heritage buildings is an essential aspect of revitalizing neighbourhoods and preserving the collective memory. The Darling Foundry is one of the last remaining symbols of industrial, 19th century Montreal. Today, as large housing and urban development projects are increasing in the western parts of Montreal, the situation is becoming critical. We have a responsibility to protect a heritage building that has withstood the test of time and a responsibility to protect our artists, artistic creation, and the longevity of our artistic mission for the community.  

To learn more about our history, visit: http://fonderiedarling.org/en/history.html 

 

 

POURQUOI MAINTENANT/WHY NOW

Dans ce contexte de mutations, Quartier Éphémère a soumis une offre d’achat du bâtiment de la Fonderie à la ville de Montréal, qui a été acceptée. Face à cette opportunité historique, l’organisme a su obtenir des subventions pour compléter ses fonds propres, notamment grâce au Ministère de l’Économie et de l’Innovation du Québec, à hauteur de 125 000$. Une subvention du Ministère de la Culture de 250 000$ est également à recevoir sous peu.

A l’heure actuelle, il demeure cependant un enjeu majeur: il manque 70 000$ au projet, et l’offre d’acquisition arrivera à échéance en septembre 2019: date passée laquelle la transaction ne sera plus possible.

Nous sollicitons l’aide du public montréalais pour récolter la somme manquante dans les délais impartis : il reste deux mois pour agir!

---

This context of change led Quartier Éphémère to submit an offer to purchase the Foundry building from the City of Montreal, which has been accepted. Faced with this historic opportunity, the organization succeeded in obtaining grants to complement its own funds, particularly $125 000 from Quebec’s Ministère de l’Économie et de l’Innovation (Ministry of Economy and Innovation). Another grant of $250 000 will also be coming soon from the Ministère de la Culture (Ministry of Culture).  

At present, a major challenge remains : we still need $70 000 for this project, and the offer to purchase expires in September 2019, after which time the transaction will no longer be possible.

 

COMMENT CONTRIBUER/HOW TO CONTRIBUTE

-   Effectuer un don sur Indiegogo/Donate on Indiegogo

-   Effectuer un don en argent dans la boîte de dons à la Fonderie Darling/Donate in cash in the donation box at the Darling Foundry

-   Parler de la campagne, la diffuser, faire du bruit/Spread the word, share the campaign, make some noise !

story:
(Magyar leírás az oldal alján.)

THE POINT

We need your support, because it is very expensive to organize an event that meets the high standards, providing the best quality and content.


WHAT IS THIS ABOUT?

In 2018, we organizing our 4th demo party. 
First of all: you will be with an excellent company, hardcore sceners with same interests, 
a great party, with presentations (or we will be your audience for your presentation) and contests.
In this year, we would like to reward the best releases with a recent graphics card (or other gifts, depends on our budget collected).
There will be some outside activities, like football and drinking competition - if we able to pay the drinks ;-)
 

WHAT ARE OUR GOALS

To ensure the financial background of this event. We need to keep the core of Hungarian demo scene together with a well-organized event.
Perhaps bring new people to the scene, sharing the fun of demo coding, graphics and music making both with retro and modern computers, 
they are even welcome to join our wild competitions. 


WHAT WILL HAPPEN IF WE REACH OUR GOALS


0 - 512$ collected

Sad thing, that we didn't hit our goal, maybe next time (or never ??? :-( )


512$ - 1024$ collected

With the entry fees included, we are able to pay the place and technical equipment renting costs.

target amount collected

We are happy to able to pay everything and all category winners will get some nice reward.

More than 2304​$ collected

The very best rewards for the first three winners. The important part, is to have outstanding prods.

Above 32,768$ collected

Feryx will disappear and change his face and name... (of course this won’t happen ;-))

 

[the same in Hungarian]

Nos hát tessék a tolmács..

Egyszer volt, hol nem volt, a pávát tartó lány szobrán túl, ahol a kurta farkú scener túr, Sülysápon. Létezik egy qbparty nevezetű esemény. (Északi szélesség 47 fok, 27 perc, 8 másodperc, keleti hosszúság 19 fok, 32 perc,2 másodperc.)
Nem lesznek itt gonosz palacsinták, harapós fánkok, hanem A paprikás krumpli lesz a díszvendég.

Nah de a lényeg: 

A közösségi gyűjtésre azért van szükség, mert nagyon költséges megrendezni egy ilyen rendezvényt és szeretnénk azt, hogy a maximális minőséget tudjuk megrendezni a scene közösségnek a lehető legtöbb tartalommal. 

Hogy miről van szó? 

Naná hogy a 4. qbparty finanszírozásáról

Először is egy kiváló társaságra számíthatsz a hazai és külföldi demoscene kemény magjának kikapcsolódásáról. Egy remek buliról ahol mindenkinek van azonos érdeklődési köre. Izgalmas szakmai előadásokra ha valaki jelentkezik hogy szeretne előadni mi biztosítjuk a célközösséget. 
Még izgalmasabb rilízekre és szeretnénk ezt honorálni is ezért kérjük a segítségeteket hogy mindenki aki megérdemli nyerhessen egy fasza viDejóKarit vagy x. attól függ mennyi cash gyűlik végül össze!
Szabadtéri kikapcsolódásra lehet akár focizni is de az ivóverseny bulibb :D , mindenre is ha van miből kifizetni :D, Paprikás krumplira és mindenféle emlegetni való partys történésre meglepetésre és boruló padokra. 

Mik a célok, 

A rendezvény anyagi hátterének biztosítása hogy a lehető legfaszább idei partyt tudjuk biztosítani, a hazai kemény mag egyben tartására az újak fiatal arcok meghódítására és persze hogy a szervezők elégedetten tudjanak a party után hátra dőlni hogy megcsináltuk az idei legfaszább partyt.

És mi is történik ha X és Y összeget elérünk?
0-512$ Elgondolkodtató lesz e folytatás?..Nem hinném
512-1024$ a belépőkkel együtt már kitudjuk fizetni a helyszín és a technika bérleti költségeit.
2304$ A Célösszeg Minden kategória első helyezett kap valami fasza díjat.
Még több jön össze Nagyon fasza díjak az első 3 helyezettnek.
Természetesen 32,768$ felett Feryx eltűnik és arcot és nevet változtat.. Persze neemis..

A lényeg tényleg hogy legyenek fasza prodok, Jó hangulat és minden ami kell egy jó partyhoz de ez pénzbe kerül támogass! ♥

story:
Freedom is legal. Thinking is courage. Beauty is ever present.

Everything started with an idea of a festival without product adverts, slogans, and plastic, without clichéd music and artificial trends. Where each of us is both the creator and the created. Without mindless consumption of entertainment, flat bonds, lazy clichés, paltering transactions, and privatization.

And then the idea of a festival became a new way of thinking.

Read the full manifesto here http://festivalskometa.com


 

Last year we started our exciting journey with a 72-hour session of exchanging knowledge, wisdom and genuinely positive vibes.

See last years programme here ...

Kometa received good reviews from the journalists and guests and was nominated for the cultural prize as the surprise of 2016 by Latvian National Broadcasting company (LSM).

Check reviews here (LV):
Parmuziku.lv
Latvian Public Media


Our goal this year is to make the festival experience just as diverse and unique as it was in our first year. We are in talks with artists and collectives from Germany, Nigeria, South Africa, Norway, France, Russia, Spain, Ukraine and Latvia to make it happen.

The envisioned stages of 2017:

World Stage that brings together diverse live acts from all around the globe.

Nomade Temple organized by a unique artist collective Nomade from South America, fusing electronic and folkloric music, drawing on the best of both worlds. See more here

Aware House for showcasing Baltic electronic music - the DJ and live sets will include the best of Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia. 60 hours of non-stop dancing, ranging from reggae, dub to techno, house and much more.

Kometa Academy for thought experiments, live discussions, asking forbidden questions, challenging assumptions and opening your eyes to the 'invisible' to encourage empathy, solidarity and cultural education.

Circus Village as a polyphony of established and upcoming contemporary circus artists who unite specially for Kometa Circus Village in order to create site-specific circus performances, and organize open workshops to all Kometians.

Open Sunday with free entrance to the festival, especially encouraging local communities, seniors and families with kids to visit the fortress and make encounters with other festival visitors and artists.


 

Kometa is dreamed to be an independent festival in order to retain full responsibility for the content we are sharing with our participants. It respects the historical environment in which it is happening and envisions a space free of advertisement.

This requires alternative financial solutions as we are not selling our audience for commercial entities to manipulate with their choices.

We need your financial support in order to build a line-up worth traveling for and make your experience at the Kometa unforgettable. All money raised are going to the artists' support, transportation fees, high quality sound system, set decorations and festival facilities.

Supporting the project you have an opportunity to get tickets for a special Indiegogo price:

Kometian ticket (only on Indiegogo) until 15th April — 30 EUR

Kometian ticket x 10 (only on Indiegogo) until 15th April — 250 EUR

Ticket prices will go up after the campaign.

Festival KOMETA is organised by Biedrība “Festivāls Komēta”, which is founded by a group of cultural and social activists who are members of different Latvian and international organisations. “Festivāls Komēta” is a non-governmental organisation (NGO) founded with an aim to organise a sustainable culture festival with aim to develop the abandoned Daugavgriva fortress, to include local communities in the creation of a unique open space available for everybody needs in order to flourish the civil society with the methods of non-formal education, music and culture experience.

Main partner organisations for festival Kometa locally are:

Kaņepes Laikmetīgās Kultūras Centrs

Bolderājas Grupa

Liene Jurgelāne – coordinator of the educational program for festival Komēta, board member of Kaņepes Culture Centre. Liene boasts extensive experience in educational and non-government organisations, as well as in organising international and intercultural projects. She is part of an artist collective Library of People - a nomadic gallery project that facilitates artistic interaction to promote dialogue and engagement surrounding cultural understandings of death; a facilitator of a variety of non-formal learning experiences in the field of global learning, artistic expression and activism and is coordinating the Imagine 2020 project with the New Theatre Institute of Latvia, which deals with art, ecology and possible futures. 

Kristine Ķikute-Krievkalne – has worked in television for more than 8 years where she has gained experience both in production and development of TV programmes and shows, and also has gained experience working in dynamic teams, managing various project groups and TV departments. In 2013, she organised an international festival “Oasis” in Georgia, focusing on organisation and production of various cultural events.

Lāsma Ozola - an expert in sustainable agriculture and food systems. She has spent multiple years traveling and researching the challenges of modern food systems and the opportunities for societies to manufacture healthy groceries in an environmentally friendly manner.

Marta Lortkipanidze - curator of Kometa’s informal education program for youth, assistant, coordinator of volunteers, proofreader and copy editor. In addition, Marta takes part managing culture events at Kaņepes Culture Centre, sings in an acapella group "Latvian Voices", teaches Latvian in Annas Ziedares Vasaras summer school in Australia, and has taken part in Latvian new theater festival Homo Novus.

Dāvis Kaņepe - a culture activist and a film director. In 2012 Dāvis was the initiator of Kaņepes Culture Centre, which has now become one of the most important contemporary culture centers in Riga that organises up to 250 events a year and has collaborated with more than 100 national and international organisations. Dāvis is also a co-founder of the social movement “Free Riga”. In 2016 with a group of activists started Kometa festival.

Kaspars Kondratjuks - has been an active event organiser for about 15 years and the major events he has been part of in Riga include: Knockout Festival 2007 and 2008, Club Essential 2004 - 2012; World Choir Games 2014; outdoor cinema project KINO PAGALMS season 2013, 2014; Riga International Film Festival 2015, 2016; Festival KOMETA 2016 and countless other smaller-scale events.

Agnis Leonovičs - by day, a seasoned translator and linguist; by night – an aficionado of ethno-electronic and other extraordinary music, a deejay and an event organizer. Upon discovery and falling in love with the globally thriving scene that fuses modern electronica with global folkloric heritage, he has been introducing it to Latvian audiences through his DJ sets, as well as by organizing audio-visual event series Pachamama Beats. Inspired by the US-born Burning Man festival, Agnis together with like-minded folks has been building the local Burning Man community and organizing an annual event DeJā.

Jānis Lipšāns - well thought of to communicate Kometa festival to the public through mass media and social media. Often takes on a task to produce genuine copy-write and is considered the head of communications and public relationships. Also known for being a rap artist and a producer Pikaso. Guest-author at Arterritory.com and Veto Magazine, original copy-write at Piens festival, contributing author-copywriter to several independent documentaries and advertising projects. 

Raitis Hrolovičs - a painter and a teacher, a year ago he graduated from the Latvian Academy of Art with a master’s degree in painting, however, his work does not fit into the frame imposed by the academic art. In 2016, he was included in the National Art Museum’s selection of young artists in the exhibition Tension (Spriedze).

Daniela Vētra - Latvian origin who studies contemporary circus at the Rogelio Rivel school of circus arts in Barcelona., she has been active in promoting circus in Latvia, as well as in building international networks. Circus Village led by Daniela will make your neck spin in ever so wondering fashion and heads roll in an aaaw-this-can't-be-real.

Bartolomeo Pampaloni - independent filmmaker and culture activist, currently living in Palermo, whose empathy with human race has led him to get to know different cultures and places from within. His debut full-length documentary about the lives of homeless community of Roma Termini central station is still traveling festivals two years after it's premiere in Rome Film Festival in 2015.
story_txt: Freedom is legal. Thinking is courage. Beauty is ever present.Everything started with an idea of a festival without product adverts, slogans, and plastic, without clichéd music and artificial trends. Where each of us is both the creator and the created. Without mindless consumption of entertainment, flat bonds, lazy clichés, paltering transactions, and privatization.And then the idea of a festival became a new way of thinking.Read the full manifesto here http://festivalskometa.com Last year we started our exciting journey with a 72-hour session of exchanging knowledge, wisdom and genuinely positive vibes.See last years programme here ...Kometa received good reviews from the journalists and guests and was nominated for the cultural prize as the surprise of 2016 by Latvian National Broadcasting company (LSM).Check reviews here (LV):Parmuziku.lvLatvian Public MediaOur goal this year is to make the festival experience just as diverse and unique as it was in our first year. We are in talks with artists and collectives from Germany, Nigeria, South Africa, Norway, France, Russia, Spain, Ukraine and Latvia to make it happen.The envisioned stages of 2017:World Stage that brings together diverse live acts from all around the globe.Nomade Temple organized by a unique artist collective Nomade from South America, fusing electronic and folkloric music, drawing on the best of both worlds. See more hereAware House for showcasing Baltic electronic music - the DJ and live sets will include the best of Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia. 60 hours of non-stop dancing, ranging from reggae, dub to techno, house and much more.Kometa Academy for thought experiments, live discussions, asking forbidden questions, challenging assumptions and opening your eyes to the 'invisible' to encourage empathy, solidarity and cultural education.Circus Village as a polyphony of established and upcoming contemporary circus artists who unite specially for Kometa Circus Village in order to create site-specific circus performances, and organize open workshops to all Kometians.Open Sunday with free entrance to the festival, especially encouraging local communities, seniors and families with kids to visit the fortress and make encounters with other festival visitors and artists. Kometa is dreamed to be an independent festival in order to retain full responsibility for the content we are sharing with our participants. It respects the historical environment in which it is happening and envisions a space free of advertisement.This requires alternative financial solutions as we are not selling our audience for commercial entities to manipulate with their choices.We need your financial support in order to build a line-up worth traveling for and make your experience at the Kometa unforgettable. All money raised are going to the artists' support, transportation fees, high quality sound system, set decorations and festival facilities.Supporting the project you have an opportunity to get tickets for a special Indiegogo price:Kometian ticket (only on Indiegogo) until 15th April — 30 EURKometian ticket x 10 (only on Indiegogo) until 15th April — 250 EURTicket prices will go up after the campaign. Liene boasts extensive experience in educational and non-government organisations, as well as in organising international and intercultural projects. She is part of an artist collective Library of People - a nomadic gallery project that facilitates artistic interaction to promote dialogue and engagement surrounding cultural understandings of death; a facilitator of a variety of non-formal learning experiences in the field of global learning, artistic expression and activism and is coordinating the Imagine 2020 project with the New Theatre Institute of Latvia, which deals with art, ecology and possible futures. Kristine Ķikute-Krievkalne – has worked in television for more than 8 years where she has gained experience both in production and development of TV programmes and shows, and also has gained experience working in dynamic teams, managing various project groups and TV departments. In 2013, she organised an international festival “Oasis” in Georgia, focusing on organisation and production of various cultural events.Lāsma Ozola - an expert in sustainable agriculture and food systems. story:
Short Summary

Aloha. I am Mahealani Uchiyama, and Iʻm the founder and artistic director of the Center for International Dance. I am a dancer, musician, teacher and author. 

I have been involved in dance and music since I was two years of age, and six decades later, am still dancing! I have, during different times in my life, learned and performed the dances of China, Java, Bali, the Caribbean, North Africa and North India. Through it all, my first love and motivating force has been the dances of Hawaiʻi and Tahiti. As a Kumu Hula, I have taught and led performance tours to Hawaiʻi, Tahiti, New Zealand and Mexico. 

This campaign is about celebrating our 25th Anniversary. It is also about re-establishing and recommitting to the core mission of this dance center – as a place where dance can be experienced as a form of healing for our multi-ethnic community.

This is important to me, because when I was a child dance made it possible for me to understand that I too had value, and a place in the world. We want to do that for others.

To celebrate our 25 years, we are producing a gala concert that will feature amazing performers of culturally-based dance, many of whom have played a role in the history of our dance center. Your contribution will help us to offset the expenses of renting the theater, hiring production staff and most importantly offering financial support to our guest artists. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We hope to raise $25,000 for our campaign - $1,000 for each of our 25 years. Here is how your contribution will help us:

Artist Fees: $13,000
Theater (tech rehearsal and performance) $5,000
Crew (sound engineer, lighting designer, etc.) $5,000
Publicity: $3,000
 

We have prepared some fun and unique awards for you! They include:

 

A Souvenir Program from the concert signed by the performing artists

25th Anniversary Commemorative Tee Shirts

Premier seats to the Gala Concert

Your name in our program

Admission for two to the VIP Reception

A fresh flower lei greeting upon arrival at the theater

A 30 minute performance by Hālau Ka Ua Tuahine at the location of your choice

And a two-hour boat cruise on the Bay for ten people (includes performance, appetizers and drinks).

Make an ongoing monthly donation of any amount from $25 and up and receive discounts for our self produced performances as well as admission to MUCIDʻs Annual Supporters Reception, as well as recognition in our programs and other communications.

Choose your own amount for a one-time donation and receive recognition in our programs and other communications.

Please know that whether or not our goal is reached, the concert will take place, and your contributions will help us!

The Impact

We hold that through exploring that which you are drawn to in depth, one can learn about one's self, connecting more deeply with who you truly are as well as with others from different cultures. The work of our dance center is to create a refuge for our diverse community; a welcoming place where we can connect with one another. Our 25th Anniversary Concert will showcase what can happen when we convene in an atmosphere of acceptance, support and goodwill. 

In our 25 years we have produced or co-produced these major events:

Diamonds, Shells and Amber
A collective performance featuring Suhaila Salimpour, FatChanceBellyDance, and Hālau Ka Ua Tuahine. Cowell Theater, San Francisco.

Hoʻolaha - Hula Spans The Globe
A concert featuring Hālau o Keikialiʻi, Hālau Nā Mamo Nōʻeau and Hālau Ka Ua Tuahine which celebrated the Hawaiian - Californian connection. Reed L. Buffington Performing Arts Center, Hayward.

A Walk By The Sea
A celebration of the unity of the human spirit including performances of Zimbabwean, Hawaiian, Tahitian and Cherokee music and dance. Julia Morgan Theater in Berkeley and Valley Center for the Performing Arts, Oakland.

Annual Repertory Concerts
An annual series of performances featuring the students and faculty of the Center For International Dance.  Julia Morgan Theater in Berkeley and Valley Center for the Performing Arts, Oakland.

20th Anniversary Concert
A gala concert celebrating 20 years of dance. Valley Center for the Performing Arts, Oakland.

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Whether or not you can contribute monetarily, we can always use your support in spreading the word about this campaign, the 25th Anniversary Concert, and our dance center!

    Please use the Indiegogo share tool on your social media platforms!

    Here are some scenes from our 20th Anniversary Concert!

story:
~EXTENDED CUT~

So it looks like we hit our initial goal- YAYYYYYYYYY! ...unfortunately the shutdown for venues like ourselves has been stretched beyond the initial cut off of mid-March and so in turn we are extending our goal as well. 

With that stretch we wanted to make sure we were offering up something different... and since we had quite a few people reach out to us and ask for some lower tiers of support, we have added this limited (2 wk) run of specialty options and thank you gifts- including music, booze, and PW merch (now if you already contributed at one of the higher membership levels we of course wont turn away any additional donation, but please know that we are already going to send along an extra thank you gift).

with this run we want to create a shared experience of sorts- so we have included various things for folks to put together an at home party package that will be delivered on 5/29 in time for our Sunset Stream (weekly music livestream set on PW rooftop).

(all 'Bar Box' orders will receive a follow up email within the week with a menu of options)

 

$20 

- Public Service digital compilation 

(a joint release with the label Public Release featuring 7 highly sought after tracks, rarities and remixes from the Public Release discography made available digitally for the first time to support PW and its staff).

Also included is a link to a PROMO ONLY live mix by Eug (Public Release), recorded at Public Works SF CA during quarantine. If you enjoy the tracks in this mix, please support those artists by buying from their Bandcamp or other digital and physical outlets.

 

$50

- PW Face mask 

- Public Service digital compilation

 

$100 

- ‘BarBox’ 

Name Brand Bottle and mixers of your choice to be delivered to your door on 5/29

- Face mask 

- Public Service digital compilation

 

$150 

- ‘Premium BarBox’ & PW enamel pin

Top shelf bottle and mixers of your choice to be delivered to your door on 5/29

- Face mask 

- Public Service digital compilation

 

$200

- PW Heart T-shirt 

- ‘Premium BarBox’  PW enamel pin

- Face mask 

- Public Service digital compilation

 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

 

The Buildup

Hey all, we as a venue have worked very hard over the last 10 years to provide a creative space and bring together the best in music, arts, and community events. As you likely know, the current global pandemic has forced Public Works to temporarily close our doors and reschedule (or in some cases even cancel) all events from mid-March through (at least) the beginning of May. This shutdown has presented many challenges for PW as a business, as an employer, and as a community.

We have been working diligently and desperately to take care of our employees while doing everything possible to make it through this current crisis in one piece. Everyone here is dedicated and committed to continue making PW a space where folks can make a living while “giving the people what they want.” But we can’t do it alone.

The Drop

This total shutdown means that all  income for the venue has stopped, but our ongoing expenses like rent, payroll, insurance, utilities, etc. have not. Unless we are able to bring in some revenue, there is a very real risk that Public Works won’t be able to stay open post quarantine.

With that in mind we’ve put together some amazing once-in-a-lifetime packages in return for your support; purchasing one of them now means we can all keep the party going later and make sure this amazing community we have built continues for years to come.

Varied levels of membership including:

  • Free coat check
  • Free tickets to shows
  • Express entry
  • Drink tickets
  • Lifetime guest list/free entry and more!

At any level, your contribution will help us navigate through this difficult time and continue to “give the people what they want” and keep this independent venue open for the community we have all built around it.

Please note that memberships are limited - once certains numbers of each membership have been backed, those would no longer be visible on the page to claim. Thank you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support financially we totally understand, you can always help just by sharing these campaigns, staying involved and interacting with us via Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter.

story:
*** Newsflash***

Thanks to some incredibly generous donations we have this weekend exceeded our campaign target!  This means that the choir can stay together and get started on this term's projects.  We are still open for donations, and further funds will help us to secure the long term future of the choir and welcome even more members. Thank you to all of you for your amazing support. 

****

In 2021, the Sing For Freedom Choir has ambitious plans to welcome new members, make a music video for Zero Discrimination Day, and hire a community support worker to provide vital pastoral support.

The Sing For Freedom Choir is a remarkable group of people who sing from a shared love of music to reclaim the voice that torture so cruelly tried to silence. This amazing and vulnerable community is made up of Survivors affiliated with UK charity Freedom from Torture after facing extreme difficulties in their countries of origin, and Londoners who join to sing in solidarity with them . In 2019 they were perilously close to shutting down and were saved by the crowdfunding community.

The Sing For Freedom Choir has fought to stay together during lockdown, providing a lifeline at a time where many of the members have found the usual services they access cut. Some of them have been working on the front line as NHS workers, and many of them do not have access to data and technology at home. Despite this, they have managed to make the "I Choose Love" music video as a demonstration of solidarity with survivors everywhere, inspiring resilience at the time of hardship and anxiety.

 

Your support will enable us to: 

  • Welcome new choir members who have also experienced displacement in January 2021
  • Zero Discrimination Day film project with the Soundabout Choirs, an inclusive choir whose members have severe learning disabilities
  • Hire a community support worker to offer vital pastoral support & signposting to services & opportunities
  • Offer training with digital technology and software
  • Continue to fund data payments for members throughout the continued pandemic

 

The impact of your support for this project means:

The project will enable more people who have experienced displacement to access the therapeutic benefits of singing in a choir. Sing For Freedom Choir has changed lives, and as one member says, "One of the worst things about torture is that it silences you….the choir has given me back a voice".

The film created for Zero Discrimination Day will empower people who regularly experience discrimination, including those with disabilities, refugees and asylum seekers, to provide a vision of what a more inclusive world could be through performance of "I'd Like To Teach The World To Sing", with a message of ending discrimination.

With services cut as a result of the pandemic, hiring a community support worker will offer, once a week, vital pastoral support and signposting to mutual aid, education and employment opportunities.

By offering training in digital technology and data support, we will enable our members to not only access the choir, but also connect to vital support services.

 

Your support: 

Please help us to support members of Sing For Freedom Choir to continue to meet online, and enable us to offer the technical support, training and pastoral support they deserve. 

£5 - will fund data payments for one singer for one week and enable them to get online

£15 - will fund a pair of headphones for one singer

£20 - will provide one member with a digital training session

£50 - will enable one choir member to participate in the video project for Zero Discrimination Day

£150 - will enable a community support officer to provide once a week, vital pastoral support and signposting to our members

£500 - will fund a bursary place for one choir member for one year
