story_txt:
Breve Resumen 
Soy profesor titular de la U. de los Andes de Venezuela, en derecho y ciencias políticas, desde 1965. Publicó una veintena de libros y muchos artículos en revistas y folletos. Se anexa listado
Como ahora no hay recursos para publicar, utilizar las redes (Facebook y blog) que se puede consultar libremente. Pero en muchos medios académicos se prefiere el texto escrito.
Al participar en esta campaña, los colaboradores para mantener el nivel de la Universidad, divulgar las ideas y los conocimientos y garantizar el derecho a la libertad de expresión. En última instancia, a salvar nuestra cultura, gravemente amenazada ahora mismo.     

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes
Están listos para publicar 6 libros (sobre temas jurídicos, políticos, históricos y sociales). De ellos, 3  este año y los demás el próximo año.
El costo de la publicación de los 6 libros es de $ 10,000. La venta de los libros no cubre ese monto. La inflación que sufre el país obliga a subsidiar a los compradores (en este caso estudiantes y académicos). La publicación se hará en Venezuela, para contribuir a mantener nuestra industria gráfica, seriamente afectada por la crisis. 
Los libros se publican en la medida en que se recauden los fondos. De manera similar, se se distribuyen los beneficios.
Los colaboradores de más de $25 recibirán los primeros tres libros publicados. Los de más de $ 50 los 6 libros publicados. Quienes colaboren con  mas de $100 (y así lo autorizan) serán mencionados al final del texto de cada uno de los libros    
 El impacto
La campaña me permite cumplir con mis tareas como profesor. Pero, permitir la Universidad cumplir con uno de sus finos: proyectos e ideas en la comunidad. Ya lo antes antes, pero no lo puedes hacer ahora, por falta de recursos.
En tiempo de crisis, solo se puede usar las cosas básicas, como las referidas a la alimentación y la salud. Es comprensible y necesario. Pero también se debe atender a otras necesidades del ser humano (como la educación y la cultura). No solo de pan vive el hombre
Hoy existe un consenso general en señalar que un cierto nivel de desarrollo cultural es indispensable para el desarrollo económico y social. Más aún, expertos en el tema señalan que la diferencia en el nivel de educación y cultura marca la diferencia entre los países (mucho más que otro factor).
¡De allí la importancia de los libros!         
Riesgos y desafíos
Es necesario que los posibles colaboradores entiendan que las necesidades no hijo solo materiales; que, también importantes son las cosas derivadas de la condición dual del ser humano.
Por eso, se debe insistir durante la campaña en las ventajas que se puede obtener con el desarrollo de la educación y la cultura. Y se debe mostrar el ejemplo de otros países del mundo. 
A través de los medios de comunicación y de las redes se pueden difundir estas ideas. Y también a través de contactos personales      
 Puedes ayudar de otras formas

 Pedimos a quienes no pueden colaborar con los recursos económicos que difunden los propósitos y características de esta campaña. Eso también es muy útil    
 
  ANEXO : CURRICULUM VITAE Y OBRAS PUBLICADAS
 
                          JESUS RONDON NUCETE – CURRICULUM VITAE Tovar (Estado Mérida),  20 de junio de 1.941.
ESTUDIOS
1.      Facultad de Derecho de la Universidad de Los Andes, Mérida (1.959 ‑1.964). Título de Abogado otorgado el l de agosto de 1.964 (con mención Suma cum Laude).
2.      Entrenamiento Gerencial de Administración Municipal en la Universidad Sur de California (1.964). Diploma.
3.      Curso de Doctorado en Derecho Constitucional y Ciencias Políti­cas en la Universidad de París (1.969 ‑1.971). Diploma.

ENSEÑANZA
Profesor (de pre y postgrado) de la Facultad de Ciencias Jurídicas y Políticas de la Universidad de Los Andes (Mérida), desde 1.965, en las Cátedras: Ciencias Políticas, Derecho Constitucional, Regímenes Políticos Contemporáneos y Políticas Públicas. Profesor invitado en cursos de postgrado de las Facultades de Arquitectura y Arte y de Ciencias Económicas y Sociales de la misma Universidad.
Conferencista invitado en Universidades de Venezuela, Colombia y Puerto Rico, así como en otras instituciones públicas y privadas.

story:
Syn Festival Edinburgh is a multi-arts festival for emerging Scotland-based artists so they can promote their work to wider audiences here in the capital! This year we are celebrating our 6th birthday! So far we’ve supported a variety of arts such as photography, painting, illustration, film, mapping projections, theatre, dance, music and more.

Who are we? We’re a bunch of art, theatre, music & movie lovers. We’re passionate about creativity & diversity. And most of all, we’re all volunteers.

Why do we do this? We believe there’re so many creative souls out there whose talent is worth a stage as well as so many people in this city eager to discover something new by attending free events. Yes, you heard it right: all Syn Festival events are free to attend and we intend to keep it so.

This is why we need your support. If you love the arts, if you are part of the creative community or a great fan of it, if you simply want to see more outstanding free events in Edinburgh, then this call is for you! Help us make the 2019 edition of the Syn Festival an even bigger and better hub for artists and the local community of Edinburgh. Make a donation today and share this video within your network. Even the smallest contribution will make an impact on the success of this festival. 

 

More about Syn Festival 

Syn means “with” or “together with”, as well as signifying mathematical addition in Greek. As a noun it translates as a pro, as opposed to a con. Syn Festival, which started in Edinburgh in 2014, constitutes a multi-arts festival which promotes intercultural dialogue. Taking into consideration that Edinburgh and Scotland in general are considerably multicultural areas, Syn, through various art, music, cinema and theatre events, brings to the fore the cultural discourse between South and North, the Mediterranean and Great Britain. To date, Syn has hosted five festivals in various venues of the city (Upper Church at Summerhall, Adam House, Teviot Row House, Out of the Blue Drill Hall) showcasing local creative talent.

Syn started in 2014 as an initiative of the Edinburgh University Hellenic Society, but since then our team has grown by students and professionals from a diverse range of cultural and professional backgrounds joining our volunteers team and/or our organising committee. Throughout the years, Syn has forged links with the Drama Short Film Festival (Greece), Be-There Corfu Animation Festival (Greece), Alba New Music Festival (Edinburgh), Edinburgh Greek Film Festival, Rebetiko Carnival (London) and the Italian Studies, University of Edinburgh. Syn Festival is a purely volunteer led organisation and prioritises on making art accessible to all by 'entry by donation' events. Additionally, each year, fundraising is held during the festival in support of vulnerable social groups such as refugees and the homeless. 

Check our webpage:

http://www.synfestivaledinburgh.co.uk/

Follow us on:

Facebook:  SynEdinburgh

Instagram: synfestivaledinburgh

Twitter: synfestivaledin

story:
"Art isn't created in a vacuum." ~Anonymous

Our Story

Hi there! My name is Rachel Berger and I am the founder of the Artist Co-op.  I'm an actor, writer and blogger in New York City. My passion to create the Artist Co-op came out of a a passion to bring the artist community together.

With the rise of coworking spaces across America, I realized that the arts community was lagging behind in this new development.

New York City is the cultural capital of the world, if we can create the Artist Co-op here, I believe it will spread into other major cities like L.A., Detroit, Chicago, Miami and Austin!

I want to thank you in advance for believing in the project. Because of your support we will be able to create a community of artists, businesses that help each other! 

"The fun for me in collaboration is: working with other people just makes you smarter; that's proven." ~Lin-Manuel Miranda

What we need

We are raising $25,000 in order to get The Artist Co-op off the ground.

Building Materials

  • Desks, chair, locker, bookshelves $1,000
  • Printer $500
  • Office Supplies $500
  • Phone $150
  • Industrial coffee maker & supplies $600
  • Lights $250
  • Walls $2,000
  • Security cameras $450

Get the word out

  • Advertising Materials $1,500
  • 501 (c) 3 filing & Trademark $1,250
  • Website development $1,500

Keep Lights On

  • Scheduling app $2,000
  • Electric utilities $1,500
  • Wifi $700
  • Insurance $1,800
  • Lock system $1,050
  • Accounting service $250

Just in case

  • Rent  $6,000
  • Unforeseen costs $2,000

TOTAL 

  • Start up and operations $25,000

"Acting is not about being someone different. It's finding the similarity in what is apparently different, then finding myself in there." ~ Meryl Streep

    Our Impact

    • In June 2016, The Artist Co-op hosted a four-day Pop Up at the Centre for Social Innovation. Over the four days, we cultivated, conversed, collaborated and celebrated the performing arts community.
    • Here's a list of companies, businesses and individuals that participated: The Farm Theater,  Ron Cephas Jones, Marin Ireland, Florencia Lozano, Courtney Romano, DISTINCT, NY Deaf Theatre, Girl Be Heard, Fire This Time Festival, Diana Oh, Lauren Whitehead, Anna/Kate Band, Fresh Ground Pepper,  Musical Theater Factory, The Bats, Theatre in Asylum, Poetic Theater Productions, The Hang,  Laura Sisskin, Audition Hero, The Artist Financial Support Group, Bookster, Forge, Script Match, Audition Answer, Abbott, Broadway Babysitters, Theatre Galleria

    Media & Press for the Artist Co-op 

    • Hottest Press about the Campaign: DNAInfo & Broadway World 
    • The Observer, American Theatre Magazine, Backstage, Playbill, Broadway World, Theatre Reviews Limited, Broadway Briefing, FOX News Radio, AND CO Blog

    "Jazz in itself is not struggling. That is, the music itself is not struggling... It's the attitude that's in trouble. My plays insist that we should not forget or toss away our history." ~August Wilson

    Challenges

    I realize this is a crazy thing to start in the most expensive city in the world but why not ... if the National Endowment for the Arts is being threatened under the current administration, "Art reflects the values, aspirations, and questions of a culture; it’s a mechanism for a society to articulate how it imagines itself." ~ Andy Horwitz

    “If art is to nourish the roots of our culture, society must set the artist free to follow his vision wherever it takes him.” –John F. Kennedy, former American President

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Help us spread the word via social media by submitting your video with what community means to you on a poster on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter with the tagline #TheHouseThatArtistsBuild
      • Here's a T.A.C. Community video by Shaun Patrick Tubbs: 
      • Publish your own T.A.C. Community video on our Instagram and Facebook!
    • Want to help us build out the space? We are looking for volunteers to help paint, build walls, assemble furniture and more. Please contact Rachel@TheArtistCo-op.com.

    THANK YOU SO MUCH!

    P.S. The Artist Co-op is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Artist Co-op must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

    P.P.S. Thank you Giant Spark, Caitie McCabe Photography and Scott Fetterman for creating a beautiful video!

story:
The Project: 

Whether it is coaching women on or off the field, Lizzy Mair is heavily involved in the local soccer association and initiated her life-long passion with the sport by coaching a “girls-only” soccer camp in her hometown, Salmon Arm, for the past 22 years.  After years of participating in the camp, as well as playing for Salmon Arm in a competitive organized soccer league, her daughter Kairo Mair volunteered and was eventually employed as a coach to help inspire and train other young female soccer players.

Through their time playing soccer they have learned valuable life skills that will carry on into their careers, relationships and overall lifestyles. Kairo has been fortunate enough to have been empowered as an athlete and as a female, with the help of such strong female role models in their community, such as her coach and mother Lizzy.  Kairo and Lizzy want to continue this tradition of empowering young females on a global spectrum.

What We Need:

We are hoping to raise $3, 500 in order to help purchase these items for the Akonjo Village:

  • Soccer Balls
  • Soccer Jersey's 
  • Running shoes 
  • Soccer cones and Pinnies
  • Reusable Menstrual Pads 
  • School Supplies 
  • Soccer Nets

Any extra funds will go towards helping develop the local school in the Akonjo village. 

The Intention: 

Through playing organized soccer Lizzy, Kairo and Libby, have had many empowering experiences and they want to pass these experiences on to young women in marginalized environments.

Team sports can help girls develop leadership skills, reliance, confidence, and self-esteem, which are all very important traits that they hope to convey through this camp. On top of developing and encourage female participation, they want to advocate the importance of physical activity and maintaining a healthy lifestyle through the power of sport. The main objective of the camp in Canada, stresses all participants to have fun, so on top of all the possible takeaways, pure enjoyment will be the number one priority.

The Team: 

Lizzy Mair : Head Soccer Coach  

Lizzy is from Salmon Arm British Columbia and works as a certified education teacher. Liz has a passion for soccer and has been coaching her daughter and hundreds of other young women in her community for the past 22 years. In 1997 she helped run the successful Girls Only Soccer Camp in Salmon Arm BC which still runs and inspires young women every year.

Kai is in her 3rd year of International Development at the University of Calgary. She has taken an interest on female empowerment and human rights with regard to sustainable development and hopes to pursue ambassador work for her country with the United Nations.

Libby Olson : Director/ Cinematographer

Samuel Wangai: Producer

The Project: 
Whether it is coaching women on or off the field, Lizzy Mair is heavily involved in the local soccer association and initiated her life-long passion with the sport by coaching a “girls-only” soccer camp in her hometown, Salmon Arm, for the past 22 years.  After years of participating in the camp, as well as playing for Salmon Arm in a competitive organized soccer league, her daughter Kairo Mair volunteered and was eventually employed as a coach to help inspire and train other young female soccer players.
Through their time playing soccer they have learned valuable life skills that will carry on into their careers, relationships and overall lifestyles. Kairo has been fortunate enough to have been empowered as an athlete and as a female, with the help of such strong female role models in their community, such as her coach and mother Lizzy.  Kairo and Lizzy want to continue this tradition of empowering young females on a global spectrum.


What We Need:
We are hoping to raise $3, 500 in order to help purchase these items for the Akonjo Village:

Soccer Balls
Soccer Jersey's 
Running shoes 
Soccer cones and Pinnies
Reusable Menstrual Pads 
School Supplies 
Soccer Nets

Any extra funds will go towards helping develop the local school in the Akonjo village. 

The Intention: 
Through playing organized soccer Lizzy, Kairo and Libby, have had many empowering experiences and they want to pass these experiences on to young women in marginalized environments.
Team sports can help girls develop leadership skills, reliance, confidence, and self-esteem, which are all very important traits that they hope to convey through this camp. On top of developing and encourage female participation, they want to advocate the importance of physical activity and maintaining a healthy lifestyle through the power of sport. story:
Each year, the dedicated priests of the Coru Cathubodua Priesthood pour our hearts and souls into service to our communities. We build safe, sacred, inclusive community spaces and gatherings where we can provide spiritual support to Pagans and Polytheists. We work to bring the Temple of the Morrígan to PantheaCon; we run A Hosting at the Morrígan’s Hearth, our gathering for Celtic polytheists, and we work all year round to be of service to our communities through pastoral care, ritual services, activism, and education. The consecrated spaces, the lovingly built shrines, the the numinous rituals of devotion, the work of community support  - we are honored to be of service in bringing these offerings to you.

But we need your help to make all this possible.

Our operating costs are significant - especially the cost of renting the spaces for community events like the Temple at PantheaCon and the Morrígan’s Hearth. This year we’re also budgeting for the cost of our IRS filing for official 501(c)3 church status.

You can help bring this work to life in 2019!

Your backing will allow us to pay for the PantheaCon suite rental, as well as the many forms of hospitality that we offer to all devotees and Gods there. Your backing will also help fund that 501(c)3 filing so we can gain our official status as a church. And, as a stretch goal, we’re aiming to also bring in seed funds to cover the site costs for the Morrígan’s Hearth Gathering - providing the Gathering with the financial stability to offer more scholarship spaces, comp or pay its presenters, and ensure we have everything we need to provide a safe and nourishing experience for participants. You can read all the budget specifics about our goals down below.

Our Backer Rewards

To make sure this fundraiser feeds you as well, we have some great rewards available to enrich your practice and grace your home: from enamel pins to wear, to devotional sculptures and art prints to display, incense and divination tools for your practice, passes to online conferences and more. Plus, to support our Morrígan’s Hearth Gathering, we’re offering pre-sales of tickets and cabin reservations. Coru Priests, Hearth members and community have gathered our creative efforts to offer these gifts to our honored backers, and we hope you find them inspirational. We can’t wait to share them with you!

NEW: UNLOCKABLE STRETCH GOAL BONUS!

Having met our primary goal AND our first stretch goal, we're adding an extra bonus perk that unlocks for all once we hit our next stretch goal of $5500.

BONUS perk: The "Guarding Your Death" Patch - This bonus perk will ONLY  be unlocked when we meet our second stretch goal of $5500 total funding. When that happens, ALL BACKERS who have contributed at $25 or higher will automatically get a patch included in your backer rewards - no additional spending needed! This killer 3" diameter woven patch sports brand-new original artwork by Morpheus Ravenna of an ominous raven, with the quote from the Morrígan: "It is at the guarding of your death that I am, and shall be." Perfect for attaching to a jacket, hoodie, backpack, or anywhere else you want to show a bit of grim joy from the Great Queen.

Graphic mock-up of the patch design - lettering may look different on the patch once it's produced.

If you want this patch, help us make sure we meet our 2nd stretch goal and EVERYONE with a backer contribution of $25 or higher gets it - no additional spending needed!

NEW: The Raven Collection: Sigil pendants by Sophia Fate-Changer - A special collection of handmade devotional and magical sigil pendants in fired, painted clay. We love these artful sigils! You can choose from three designs created by Sophia for our campaign: the Cathubodua pendant featuring Her sigil and distinctive carrion bird form; the Spellsong sigil designed to enhance the manifestation of a magical need (especially in times of desperation); or Queen Medb’s sovereignty sigil featuring Her crown and body shaped by spears.

Shown left to right: Cathubodua sigil, Spellsong sigil, Queen Medb's sigil

Honored sponsor - All backers will be listed on our website as an honored sponsor with our thanks. You’ll also receive an invitation to the private Temple Consecration ritual at PantheaCon for yourself and a friend.

Coru raven enamel pins - Wear the sign of your devotion with our new shiny enamel pin, imprinted with our raven in honor of the Morrígan in bold red and black.

Devotional art posters - A gorgeous art print, with devotional photography by Land Sea Sky Travel and original poetry by our own Barbara Cormack.

Morrígan devotional incense - Handcrafted Morrigan devotional incense by Vyviane Armstrong of Land Sea Sky Travel, a spicy blend including woad, poppies, dragon's blood and many other herbs.

Poetic divination tool sets - Our original poetic divination oracle, devised and consecrated by Coru priests for communicating with the Morrígan and Her sisters, using Her poetry from the early Irish myths, complete with poetic divination instruction booklet, a set of three consecrated bone dice and carrying pouch.

Skilled divination sessions - One of our professional diviners will help you in a 60 minute divination session conducted via phone or video conferencing. You’ll be able to choose your preferred diviner from among the priests of the Coru to help you with your questions.

Bronze corvid sculptures - We have a very limited number of gorgeous, cold cast bronze sculptures, in the form of a corvid skull with raised triskelion motif, made in dedication to the Morrígan by NineCraft Creations. These will go fast!

Morrígan's Hearth retreat pass - Your ticket to A Hosting at the Morrígan's Hearth, our annual Celtic polytheist devotional retreat, including tent cabin accommodation. This ticket gets you in at the early-bird rate of $125 - plus it comes with extra goodies you won't get if you wait and buy your ticket when registration opens to the public.

Morrígan's Hearth cabin pass for 4 people - Tickets for four to A Hosting at the Morrígan's Hearth, our annual Celtic polytheist devotional retreat, including your own 4-person tent cabin reserved for your group. This pass is valued at $500 (at the early-bird rate of $125 per person x4) PLUS extra backer goodies come with it,  so grabbing your tickets through this campaign saves you a bundle.

Year with Our Gods passes - Year With Our Gods online conferences provide a balanced mix of hands-on, devotional, and experiential practice with academic and lore-based studies for Devotional Polytheists and Pagans. We're offering a full pass to your choice of any 2019 conference.

Check out all the backer perk packages and grab yours before they're gone!

Budget

Our primary goal funds the base costs of the Temple of the Morrígan at PantheaCon, plus the 501(c)3 filing. At Stretch Goal 1 we’ll be able to cover 50% of base costs for the Morrígan’s Hearth Gathering, and Stretch Goal 2 will bring that to 100%. This is our third annual fundraiser and with our history of success, we’re confident that with your participation, we’ll be able to meet all these goals.

Primary Goal

Temple, 4 nights: $1,500.00
Filing fees for IRS church status: $500.00
Perks & campaign costs:  $400.00
Goal: $2,400.00

Stretch Goal 1

Seed funds - Morrígan's Hearth (50%): $1,275.00
Perks & campaign costs: $275.00
Goal: $1,550.00 | Total: $3,950.00

Stretch Goal 2

Seed funds - Morrígan's Hearth (50%): $1,275.00
Perks & campaign costs: $275.00
Goal: $1,550.00 | Total: $5,500.00

Join us in service and devotion!

If you’ve ever enjoyed celebrating the Gods in the Temple of the Morrígan, or if you've valued the community spaces we’ve created and the work that we do, this is your opportunity to participate directly. Or, if you aren’t an attendee at our events directly, but still wish to support living polytheist devotion, we welcome your support and hope that our backer gifts will help make that support worth your while.

We, the Coru Cathubodua Priesthood are honored to serve and look forward to another year of rich devotion and community service with the many communities and kinships of Paganism and Polytheism in their love and devotion of the Morrígan and the family of Celtic Gods.

Please back this campaign today and help bring us bring this work to life in 2019. And please share this link and tell your friends!

In Her service,

The Coru Cathubodua Priesthood

story:
Short Summary

This year’s tour plans to build on the success of last year’s MPF performance at the University of Maine in Orono, which represented the first time the festival, open to any resident throughout the state, had been performed outside of Portland.  Due in part to last year’s expansion efforts, the 2018 festival received scripts from a record number of Maine-based playwrights this fall (62 in all).  Acorn’s aim with this tour is to make sure that, if selected, any writer, their friends and family would have the opportunity to see their work in its world premiere production without having to travel to Portland, where the regular performance run will be held in the Studio Theater at 25A Forest Avenue April 26 to May 5.  Connecting the MPF to more writers from across the state is an important part of the MPF’s mission.  As the number and geographic diversity of the MPF’s submissions continues to grow, the festival will be able better serve the artistic community by offering production opportunities to a wider diversity of writers from across the state.  This campaign will also provide key seed funding to initiate a planned long-term partnership with Penobscot Theater to showcase each year's selections in Bangor.

 

What We Need

The budget for the Maine Playwrights Festival includes expenses directly related to the Bangor tour, such as the hard costs of transportation, housing, personnel, and marketing, as well as the soft costs of time and energy that will be needed to ensure the festival's design permits it to easily tour.  This campaign also helps to fund a pro-rated cost of the entire event's overhead.  Here are some specific details about what your contribution(s) would help fund:

What the following will "buy" for the Maine Playwrights Festival

$25 – covers travel reimbursement for one carpool of actors to Bangor

$50 – hires a local technician for load-in in Bangor

$75 – hires for one actor for the festival run

$100 – covers additional marketing and publicity for the Bangor performance

$250 – purchases costumes and set pieces for the festival production

$500 – covers U-haul rental and gas to transport sets & costumes to Bangor

$800 – rents the theater to perform in Portland for one week

 

How It Helps

Producing the Maine Playwrights Festival is a stretch for a grassroots, non-profit company like Acorn, but every year we are able to do it thanks to the generous support of people in our community.  Every dollar raised from this campaign goes directly to help produce the festival and support the tour to Bangor.  If we are unable to meet our goal, not only would the tour to Bangor not take place, we would also have to consider scaling back future editions of the MPF and making artistic compromises to keep it viable.  Acorn's entire budget for the season is less than $50,000, so every donation really does make a difference in the company's ability to produce the MPF every year.

 

The Plays

Here are the brand new works chosen to be a part of this year's Maine Playwrights Festival.  Your donation supports this work, and the overall work of all playwrights in the state by keeping the MPF thriving!

Featured Plays:

BOY MISSING, by Travis G. Baker In a small-town bar, Darcy and Jerry are going to have a ‘conversation’ about the missing boy who connects their families.

KNOCKS AND HOW TO ANSWER,  by Ron Kanecke Two lonely people at crossroads in their lives meet during a hurricane evacuation.

GESUNDHEIT,  by Parker Lemal-Brown After deciding out of the blue that he’s on his deathbed, a father’s cavalier attitude towards illness – and giving away his possessions – drives his daughter to desperation.

ANGELS WE HAVE HEARD,  by Gordon LePage After the arrival of an unexpected young guest, a successful New York real estate agent must appraise the value of her properties past and present.

SLEEPING AT CAMPOBELLO,  by Jennifer Reck Historical artifacts get borrowed and broken as the summer season at Campobello draws to a close, and a docent finds herself in a compromising position in the Roosevelts’ bedroom.

Semi-Finalist Scripts:

HIPPOS IN THE CATHOLIC SCHOOL PARKING LOT, by David Body Two befuddled school administrators try to cope with a sudden crisis: the surprising appearance of two leathery, gray hippos in their parking lot.

THE OTHER LIFE,  by Lynne Cullen After waking from a coma, a woman begins to doubt the reality of her life, and her marriage.

GUERNICA, by David Draheim Imprisoned and sentenced for resisting the fascist rule of Francisco Franco, how will Federico Garcia Goya choose to die?

WHOOSIE,  by Cassandra Powers Coming off a rough divorce, Sara seeks refuge with her family on New Year’s Eve, only to find it’s a stranger who can help her make peace with the chaos.

JUST SAYING, by Mary Katherine Spain When navigating the complex waters of relationships, an International Day of Honesty forces the most loving couples to either come clean or realize the error of bending the truth.

 

The Impact

A major goal of the MPF is to lift the level of playwriting across the state. Maine’s playwriting community is slowly growing, but writers have very few opportunities in-state to work on honing their craft, and few established paths to connect with successful, mid-career writers to serve as role models for dedication and ongoing artistic growth.  The MPF offers selected playwrights the chance to workshop their pieces with Callie Kimball, this year’s Playwright-in-Residence, as well as the chance to receive audience feedback over the course of the 7 performances in Portland and one planned performance in Bangor.  Expanding the festival to include a performance at PTC will not only provide playwrights with the chance to engage a whole new audience base in the work being created by Maine playwrights and get feedback from new artists and audience members.  A successful performance in Bangor during the 2018 MPF will inspire more writers in eastern, central, and northern Maine to consider writing and submitting new plays in future cycles (for 2019 and after), thus increasing the geographic diversity of the festival and expanding opportunities for writers from these parts of the state.  The tour will also help to forge ongoing relationships with playwrights in those areas with Penobscot Theater to hold future performances in Bangor.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign on Facebook and other social media to help get the word out!!

Maine’s playwriting community is slowly growing, but writers have very few opportunities in-state to work on honing their craft, and few established paths to connect with successful, mid-career writers to serve as role models for dedication and ongoing artistic growth.  The MPF offers selected playwrights the chance to workshop their pieces with Callie Kimball, this year’s Playwright-in-Residence, as well as the chance to receive audience feedback over the course of the 7 performances in Portland and one planned performance in Bangor.  Expanding the festival to include a performance at PTC will not only provide playwrights with the chance to engage a whole new audience base in the work being created by Maine playwrights and get feedback from new artists and audience members.  A successful performance in Bangor during the 2018 MPF will inspire more writers in eastern, central, and northern Maine to consider writing and submitting new plays in future cycles (for 2019 and after), thus increasing the geographic diversity of the festival and expanding opportunities for writers from these parts of the state.  The tour will also help to forge ongoing relationships with playwrights in those areas with Penobscot Theater to hold future performances in Bangor.
 

Other Ways You Can HelpShare our campaign on Facebook and other social media to help get the word out!!

story:
Short Summary

The Milwaukee Underground Film Festival (MUFF) began as a class offered to film students here at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. It has since evolved into an annual, internationally recognized film festival while still remaining student run. Our submission fees are low, admission is free and we want to keep it that way. Your donation will go towards venues, equipment, jurors and, of course, festival fun!  Let's make 2018 the best Milwaukee Underground Film Festival yet!

 

What We Need

Running a film festival can get expensive! Our goal is $3,000 to help cover various festival expenses, such as:

  • venue rental
  • equipment rental
  • travel for and hosting jurors 
  • supporting visiting artists
  • jury prizes

What You Get

With every donation you'll get a BIG thanks from us and will be mentioned in our festival program and on our website.  Depending on your donation level, you could also get various, super cool, MUFF merchandise that was designed by one of the students in our class! Posters, stickers, buttons, T-shirts! Follow our campaign to find out more about the artists over the next month. If you donate to one of the top two levels, you will be invited as a VIP to our filmmaker and staff brunch on Sunday April 22nd!  This would be your chance to rub elbows with the most creative people in town.  But really, absolutely everyone receives the best reward of all because admission to MUFF is free! We hope to see you at the festival! Introduce yourself to our staff if you attend.

The Impact

The Milwaukee Underground Film Festival has been an integral part of Milwaukee's underground film community for almost two decades.  MUFF continues to advance the art of underground film and brings Milwaukee's cinematic community together with international artists for one awesome weekend every year. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

As an underground student-run festival, we completely understand what it means to have a tight budget! If you are unable to donate, we won't be mad, we promise. You can still help MUFF for free! You can aid us by sharing this campaign and liking/following us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram!

story:
The Crispus Attucks Community Center has been a jewel to the SouthEast of Lancaster for decades. Since it's inception, Crispus Attucks has helped countless families with its food bank, its drill team, and multiple community outlets for the 7th ward to enjoy. Unfortunately today, it stands in need of some TLC, and we're the ones to do it! Our plan is to rehab the center, and house two performing arts entities inside. Along with the Mayor's office of Community Engagement, and the Love Your Block Iniative, The TCP Network and Rebel Chic Dance Co., will help once again bring the performing arts back to Crispus Attucks, but we cannot do this without your help!

Join us as we rehab our beloved Crispus Attucks building!!!

Extra Supplies/ Donations would be greatly appreciated.

Paint

Paint roller kits

Floor Buffer

Gloves

Scrapers / Putty Knives

Dust Mop

Wood Floor Cleaner

*Donated funds will be used to purchase cleaning materials, new light bulbs, new electrical sockets, new door knobs, and new paint/murals around the center!

story:
Basics

Just a Little Lovin' is one of the best known larps from Nordic larp genre, offering an immersive experience of friendship, desire, and the fear of death through three 4th of July parties in 1982, 1983 and 1984. Written by Norwegian designers Tor Kjetil Edland and Hanne Grasmo and first played in 2011, it has quickly traveled around the world - Norway, Sweden, Denmark, France and US -  and the hype is high. We're now bringing in to Finland for the first time, from June 5th-10th, 2018.

Needs

Larp running isn’t cheap. Just a Little Lovin’ is runs 6 days including workshops, and has relatively high production values. A big budget results in expensive tickets and reduced financial accessibility to players. Our tickets cost 275 euros, which, for a 6-day event including accommodation, is pretty great. But it will still be prohibitively expensive for some people, and those include people who we think really ought to have a chance to play this larp. 

That’s why we crowdfund – to offer subsidised tickets to players in a weaker financial situation. If we sold our tickets on a first-come, first-served basis, we could have easily offered tickets in several price categories. We decided instead to do a player selection to achieve better diversity in our players by nationality, larp experience, age, gender expression, and sexual orientation. The US run of JaLL prioritised players who were either LGBTQIA+, directly affected by the HIV epidemic, persons of colour, and/or have a low income. We will do the same.

A subsidized ticket will cost 175 euros, which can also be paid in parts. Our main goal is to fund at least 10 of these tickets. If we manage to crowdfund a even bigger amount of money, we use the rest to give a bigger leeway to our amazing set designer Tonja and lighting designer Essi. Any possible money left over will be donated to LarpFund or Hiv-säätiö (Finland's HIV association).

Approximately every 105 euros raised gives us about 1 subsidised ticket more for a person in need. About 5 euros goes to service fees, 100 euros on the ticket. We do have some another expenses, but basically that’s it. And if you can't donate that much – well, every euro matters.

We get nothing for this apart from the kudos of doing it. Our team works for free and the money we raise goes straight to subsidising tickets after we pay the Indiegogo service fees and any material expenses from perks.

Benefits

Can you spare 5 euros? Great! You'll get credit on our website as a supporter (under your own name, a nickname, or anonymously), and a special digital drawing by our set designer, Tonja Goldblatt. She promises gay rainbow cats in leather pants!

15 euros? Thank you! You'll get a personalised doodle from Tonja, credits on the site, and a sew-on Just a Little Lovin' patch.

We are currently arranging a fundraising draglesque club night in Helsinki, featuring local drag artists and queer stand-up comedy. A 20 euro donation gets you an early bird ticket to the event - plus a patch and credits on the site. There are also a couple VIP tickets, where you get all the above plus a photo session with Jamie, whose Polariod SX-70 camera screams 1980s authenticity.

If you live farther away, 30 euros gets you the patch and a personal video thank-you message from the organiser team that we can post on your FB, or just send to you. If you are a true 80s soul at heart and prefer original art to digital copies, 50 euros will get you an original gay leather rainbow cat drawing by Tonja.

We produce this run with Nordic Roleplaying Society. They donated books for us to offer as perks. You can check their publications out here: http://www.nordicrpg.fi/julkaisut/


Finally, our largest donations get some amazing experiences! A donation of 100 euros will get you and 4 friends your own run of JaLL's little sister, I Say a Little Prayer. It's based on the same events, but is a shorter game you can play in an evening. Our own experienced team will run it for you.

200 euros will get you your own personal drag coaching from House of Vanilla alumna HyperFemme. Get started creating your drag persona, or get coaching on a number you're already working on. Online or in person!

We will do this as a flexible campaign to reach the goal in any case.

Risks

If we don’t manage to raise money for subsidised tickets, we only sell the regular priced ones. It won’t affect whether the larp happens in any way, only who might be able to be there. If we crowdfund well, however, we will be very happy as we would have not only supported tickets but a bigger budget to work with for an even more immersive, memorable experience. 

If you have anything you want to ask from us or want more information about the perks just drop us a message or send an email to jallfinland@gmail.com. Can't a donate? You can help us to succeed - share our campaign with your friends!

story:
Celebrating 10 Years of Sounds and Colours

To celebrate 10 years of Sounds and Colours we were planning a big party this year. That’s not going to happen any more... but we are launching this fundraiser to make Sounds and Colours an even better resource for cutting-edge Latin American music and culture, and ensure our survival as we battle with a severe drop in advertising revenue.

One of the hardest things about this lockdown has been trying to figure out how life now works while also helping support as many projects as possible. It's been tough, but has made us realise how much Latin artists need media that they can trust and that fully supports their endeavours. It's for that reason that we felt it essential that we carried on with this campaign (which we had been planning since last year) and help ensure that we can continue to support Latin music and culture for another 10 years.

As part of our anniversary celebrations we're releasing two brand new projects, a downloadable compilation (which is OUT NOW) and a brand new book filled with articles and photos documenting Latin culture, which will be released in August 2020. We're selling copies of our compilation and book as part of this fundraiser as well as a collection of amazing perks donated by our friends and supporters, and some extra special items from the Sounds and Colours archives.

Read on to find out more...

Sounds and Colours: 10 Years Compilation

The compilation, Sounds and Colours: 10 Years is available now and features new, rare and unreleased music from Orkesta Mendoza + Mexican Institute of Sounds + Calexico, Kassin, Monte (the new project of Bomba Estereo’s Simón Mejía), Cabruêra, Romperayo, Mȁ̲̠̻ͥ̾ra͔̥̩̾͊̑cuyá͊, Santi & Tuğçe, Numa Gama, Santiago Córdoba, ESDLCP, DJ Mam, NILLO, M. Takara & Carla Boregas (RAKTA), Cineplexx, Kif, Maria Rita Stumpf, Dolli, Sentidor, Savan, Lulina, Tongas & Mates, El Buga, Kumbia Obscura and Pernett.

You can listen to the compilation at Bandcamp and buy it there, or in conjunction with some perks right here.

Sounds and Colours: 10 Years Book

We are also releasing the Sounds and Colours: 10 Years book which will feature 100 pages of brand new content, including the following:

  • special reporting on the protests that have engulfed many Latin American countries over the past 12 months (with text and photos from contributors in Bolivia, Chile and Colombia)
  • feature on the female producers breaking ground in electronic music in São Paulo
  • story on the impact of Mexico City's water crisis and how creativity and culture are being used to find a solution
  • an oral history of champeta, as told by the musicians, DJs and important figures who have helped champion the Colombian style since the beginning
  • the continuing tales of Brazilian soul legend Tim Maia, with new stories from Allen Thayer, the definitive authority on Maia (and Brazilian funk and soul in general)
  • a look back at the work of the influential Bolivian film-maker Jorge Sanjinés and his Grupo Ukamau collective
  • when strikes hit Colombia last year many musicians raised their voice in support - we take a look at how musicians played a role in this social movement, and to what end
  • a spotlight on the work of some of Bolivia's finest artists, who also share their thoughts on current social disruption in the country
  • we take a look at three social activist organisations in Colombia empowering young Colombians, who increasingly feel marginalised by society, through culture
  • plus, a retrospective of the best Latin films, books and music that have been released over Sounds and Colours' 10 years of existence

What We Need

We are looking to generate £5,000 to make the following happen:

  • improve our website – a long-overdue update to create the ultimate resource for Latin American music and culture. We will make content easier to find, fix errors and improve the look – we’ve already got some very nice original illustrations from Lee Hodges to help in that department. There are thousands of articles, including important research into Latin culture on our site, but it's not easy to find. We need to resolve that. We are looking for a budget of £1,200 to get this update over the line.
  • publish 10th Anniversary book - this campaign is partly a pre-order for our Sounds and Colours: 10 Years book, for which we will be looking to put £2,000 towards the cost of printing the book and paying our writing team
  • launch a membership scheme – to be able to offer premium content (i.e. podcasts, in-depth research articles, online film screenings) we will need a steady flow of income and are proposing a membership scheme to pay for that content. More details will be announced soon, but our plan requires a budget for initial costs as we look to build our subscribers. We are therefore planning to generate a £1,000 initial budget to subsidise the project in its early stages. As an added bonus of this campaign everyone who buys any perk will get a month’s subscription for free.
  • keep running Sounds and Colours as we are – compensating for the drop in advertising revenue, a modest budget of £800 will help us to keep the website running at moderate speed for the following months as we wait for the live events, whose advertising we rely on, to come back into our lives

What You Get

There is much on offer. As well as being able to buy the Sounds and Colours: 10 Years compilation, and pre-order the 10 Years Book, we are also selling donations very generously given to us by:

  • Mr Bongo Records
  • Mais Um Discos
  • And Other Stories
  • Songlines
  • NYC Trust
  • ZZK Records
  • Peace & Rhythm
  • Discos Rolas
  • Movimientos
  • Soundway Records
  • Shika Shika
  • El Palmas Music
  • Olindo Records
  • LAB (Latin America Bureau)
  • Sterns Music
  • Far Out Recordings
  • Dengue Dengue Dengue!
  • Mirjam Wirz
  • Chhoti Maa

Take a look at just some of these perks below (these are all available in the various bundles we're offering):

As well as items from the Sounds and Colours Shop, and a few choice vinyl items from the record collection of our editor, Russell Slater.

Everyone who buys a perk will additionally be given one months' free membership to the Sounds and Colours Membership Scheme when it launches later this year.

story:
Hey there!

My name is Maggie, and I'm a professional violinist and educator in New York City.

I've been teaching violin for over ten years, and along with my teaching colleagues, I've noticed a gap in instrumental instruction in our city. So many of our young, Suzuki violin students take private lessons in their own homes, and they miss the experience of playing in a group class with other children (which is a crucial component of Suzuki method learning!) Our students and their families expressed the desire to play their instruments with other learners, particularly in convenient locations. With this need grew the idea for Bow & Heart.

Bow & Heart is a group class program that serves as a collective of Suzuki students, their teachers, and their families. We meet in community arts centers and schools in locations throughout New York City, celebrating our communities' assets while playing our instruments together. We build our confidence and motivation and open our eyes and ears to one another, working to string together our musical communities while developing a deeper love for the violin.

 

What We Need 

At Bow & Heart, we charge our students a minimal fee to attend classes. This means it's crucial for us to raise funds in order to pay our teachers for their hard work! Additionally, for us to bring instruction to many communities throughout New York City, we need contributions to help us book class venues and purchase class supplies. Finally, we're building-in a "guest artist" component to our classes, where we'll bring in some of NYC's finest artists to help show our students all the capabilities of their music making.

Here's a breakdown of what your contribution can do for us:

  • $20 pays for a Suzuki method book or post-class snack
  • $50 pays for two music stands for class
  • $75 provides payment to one of our teachers per class
  • $100 covers the fee for class rental space
  • $200 provides payment for a guest artist 

 

Any funds raised beyond $4,000 will help us continue our classes over the summer and next fall, and expand our program to even more neighborhoods!

 

What You Get

We'd be incredibly grateful for your support. We'll let you know exactly where your contribution's going, and each support level has a different perk: invitations to guest artist classes, an arrangement of your chosen song performed by our faculty, a thank-you from our students, and more!

 

Why This Matters

There's something pretty great that happens when we play our instruments alongside one another. Along with making beautiful music, we develop an awareness of the sights and sounds coming from our neighbors. We move from what may seem like an isolating experience to a joyfully inclusive one. And along the way, we build a musical community that can be a lasting one.

When I was little, I looked forward to Suzuki group class as much as I did a birthday party. I knew I'd share music with my friends, learn something new, and have a blast doing it. Our teachers at Bow & Heart share these similar experiences and want to create a space for young violinists to do the same.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We're so happy you're here to learn about us, even if you can't contribute to our fund! We'd appreciate any help in spreading the word. You can always: 

  • Share this campaign via social media and e-mail.
  • Support us on
    • Instagram
    • Facebook
    • Our website

My name is Maggie, and I'm a professional violinist and educator in New York City.
I've been teaching violin for over ten years, and along with my teaching colleagues, I've noticed a gap in instrumental instruction in our city. So many of our young, Suzuki violin students take private lessons in their own homes, and they miss the experience of playing in a group class with other children (which is a crucial component of Suzuki method learning!) Our students and their families expressed the desire to play their instruments with other learners, particularly in convenient locations. With this need grew the idea for Bow & Heart.
Bow & Heart is a group class program that serves as a collective of Suzuki students, their teachers, and their families. We meet in community arts centers and schools in locations throughout New York City, celebrating our communities' assets while playing our instruments together. We build our confidence and motivation and open our eyes and ears to one another, working to string together our musical communities while developing a deeper love for the violin.
 

What We Need 
At Bow & Heart, we charge our students a minimal fee to attend classes. This means it's crucial for us to raise funds in order to pay our teachers for their hard work! Additionally, for us to bring instruction to many communities throughout New York City, we need contributions to help us book class venues and purchase class supplies. Finally, we're building-in a "guest artist" component to our classes, where we'll bring in some of NYC's finest artists to help show our students all the capabilities of their music making.
Here's a breakdown of what your contribution can do for us:

$20 pays for a Suzuki method book or post-class snack
$50 pays for two music stands for class
$75 provides payment to one of our teachers per class
$100 covers the fee for class rental space
$200 provides payment for a guest artist 

 
Any funds raised beyond $4,000 will help us continue our classes over the summer and next fall, and expand our program to even more neighborhoods!
 
What You Get
We'd be incredibly grateful for your support. We'll let you know exactly where your contribution's going, and each support level has a different perk: invitations to guest artist classes, an arrangement of your chosen song performed by our faculty, a thank-you from our students, and more!
 

Why This Matters
There's something pretty great that happens when we play our instruments alongside one another. Along with making beautiful music, we develop an awareness of the sights and sounds coming from our neighbors. We move from what may seem like an isolating experience to a joyfully inclusive one. And along the way, we build a musical community that can be a lasting one.
When I was little, I looked forward to Suzuki group class as much as I did a birthday party. I knew I'd share music with my friends, learn something new, and have a blast doing it. Our teachers at Bow & Heart share these similar experiences and want to create a space for young violinists to do the same.
